First Nations communities must lead the way in Ontario's bioeconomy. Jason Rasevych, president of the Anishnawbe Business Professional Association (Northern Ontario) , powerfully stated at the Scaling Up Bioeconomy Conference | #ScalingUpBio that First Nations need to have ownership and leadership roles in this growing sector.

Why? Because they hold inherent rights to the land and its resources. Their traditional knowledge and practices are vital for sustainable resource management.

ğŸŒº The bioeconomy depends on biodiversity as its foundation, and biodiversity is essential for the processes that support all life on Earth.

ğŸŒ´ For example, the rainforests of the Amazon Basin and Congo Basin are globally important carbon sinks. 

ğŸŒ Since all countries benefit from the ecosystem services of nature, bioeconomy strategies can provide value to countries with different levels of biodiversity and technological development.

ğŸŸ© For nature-rich countries, transitioning to a bioeconomy offers numerous opportunities for sustainable development by 

ğŸ”º Creating jobs,Â 
ğŸ”º Empowering vulnerable communitiesÂ 
ğŸ”º Driving economic growth. 

ğŸŸ¢ Vicente AraÃºjo from the Brazilian Ministry of Foreign Affairs highlights that countries with less biological diversity often have a greater science and innovation capacity that can support the bioeconomy. 

ğŸ§® Therefore, the bioeconomy presents a broad investment landscape for technology, research and innovation, even for countries with limited natural capital. 

ğŸ‡§ğŸ‡· Vicente states that Brazilâ€™s G20 Initiative on Bioeconomy aims to provide the international community with a tool that can help us address a multitude of global challenges. 

ğŸ“‘ A Global Stocktake Report details the bioeconomy strategy and practices of G20 members.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenomicsâ€™ Post Indigenomics 4,887 followers 2mo Report this post #Indigenomics Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 2mo Call for speakers! We are seeking visionary Indigenous leaders to take the stage at Indigenomics IMPACT 2025, happening at the Space Centre in Vancouver, April 8-9th.

This groundbreaking event will showcase transformative partnerships, thriving businesses, innovative investments, and dynamic initiatives, highlighting the power and potential of the Indigenous economy.

This conference promotes a strengths-based narrative of Indigenous economic growth, design, inclusion, and reconciliation. By uniting leaders from various sectors, Indigenomics IMPACT aims to achieve powerful outcomes in the Indigenous economy during this pivotal era of economic reconciliation.

Attended the City of Regina Indigenous Procurement Business Gathering, where the City reaffirmed its commitment to increasing Indigenous participation in procurement. With a 20% target, theyâ€™re actively working to create more opportunities for Indigenous businesses.

On a national level, the Federal Governmentâ€™s 5% Indigenous Procurement Policy represents a potential $22.5B annual investment in Indigenous enterprises. While targets havenâ€™t been fully met, the momentum is undeniable.

Procurement is a powerful tool for economic development, job creation, and self-sufficiency in Indigenous communities. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y Edited Report this post The enduring impact of colonization has significantly shaped our modern economic perspectives, leading to displacement and a persistent socio-economic gap among Indigenous peoples. However, the time has come for us to reclaim our narrative and strategically craft a future that aligns with the Indigenous economic worldview.

With the resurgence of business, entrepreneurship, and nation-building, there arises a crucial need for a dedicated space to focus on designing and healing our relationship with money.

ğŸŒ± Indigenomics DESIGN: Indigenous Wealth Dynamics ğŸŒ±
City: Saskatoon (venue to be announced)
Date: June 4th, 2024

This conference serves as a pivotal platform for dialogue on systematically transforming our approach to money, finance, commerce, investment, and capital markets. It is a forum for strategic healing and visionary design critical for the prosperity and sustainability of Indigenous communities.

Let's unite to forge a path towards a future where prosperity is deeply rooted in our cultural heritage, guided by Indigenous wisdom, and propelled by strategic innovation.

Title: Marwa Abdou's Post - LinkedIn
Description: Feb 26, 2023  Â·  Indigenomics Institute #economics #indigenomics #storytelling #canada #bookclub. NoÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
#economics #indigenomics #storytelling #canada #bookclub | Marwa Abdou Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Marwa Abdouâ€™s Post Marwa Abdou Senior Research Director | Advisory | Public Policy | Inclusive & Sustainable Development | Advocacy | Storytelling | Data Analysis 2y Edited Report this post Just before the holidays, Stephen Tapp, PhD gifted our team five books to offer inspiration for 2023. It didn't take long before I leapt towards Carol Anne Hilton, MBA 's â€œIndigenomics â€“ taking a seat at the tableâ€ and finally got around to reading it this weekend. 

If Economics as a discipline is about understanding behavior around our worldâ€™s limited resources, then Indigenomics should be a field of study on its own under that umbrella. For all economic practitioners. Indigenous lands are estimated to make up aroundÂ 20%Â of the worldâ€™s territory, containing 80% of its remaining biodiversity (IISD). And, my guess is these are very conservative estimates as they donâ€™t include unceded lands and territories. 

In 2011, TD Economics estimated that the size of the indigenous economy in Canada would eclipse $32 billion by 2016. That number has since grown 1.5 X â€“ expected to reach 100 billion by 2025. And yet, indigenous voices remain excluded (alongside numerous others).

Intersectionality is crucial in storytelling. Itâ€™s also fundamental in building a more connected understanding of the world. Making progress in todayâ€™s world requires us dig into and engage with multiple identities and perspectives simultaneously. Unfortunately, as humans we are wired to seek neatly defined boxes and checklists. It gives us a sense of security and comfort. But weâ€™re way past the point (or at least should be) of one-dimensional invitations or assigned seats. Representation canâ€™t be just about proportions because identities are complex and the world we live in requires agility and dynamism. So, perhaps that means that the table and the criteria around it needs to be scrapped, reimagined, and rebuilt, rather than just extended.

While itâ€™s a broad lens, there is a lot in this work that is transferable. As Hilton says Indigenomics is about â€œour relationship to ourselves, to each other, to the Earth, to our past, and our futureâ€. 

All in all, this book didnâ€™t disappoint. One that I wish existed (and was required) when I was a student. I hope it will have follow on work that digs further and more explicitly into the data and policy side of things. Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1mo Report this post #indigenomics in action #indigenouseconomy Keith Henry President and Chief Executive Officer at Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) 1mo Thank you Sam Laskaris and Windspeaker Media for the story about the current economic results regarding #Indigenous tourism in Canada as produced by the The Conference Board of Canada released this month. 

This is the most accurate media coverage about the concerns facing the Indigenous tourism industry that I have read so far.

Key takeaways:

1.  Non Indigenous tourism has surpassed 2019 tourism revenues as of 2023, reaching 113 billion in total revenues.  Was worth an estimated 105 billion in 2019.  
2.  Indigenous tourism remains well below the 2019 economic levels (was our best year ever).  The total is 3.7 billion as of the end of 2023 which remains 8% lower that 2019.  
3. More Indigenous tourism businesses than ever,  but less revenues overall.  
4.  Staffing remains a major challenge and is 5% less than 2019. 
5.  Growth projected due to the high domestic and international visitor demands, but Indigenius tourism will not meet revenues and job creation potential without key investments and still remain below 2019 levels. 
6.  Federal investments for our sector continue to decline and will reach the lowest level of Federal government support for our industry since 2017 in 2025. 

This remains a major concern to our leadership and team Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) We continue to create solutions but need partners to show tangible support as well. 

Go to this link to read the entire story. https://lnkd.in/grWXw3vB #2025iitc #DestinationIndigenous #indigenoustourism #ITDF #TheOriginalOriginal #indigenous #firstnations #metis #inuit 10 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Tourism Industry Association of Canada 30,003 followers 11mo Report this post As the Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) celebrates #TourismWeekCanada2024 , let's recognize the incredible impact the Indigenous Tourism sector has had and continues to have on Canada. 

As of 2019, Indigenous tourism in Canada boasted over 39,000 workers and comprised more than 1,900 Indigenous tourism businesses, contributing $1.9 billion annually to Canadaâ€™s direct GDP (up $1.5 billion in 2017). Moreover, it generated $1.1 billion in wages and salaries, and revenue generated $3.7 billion, showcasing its potential for growth and sustainability.  

More good news! In 2024, Indigenous tourism will  directly contribute a total of $800M in tax revenues to all three levels of government in Canada. 

Indigenous tourism is poised for even greater success. Strategic priorities have been outlined in Canada 365, the 2023 Federal Tourism Growth Strategy, and ITACâ€™s ambitious 2030 Vision to make Canada the world leader in Indigenous tourism. 

Download the Fact Sheet: https://ow.ly/5Vjx50RhucI #TheOriginalOriginal #IndigenousTourism #IndigenousTourismTeamCanada 35 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Indigenous SME Business Magazine 1,176 followers 8mo Report this post The Rise of Indigenous-Led Tourism in Canada!

Indigenous-led tourism is transforming Canada's tourism landscape, highlighting the strength and resourcefulness of Indigenous peoples. With a substantial CAD 25 billion investment from the federal government, this sector is set to thrive, offering genuine cultural experiences and promoting sustainable development. The Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) plays a pivotal role, fostering collaboration among associations, governments, and industry leaders. This growth not only boosts the economy and preserves Indigenous traditions but also fosters reconciliation and self-determination. By 2030, the industry aims to add 85,000 jobs and elevate Canada on the global tourism stage.

Read more at https://lnkd.in/gSrDy-4r Subscribe to the Indigenous-SME Business Magazine at https://lnkd.in/gBMWGCHX #IndigenousTourism #CanadaTourism #CulturalHeritage 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Shae Bird Tourism executive building destinations for community and the visitor economy. 1mo Report this post This latest economic research from Conference Board of Canada tells a lot about the Indigenous tourism economy across Canada, but for Alberta it highlights the resilience, leadership and alignment throughout this province. While the rest of the country continues on its journey to reach pre-covid impacts, Alberta has not only recovered but increased Direct GDP by an astounding 66% going from $141.1m (2019) to $234.2m (2023). 

 I am grateful to have been involved in such important work and look forward to watching Indigenous Tourism Alberta's continued success alongside all their partners.

The new look of the report highlights ITACâ€™s continued success in supporting its record-breaking year for members and the advancement of Indigenous tourism from coast to coast to coast.Â 
f
In the 2023-24 fiscal year, ITAC introduced new programs aimed at fostering long-term growth while maintaining a balanced budget. Notable national achievements include the launch of the Truth2Action Training, a reconciliation program for the tourism industry, and the Indigenous Tourism Destination Fund, which surpassed its target by raising $232,000.

To date, the Indigenous Tourism Fund's Micro and Small Business Stream, supported by the Government of Canada, has provided $3.7 million in critical funding to 145 Indigenous tourism businesses nationwide.

All age groups â€“ over 55 (98%), 35-54 (94%), and 18-24 (86%) â€“ believe the tourism industry is important to British Columbia's economy. #TourismWeekCanada2024 #BCTourismCounts Tourism Industry Association of BC (TIABC) // Destination British Columbia 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) 10,335 followers 2mo Edited Report this post #PressRelease : New Conference Board of Canada Research Shows Indigenous Tourismâ€™s Potential Falling Short of Post-Covid Recovery Goals Despite Growing Demand

Indigenous tourism has yet to return to pre-pandemic levels (in 2019), with inflationary pressures and workforce shortages serving as the key contributors, according to an economic report conducted by the The Conference Board of Canada (CBOC) and the Indigenous Tourism Association of Canada (ITAC) .

The report underscores the critical role Indigenous tourism plays in Canadaâ€™s economy. In 2023, Indigenous tourism directly contributed $1.6 billion to Canadaâ€™s GDP â€“ a decrease of 10 per cent compared to 2019, and an even greater decrease of nearly 24 per cent when adjusted for inflation.

Despite the downturn, Indigenous tourism in Canada generated an estimated $3.7 billion in revenues in 2023. Moreover, Indigenous tourismâ€™s total direct economic impact supported more than 34,700 jobs and contributed close to $730 million in direct government revenue (federal, provincial, and municipal).

â€œLooking ahead to 2025 and beyond, it will be more important than ever for our federal, territorial, and provincial partners to come together and collectively support the ongoing recovery of Indigenous tourism,â€ says Keith Henry , CEO and president at ITAC. â€œThis report highlights the sectorâ€™s positive impact on Canadaâ€™s economy â€“ and for Indigenous businesses across the country to thrive and reach pre-pandemic levels, ongoing and long-term investment is vitally important to the sectorâ€™s success.â€

â€œThe tourism sector is also facing greater inflationary pressures than other sectors,â€ said Alan Chaffe, PhD , Associate Director of Economic Research at The Conference Board of Canada. â€œPrices for tourism-related goods and services in 2023 were an estimated 18.8 per cent higher than in 2019â€”exceeding the economy-wide inflation rate of 15.5 per cent over the sameÂ period.â€

Description: Jan 21, 2025  Â·  It's time for the fire of Indigenous economic justice to transform how we build and share wealth. Together, we are building an economy rooted in our traditions.
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #economicreconciliation #indigenousleadershipâ€¦ | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 2mo Report this post "Itâ€™s time for the fire of Indigenous economic justice to transform how we build and share wealth. Together, we are building an economy rooted in our traditions, knowledge, and sovereignty."

As Indigenous peoples, we are not just participants in the economy; we are architects of a system that reflects our interconnectedness, sustainability, and collective prosperity. Economic justice means recognizing our inherent rights, fostering economic reconciliation, and creating pathways for economic sovereignty that benefit all.

We are witnessing a transformative era where Indigenous businesses, entrepreneurs, and nations are reclaiming their rightful place at the economic table. The future is being shaped by Indigenous leadership, collaborative partnerships, and a vision that respects the land, our values, and our people.

Letâ€™s continue to fuel this momentum. Who wants to play Indigenomics?

This is where Indigenous-led solutions, business excellence, and investment meet to activate the full potential of the $100 billion Indigenous economy.

Learn more in President and CEO Jamey Butcherâ€™s new article for Forbes below â¬‡ï¸ Jamey Butcher President and CEO at Chemonics International 2mo Business and #SustainableDevelopment leaders have a unique opportunityâ€”and responsibilityâ€”to make a transformative impact on the future of global poverty and economic growth. One of the most effective ways to create lasting impact is by advancing #financial inclusion globally, ensuring that everyone, regardless of where they live, has access to essential financial services.
Â 
At Chemonics International , weâ€™ve seen firsthand how impactful financial inclusion can be. For example, in the #Philippines , where we have a long history of advancing financial inclusion, we launched Higala in partnership with Talino Venture Studios to help reach millions of unbanked people in the country. Higala will ultimately make digital transactions more accessible and affordable for rural banks and their customers.

One of the most effective ways to create lasting impact is by advancing #financial inclusion globally, ensuring that everyone, regardless of where they live, has access to essential financial services.

Senior Vice President at Chemonics International 2mo Edited Report this post ğŸ’¡ Did you know that 1.4 billion people worldwide still lack access to basic financial services? Achieving #FinancialInclusion is a key enabler for the Sustainable Development Goals ( #SDGs ), not only helping people meet basic needs but also enabling global economic growth and resilience.  

In a new article for Forbes , Chemonics International President and CEO Jamey Butcher shares insights about the importance of financial inclusion, highlights Chemonicsâ€™ 50 years of experience in advancing it through our mission-driven work, and some of the strategies leaders can leverage to support it.  

 â€œTo solve problems globally, we need to invest in local communities and innovators. Infrastructure for transformative change already existsâ€¦ itâ€™s just a matter of private sector partners, governments, and beyond working together to fill the gaps.â€ 

Learn more at the link below! â¬‡ï¸ Council Post: Why Financial Inclusion Is Criticalâ€”And How Businesses Can Support It social-www.forbes.com 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Francis Bosah ğŸ”¬Soil Health | Regenerative Agriculture Missionary + Thought-Leader + Educator + Communicator + Coach + Mentor + Board Advisor 2mo Edited Report this post ğŸ¦ğŸŒ´ Prioritizing Afro-Regenerative Roots 

Any African ag interventional strategy, regardless of its origin, must prioritize an Afro-regenerative systemic mindset shift as its foundational framework. This is not optional, but indispensable.

Decades of well-intentioned yet flawed interventions,often rooted in colonial ag's legacy of exploitation & dispossession,have yielded limited impact, perpetuating systemic inequalities & ecological degradation.

It's time to acknowledge that:

1ï¸âƒ£ Business-as-usual approaches, modeled after colonial-era export-oriented ag, have come up short, failing to address the complex, interconnected challenges facing African ag.

2ï¸âƒ£ External solutions imposed without African ownership & agency, echoing the paternalistic attitudes of colonial powers, have often exacerbated problems,undermining local knowledge & resilienceğŸ’”

3ï¸âƒ£ Incremental reforms & technical fixes, reminiscent of the "modernization" efforts of colonial ag, are insufficient; transformative, systemic change is requiredğŸ”¥

Even when regen models are introduced, they often fall short of being truly systemic, neglecting to:

ğŸŒ±Address the historical power imbalances & injustices perpetuated by colonialism & neoliberalism.

ğŸŒ¿ Incorporate African indigenous knowledge,cultural heritage & ancestral wisdom.

ğŸŒ»Prioritize African-led solutions, self-determination & community-driven development.

By realigning interventions around an Afro-regenerative systemic mindset shift, we can:

1ï¸âƒ£ Center African voices, perspectives & leadership in ag development, reclaiming the narrative from colonial-era stereotypes

2ï¸âƒ£ Foster self-determination, community-driven solutions & collective prosperity, redressing the historical injustices of colonial ag

3ï¸âƒ£ Cultivate Afro-ecological resilience, ensuring sustainable, regen & climate-resilient ag practices,a stark departure from the exploitative practices of colonial ag.

This shift:

1ï¸âƒ£ Recognizes & respects African indigenous knowledge, cultural heritage, & ancestral wisdom,long suppressed by colonial powers

2ï¸âƒ£ Addresses the historical injustices & power imbalances perpetuated by colonialism & neoliberalism, acknowledging the ongoing impacts of colonial ag

3ï¸âƒ£ Prioritizes African-led solutions, self-determination & community-driven development, a radical departure from the top-down approaches of colonial ag

By integrating an Afro-regenerative systemic mindset shift, interventions can:

1ï¸âƒ£ Avoid perpetuating neocolonialism & extractive practices, instead promoting African-led, Afro-centric solutions

2ï¸âƒ£ Foster genuine partnerships & collaborations that center African voices & perspectives,rather than imposing external "expertise"

3ï¸âƒ£ Cultivate Afro-ecological resilience, ensuring sustainable & regen ag practices, a testament to the ingenuity & resilience of #Africanfarmers .

It's time to co-create a new pathway, one that honours African agency, wisdom & resilience.

#indigenomics #economicreconciliation #leadership #sustainabilityâ€¦ | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 6mo Report this post As Indigenous businesses continue to rise, the opportunity for meaningful partnerships, sustainable growth, and economic reconciliation has never been greater. Indigenomics on BAY STREET provides corporate leadership opportunities to forge meaningful partnerships, gain strategic insights, and actively contribute to the growth of the Indigenous economy.

-Drive Inclusive Growth: Collaborating with Indigenous businesses enhances diversity, strengthens supply chains, and creates shared prosperity.

-Champion Economic Reconciliation: Supporting the Indigenous economy is not just a responsibilityâ€”it's a strategic advantage in building a more equitable and resilient future.

-Invest in Sustainability: Indigenous-led projects are at the forefront of sustainable practices, offering innovative solutions that benefit both the environment and the economy.

Bring your leadership to Indigenomics on BAY STREET to connect with Indigenous leaders, explore investment opportunities, and be part of shaping the future of Canada's economy.

Register before September 18 to secure your spot and take the first step toward contributing to the transformative growth of the Indigenous economy. https://lnkd.in/geMXdZPA #Indigenomics #EconomicReconciliation #Leadership #Sustainability #IndigenousEconomy #IndigenomicsOnBayStreet â€¦more 14 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Tebby V. Olatetse Accounting MajorI United World Colleges Scholar| Sales Associate at Garage Clothing |
Passionate about Finance, Sales, and Global Education 5mo Edited Report this post Yesterday, I had the privilege of attending the Economic Reconciliation in the Workplace workshop, part of the Canadian Chamberâ€™s 2024 Inclusive Growth Dialogue Series ğŸŒ, in collaboration with the Greater Nanaimo Chamber of Commerce and Vancouver Island Economic Alliance . Hearing from Erralyn Joseph , Desiree Baker, Kear Portris, and Trevor Cootes, made me realize how essential it is to champion long-term growth through meaningful collaborations. It was an insightful and inspiring event that deepened my understanding of the critical role economic reconciliation plays in advancing inclusive growth.

Here are my three key takeaways:

Economic reconciliation is about actionable changeâ€”Itâ€™s more than just inclusion. Itâ€™s about creating sustainable, equitable opportunities for Indigenous communities to thrive through meaningful partnerships and support. ğŸ¤

Businesses have a pivotal roleâ€”From inclusive hiring practices to supporting Indigenous-led initiatives, organizations have the power to drive lasting change by embedding reconciliation into their culture and operations. ğŸ¢

Education and mentorship are powerful toolsâ€”Investing in Indigenous entrepreneurship, providing mentorship, and sharing resources are essential steps toward building a more inclusive and resilient economy. ğŸ“š

Iâ€™m excited to take these lessons forward and contribute to tangible progress in my own work. How is your organization advancing economic reconciliation? Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts and ideas. #EconomicReconciliation #InclusiveGrowth #IndigenousLeadership #WorkplaceEquity #ChamberEvents #Nanaimo #ReconciliationInAction #GrowthMindset 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Bay of Plenty Business News 2,076 followers 7mo Report this post Priority One and Te Waka call on the government to join forces with local leaders to develop a united strategy for strengthening the Golden Triangle. Coordinated investment in Waikato and Western Bay of Plenty is key to driving export economies and New Zealand's future wellbeing. Priority One Western Bay of Plenty | Te Waka: Waikato's Regional Economic Development Agency Call for government to unlock the Western Bayâ€™s potential - Bay of Plenty Business News https://bopbusinessnews.co.nz 22 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Forward Summit 9,288 followers 2mo Report this post What is Indigenous Economic Reconciliation?

Itâ€™s more than a conceptâ€”itâ€™s a call to action. Itâ€™s about ensuring Indigenous communities have the opportunity to fully participate in and benefit from the economy by breaking down systemic barriers and building meaningful partnerships.

Four key areas for economic reconciliation are:
1ï¸âƒ£  Partnerships & Collaborations
2ï¸âƒ£  Capacity Building
3ï¸âƒ£  Inclusive Policies
4ï¸âƒ£  Investment in Communities

Forward Summit incorporates these key focuses when bringing together Indigenous and non-Indigenous leaders to drive progress for economic reconciliation.

Need a reason for why it matters? Here are a few: 
ğŸŸ¢  Unlocks Canadaâ€™s economic potential
ğŸŸ¢  Advances equity and justice

-- What innovative approaches or collaborations have you seen that support Indigenous economic reconciliation? Share by commenting below! ğŸ‘‡ -- #ForwardSummit #ForwardSummit2025 #EconomicReconciliation #SharedProsperity #CommunityInvestment #EmpowerChange 51 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Michelle Tierney Non-Executive Director | ASX | NZX | Govt | NFP 10mo Report this post Researchers at the University of Melbourneâ€™s Dilin Duwa Centre for Indigenous Business Leadership
show in the 2021-22 financial year, Indigenous businesses generated $16.1 billion in revenue, around the same as the Australian timber industry, and provided jobs for 116,795 employees. 

â€œThis is no small contribution, especially when considering that much of the employment is in regional and remote Australia.â€

â€œStarting from little if any intergenerational wealth, starting from low-to-no homeownership, starting from a challenging pipeline into higher education and access to resourceful social networks, the progress of many is astounding.â€

â€œEconomically engaging and building up Indigenous businesses is workingâ€¦ We all win with the advancement of Indigenous economic self-determination.â€ #self -determination #IndigenousBusiness #economicempowerment @MichelleEvans @CainPolidano The great success story of Indigenous enterprise is missing afr.com 3 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in SODECO SARL DRC Society for the development of Congo 10mo Edited Report this post Calling All Experts: Help Shape a Groundbreaking Book on Transformative Leadership for African Development

 Esteemed Colleagues,
 I am embarking on an ambitious and timely book project that aims to redefine the landscape of sustainable development in Africa. Titled "Transformative Leadership for Reimagining African Futures: Towards Sustainable and Equitable Development," this pioneering work will present a bold, interdisciplinary framework for catalyzing transformative change across the African continent. As a scholar and practitioner in the field of African development, I am seeking to tap into the wealth of knowledge, diverse perspectives, and innovative ideas within our global community. I invite you - the experts, scholars, policymakers, and development practitioners - to contribute your insights and expertise to this landmark publication. Some of the key themes and questions we will explore include:
 1. Rethinking Development Paradigms: What are the shortcomings of existing development frameworks in Africa, and how can we design more holistic, equitable, and environmentally-sustainable approaches? 
 2. Harnessing the Power of Transformative Leadership: What are the essential characteristics, competencies, and enabling conditions for African leaders to cultivate a shared vision, empower marginalized communities, and drive systemic change? 
 3. Scaling Up Community-Driven Initiatives: How can we learn from and scale up innovative, community-led projects that harness renewable energy, promote agroecological farming, empower women and youth, and revitalize traditional knowledge systems? 
 4. Forging Multi-Stakeholder Collaboration: How can policymakers, civil society leaders, and community organizers work in tandem to align development efforts with the Sustainable Development Goals?
 5. Advancing Theoretical and Practical Frameworks: How can we synthesize cutting-edge theories from development studies, political economy, environmental science, and leadership studies to develop a transformative new paradigm for African development? If you are passionate about redefining the future of Africa and contributing to this landmark publication, I encourage you to reach out to me directly. I am particularly interested in hearing from those with expertise in any of the aforementioned areas, as well as those who can offer insights from the unique socio-cultural, political, and environmental contexts of different African regions. Together, let us embark on this transformative journey and co-create a bold, visionary framework that will shape the development discourse and inspire tangible change across the African continent. I look forward to your engagement and collaboration. 
 Best regards, 
Pitshou Moleka, PhD 
Author, "Transformative Leadership for Reimagining African Futures" #Africa #transformation #leadership #change #development #paradigmshift 16 40 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Coalition for a Better Future 2,160 followers 7mo Report this post Economic reconciliation is crucial for fostering #inclusive #economic #growth , and ensuring that Indigenous Peoples hold leadership positions is a key part of that. 

According to our #Scorecard report ( https://bit.ly/3vEuTCX ), representation of First Nations, Inuit, and MÃ©tis in management positions â¬‡ decreased to 2.4% in 2023 from 2.7% the previous year. Tabatha Bull , President and CEO of the Canadian Council for Indigenous Business emphasizes the importance of understanding why these numbers declined and suggests three ways for corporate Canada to transform their approach to #recruiting and #retaining Indigenous leadership:

ğŸ’¡ 1) Change the decision-making process at the board level. Consider embracing consensus decision-making and recognize that Indigenous Peoples may take time to assess the long-term impact of decisions on future generations.

ğŸ’¡ 2) Focus on recruiting for potential, not just experience. Relying solely on a candidate's years of experience will restrict the pool of Indigenous talent.

ğŸ’¡ 3) Prioritize intentional training and development. Ensure Indigenous hires receive the necessary training to prepare them for leadership roles.

ğŸ“º View Tabatha's full comments starting at 2:23:00 https://bit.ly/3Wv8AZI âœ Join the conversation. What does economic growth mean to you? #GrowthforAllCdns #BetterFutureforCanada First Nations Finance Authority , First Nations Major Projects Coalition Jesse McCormick , BlackNorth Initiative , Dahabo Ahmed-Omer, Alberta Indigenous Opportunities Corporation , Canada's 2SLGBTQI+ Chamber of Commerce (CGLCC) , FCC / FAC , Justine Hendricks , ACCES Employment , Heather Scoffield Patty Hajdu , Jamie Schmale Blake Desjarlais , â€¦more 6 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in The Ceylon Chamber of Commerce 18,048 followers 3mo Edited Report this post Dive into the Vision 2030 Economic Plan with Shiran Fernando , Chief Economic Policy Advisor at The Ceylon Chamber of Commerce. Learn about the 10 key priority areas that aim to transform Sri Lankaâ€™s economy and drive sustainable growth for the next decade. #Vision2030LKA #ceylonchamber â€¦more 72 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Economic Research Southern Africa (ERSA) 6,104 followers 4mo Report this post As our conference on The Role of Cities as Potential Drivers of Economic Growth and Prosperity continues, we share insights from our final panel discussion between our distinguished panellists Glen Robbins , Trudi Makhaya and Harris Selod , and chaired by Saul Levin . Here, our panelists explored the role of industrial policy in enabling cities to become drivers of growth. 

Considering the array of plans and frameworks on industrial policy in South Africa over the past 3 decades, there has been little success and the spatial dynamics of inequality must be addressed. How can industrial policy be used to bring people to jobs, connect people to jobs, or bring jobs to people? What are complementary policies that are necessary to support industrial policy, encourage economic growth and the redistribution of wealth? And how different are the roles of local and national government, in driving investment?

With local development being driven significantly by entrepreneurs, national policy needs to support the local level. Harris Selod emphasised the importance of the 3 Ps (place, productivity and prosperity) and 3 Es (explain the problem; estimate the effects; and ensure all actions are aligned) in promoting development. 7 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in African Center for Economic Transformation (ACET) 20,733 followers 3mo Report this post In her recentâ€¯interview with Alliance magazine , Mavis Owusu-Gyamfi , President and CEO of #ACET , shares her vision for Africa's growth and its path to economic transformation: 

ğŸ”µ Intentional policymakingâ€¯to develop value chainsÂ

Article:Â Optimization of a gas network fuel consumption with genetic algorithm Matthew Takerhi | Achievement researchgate.net 9 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Samantha Power Regenerative Economist, Futurist, Bioregionalist, Co-Founder & Director of the BioFi Project 2mo Edited Report this post At the start of 2025, amidst a great sense of loss, turmoil, and angst in North America and around the world, we at The BioFi Project are also feeling a profound sense of hope about the potential for the resurgent bioregional and growing regenerative economics movements this year. 

Amidst the increased dysfunction and collapse of old systems, as well as the loss of ways of life, ecosystems, structures, and perceived stability, there is space for new institutions and ways of seeing and being to emerge.

In this spirit, I am excited to share the latest 'Reality Roundtable' episode of the Great Simplification hosted by my new amazing friend Nate Hagens . It was a privilege to join the thoughtful and inspiring Daniel Christian Wahl and Isabel Carlisle to discuss why 'the future is local' and why the time for bioregioning is now. They each bring decades of wisdom from walking the walk..

I still have SO much to learn about bioregionalism, the literature that was published by the OGs in the 80s and 90s (shout out to David Haenke for sending me stuff on the reg!), what it looks like in practice, and how we grow it without allowing it to be consumed by what Nate likes to call 'the Superorganism.' And am feeling very grateful to be learning with and from incredible colleagues like Nate, Daniel, and Isabel, and you - the amazing regenerative/bioregional community. This conversation reflects some of what I've learned - but also so much of what I have left to learn and look forward to learning together!

I would love to hear what questions this conversation brings up for you and what questions on bioregionalism you might like to explore together. Thank you for your enthusiasm in collectively growing bioregional and regenerative economics movements! https://lnkd.in/gukKN-Wb #bioregioning #bioregionalism #regenerativeeconomies #biofi #regeneration 176 14 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in 185 followers View Profile Connect Explore topics Sales Marketing IT Services Business Administration HR Management Engineering Soft Skills See All LinkedIn Â© 2025 About Accessibility User Agreement Privacy Policy Cookie Policy Copyright Policy Brand Policy Guest Controls Community Guidelines Ø§Ù„Ø¹Ø±Ø¨ÙŠØ© (Arabic) à¦¬à¦¾à¦‚à¦²à¦¾ (Bangla) ÄŒeÅ¡tina (Czech) Dansk (Danish) Deutsch (German) Î•Î»Î»Î·Î½Î¹ÎºÎ¬ (Greek) English (English) EspaÃ±ol (Spanish) ÙØ§Ø±Ø³ÛŒ (Persian) Suomi (Finnish) FranÃ§ais (French) à¤¹à¤¿à¤‚à¤¦à¥€ (Hindi) Magyar (Hungarian) Bahasa Indonesia (Indonesian) Italiano (Italian) ×¢×‘×¨×™×ª (Hebrew) æ—¥æœ¬èª (Japanese) í•œêµ­ì–´ (Korean) à¤®à¤°à¤¾à¤ à¥€ (Marathi) Bahasa Malaysia (Malay) Nederlands (Dutch) Norsk (Norwegian) à¨ªà©°à¨œà¨¾à¨¬à©€ (Punjabi) Polski (Polish) PortuguÃªs (Portuguese) RomÃ¢nÄƒ (Romanian) Ğ ÑƒÑÑĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (Russian) Svenska (Swedish) à°¤à±†à°²à±à°—à± (Telugu) à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²à¹„à¸—à¸¢ (Thai) Tagalog (Tagalog) TÃ¼rkÃ§e (Turkish) Ğ£ĞºÑ€Ğ°Ñ—Ğ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ° (Ukrainian) Tiáº¿ng Viá»‡t (Vietnamese) ç®€ä½“ä¸­æ–‡ (Chinese (Simplified)) æ­£é«”ä¸­æ–‡ (Chinese (Traditional)) Language Sign in to view more content Create your free account or sign in to continue your search Sign in Welcome back Email or phone Password Show Forgot password? Title: Indigenous Wealth Dynamics | Indigenomics posted on the topic
Description: May 24, 2024  Â·  Indigenomics, to me, represents a commitment to empowering Indigenous communities through financing, sustainable technology, and innovation.
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #indigenouseconomy #economicreconciliation | Indigenomics Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenomicsâ€™ Post Indigenomics 4,887 followers 10mo Edited Report this post Only 10 Days away! Are you registered for Indigenomics Design- Indigenous Wealth Dynamics?

Breakout speakers Thomas Benjoe , OneHoop and Joshua A. , Raven Indigenous Capital Partners , will discuss "Building Indigenous-Led Capital," sharing insights on economic sovereignty and Indigenous leadership. This is what Indigenomics means to them;

"Indigenomics, to me, represents a commitment to empowering Indigenous communities through financing, sustainable technology, and innovation. It involves weaving traditional Indigenous values into investment practices, emphasizing collaboration and community-focused development in the tech sector." Josh Alook

'For too long our peoples livelihood have been associated with poverty but poverty was not created by poor people. It is created by the economic and social systems that we have designed for ourselves, the institutions and concepts that make up these systems are the result of decision made by human beings. As we create them, so we can change them. Through Indigenomics we will change the institutions and concepts to see our people prosper in business and economics." Thomas Benjoe

Don't miss this chance to engage with leaders in Indigenous economic design. This important session invited dialogue on how Indigenous trusts and investment strategies have evolved significantly over the last 50 years. Through increasing settlement values and innovative strategies, trusts and investments have become powerful tools for driving economic development and supporting social programming in Indigenous communities.

Pursuing a PhD in India is not just a test of academic endurance but also a financial struggle for many scholars. The prolonged duration of PhD programs, coupled with irregular or insufficient fellowships, forces many to take up odd jobs just to make ends meet. This not only hampers their research focus but also highlights the urgent need for better financial support systems. It's time to address these challenges and ensure that our scholars can dedicate themselves fully to their research without the burden of financial insecurity. #PhDScholar #ResearchMatters #FinancialSupport #HigherEducation #India Your opinion on such state of scholars? https://lnkd.in/gAupcpEs Nationalist on Instagram: "- Google and you will find my..... - Your shop, right?? - No, my research papers on Bio-technology. #india #biotechnology #sad #but #reality" instagram.com 14 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in IRANZ Independent Research Association of New Zealand 916 followers 9mo Report this post HERA: Which matters more? Excellence or impact? HERA CEO Dr Troy Coyle (Wahine/She/Her) writes about the differences between excellent research that has impact vs impactful research that is excellent, and the potentially harmful bias in the New Zealand Science System. It's a timely article and a discussion we have been having ourselves at IRANZ as we prepared our submission for the Science System Advisory Group in May.

"The Aotearoa New Zealand research, science and innovation (RSI) system is one that purportedly values and rewards research excellence and research impact equally.

"Despite this, the current system favours an approach that focuses on excellent research that has impact vs impactful research that is excellent."

Dr Coyle writes that an alternative approach is to ensure that all proposals are assessed for both impact and excellence or that impact is the first hurdle. "Surely, all research must be high impact? Is there any point doing the most excellent research in the world if it has no impact?" #ResearchExcellence #ImpactfulResearch #ScienceDebate #ResearchImpact #NZScience #SciencePolicy #RSI #InnovationNZ #ScienceSystem #HighImpactResearch #ScienceDiscussion #ResearchMatters #ExcellenceVsImpact #HERA #iranzresearch https://lnkd.in/gaUT___z Which matters more? As part of the Team Finland Knowledge funded project â€œFostering green transition through mobility and effective communication between Finnish and Chilean HEIs â€œ starting in 2022, we have been building Finnish-Chilean partnership to foster academic exchange, research collaboration, and sustainable innovation in the field of bioeconomy.

Project highlights:
â€¢ Chilean academics visited Finland to explore education programs, industry practices, and research opportunities.
â€¢ Finnish experts travelled to Chile, engaging in bioeconomy seminars, student exchange agreements, and circular bioeconomy development discussions.
â€¢ Workshops, webinars, and vide variety of visits connected professionals, educators, and students to strengthening bioeconomy education.

GreenMOBECO project ended at the end of 2024, but collaboration is continuing in several ways, such as student and staff exchange and joint project applications.

Researchers from low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) have a deep understanding of local contexts and strong relationships with policymakers, yet they contribute to only two percent of global research output. To address this, initiatives like CEGA's Global Networks program and J-PAL's Scholars Program are enhancing inclusion in and building capacity of impact evaluation by providing training, mentorship, and funding to LMIC scholars.

Launched in 2021, the Digital Agricultural Innovations and Services Initiative (DAISI), managed jointly by CEGA and J-PAL, supports research aimed at enhancing digital agricultural solutions for small-scale producers in South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. The DAISI Regional Scholars Program offers PhD holders from these regions opportunities for funding and mentorship in impact evaluation methodologies.

On October 17th, the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty brings attention to the ongoing global struggle against poverty and calls for collective action. This yearâ€™s theme, â€œEnding Social and Institutional Maltreatment,â€ urges us to address not only economic hardship but also the social and institutional barriers that perpetuate poverty.

Since its recognition by the United Nations in 1992, this day has amplified the voices of those affected by poverty to ensure fair access to education, employment, and essential services, which are vital for building more inclusive societies.

However, fight against poverty is not limited to lack of basic needs anymore. It is about the underlying absence of opportunities, freedom of choice and participation in decision making. Achieving SDG 1 refers to the idea of equal and equitable access to resources that envisions a future where all communities have a fair chance to grow and succeed.

By working together, we can create a society where every individual has the opportunity to thrive. As development practitioners, it is essential to take shared responsibility, to bring affirmative changes for a better future. The fight against poverty is far from over. The 2024 UN SDG Report highlights the critical need for action to close the gaps in social protection and climate resilience. 

With millions still facing extreme poverty, especially in vulnerable regions, the path forward demands focused efforts to support those most affected.

 IT Support Expert | Data Enthusiast| Certified Educator | SDGs Promoter | Co-founder Codeville Girls | God's Chosen 5mo Report this post The #International #Day for the #Eradication of #Poverty is observed annually on October 17.

 Established by the United Nations in 1992, it commemorates a 1987 gathering in #Paris where over 100,000 people honored victims of poverty. The day aims to promote dialogue between those living in poverty and society, emphasizing that poverty is a violation of #humanrights . 

Activities include raising awareness, supporting anti-poverty organizations, and advocating for #policy changes to combat #poverty , #violence and #hunger globally


In December 1995, the United Nations General #Assembly proclaimed the First United Nations Decade for the Eradication of Poverty (1997â€“2006), following the #Copenhagen Social Summit. UNESCO 's involvement in the fight against poverty on October 17 emphasizes the importance of #education , #science , and #cultural #initiatives as tools for #empowerment . 

By promoting #capacity building, UNESCO supports individuals in overcoming poverty through #skills #development and #creative #economies , which foster employment and dignity. The organization aligns its efforts with the #2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, particularly Goal 1, which aims to end #poverty in all forms.

Almost 700 million people globally still live in extreme poverty â€“ on less than $2.15 a day. What will it take to get back on track to #EndPoverty ? (2008) identified a significant negative correlation between nitrogen fertilizer use and bird species richness. Birds in agricultural landscapes are more likely to decline due to cascading ecological impacts of high fertilizer use, such as reduced plant and insect diversity and eutrophication of aquatic habitats. However, increasing the area of semi-natural habitats (e.g., hedgerows and uncultivated margins) in agricultural landscapes can mitigate these negative effects by providing alternative resources and habitats for birds.

First created by the Second Committee of the UN General Assembly inÂ 1993, IDB is a celebration of biological diversityâ€”a day to educate and bring awareness to biodiversity issues worldwide.

BiodiversityÂ encompasses all the different living things found in an area, including animals, insects, fungi, plant life, and microorganisms. This complex mix of life is a delicate balance, as every organism relies on others to survive. 

Great Ecology engages with practices of strengthening biodiversity through our projects. We lead the way in creative solutions for ecological problems, working with clients to preserve biological diversity in the face of complex environmental issues.

Key take away thoughts to consider were:
- Diversity on boards in terms of both gender and skillset is important.
- Skills in governance as well as financial literacy are essential to be present on boards. In addition, skills in life sciences provide an important balance.
- The discussion around prior board experience vs skillset, provided some food for thought on whether prior board experience is always needed, if the skillset is a good fit.
- â€œBoard observerâ€ opportunities could help aspiring board members gain the boardroom experience needed to be considered for future positions

Women's biotech leaders need the fair support of investors to bring innovation to unmet societal medical needs, including the need for precision medicine for heart failure.  
In recent years, US companies founded or co-founded by women have received a smaller share of total deals compared to previous years. However, those companies continue to grow their share of capital raised. https://lnkd.in/giZGy6Yg According to a report by the McKinsey Institute and the World Economic Forum,Â investing in women's health can boost the global economy by $1 trillion annually by 2040â€”a 1.7 percent increase in the average per capita GDP generated by women.

My guest tomorrow on She Leads Biotech is President & CEO of Invivo Biosciences , Ayla Annac . whose journeyÂ takes us from her roots in Turkey to her pioneering work in the biotech space, where she's making strides in heart disease treatment.

Ayla is a passionate advocate for increasing female representation at all levels in biotech. 

She believes that diversity in leadership, especially from women, brings essential perspectives and drives collaboration over competition. 

Her commitment to mentorship and supporting other women in science is a testament to her belief in lifting others as she climbs. 9 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Kintiga 6,845 followers 3mo Report this post Last night, we had the privilege of attending BioIndustry Association (BIA) 's Women in Biotech event in London, with Marianne Lambertson and Karina Tatagiba GonÃ§alves representing the MAP Group. The event highlighted the challenges faced by female founders and the ongoing barriers for women in leadership roles within the life sciences sector.
Â 
We were honoured to participate and contribute to the conversation about driving positive change in the industry. One CEO and founder shared a striking experience: of the 100+ venture capital firms she approached, over 60% suggested appointing a male CEO to improve her chances of success.
Â 
Another key takeaway was that only about one-third of grant funding in the UK is allocated to female-founded organisations. The panel discussion explored actionable steps we can take now and in the future to support women-led initiatives.
Â

This volume explores the strategies, innovations, and leadership required to forge a new global development agenda beyond 2030. It not only underlines the challenges that confront us but illuminates the pathways that can lead to a more resilient, inclusive, and sustainable world. 

This publication comprises twenty-seven essays authored by a range of authors from the development, philanthropy, and think tank sectors, as well as policymakers and other thought leaders, carrying voices from both the Global North and the Global South.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenomicsâ€™ Post Indigenomics 4,887 followers 10mo Report this post The expression of Indigenous value, of value creation and the distribution of wealth is expressed through ceremony and relationships within Indigenous reality. 

For thousands of years, wealth has been expressed through giving, the transaction, the distribution through ceremony and based upon the quality of recognition of relationship and connection to each other, to our environment, and to resources with respect for life at the heart of both the economy and ceremony. 

This is Indigenomics.

At TechNvst, weâ€™re dedicated to driving growth and scaling solution integrators through strategic corporate collaboration and market access facilitation. We believe in the power of small businesses as the backbone of Africaâ€™s economy, and weâ€™re committed to supporting their journey towards scaling and success.

Dive into the latest insights with the State of Tech in Africa 2023 Report by Africa Arena. This comprehensive report offers a deep dive into the evolving tech landscape and the critical role of innovation in shaping Africaâ€™s future.

ğŸ”— https://www.africarena.com Letâ€™s continue to drive innovation and unlock new opportunities for Africaâ€™s tech ecosystem! #TechNvst #Innovation #AfricaTech #SmallBusiness #MarketAccess #CorporateCollaboration #TechReport #AfricaArena AFRICARISE | AfricArena africarena.com 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Blessing Douglas Convener for Boma Prize for Africa | Social Impact Ecosystem Builder | Championing Entrepreneurship, Innovation & Funding Access in Africa | Nonprofit & Startup Growth Strategist | Hult Prize 9mo Report this post Every journey begins with a vision, but sustaining that vision through challenges requires unwavering strength and resilience. When I founded the Boma Prize for Africa, my mission was clear: to empower and uplift the most innovative minds across the continent that will eventually put Africans on the global map. But the path has not been without its storms.

In this picture, I hold a cup that symbolizes more than just a beverage; it represents the fuel that drives my passion and determination every single day. From day one, my faith has been my cornerstone. As Romans 8:31 reminds us, â€œIf God is for us, who can be against us?â€ This belief has fortified me through every obstacle, ensuring that I never lose sight of my purpose.

Unstoppable people carry a spirit that propels them beyond their limits. As Philippians 4:13 says, â€œI can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.â€ This verse is a testament to the strength that fuels my journey. Despite the challenges, despite the setbacks, I continue to push forward. The Boma Prize for Africa is now a little over a month away, and every day brings new hurdles. Yet, every day also brings new victories.

Starting this initiative was not just about creating an event; it was about building a platform for change, for innovation, and for growth. The support from our sponsors and the community has been incredible, reinforcing my belief that together, we can achieve greatness.

As we approach the event, I am reminded of the power of perseverance. The storms have come, but they have only made me stronger. Each challenge has been a lesson, each obstacle an opportunity to grow. And here we are, standing strong, ready to showcase the brilliance that Africa has to offer Abuja this coming July.

To everyone facing their own battles, remember that your strength lies within. Keep pushing, keep striving, and know that you are capable of extraordinary things. The Boma Prize for Africa is happening, and it can only be God! #Leadership #Faith #Innovation #CommunityImpact #BomaPrizeForAfrica #Resilience #Perseverance #Empowerment #blessingdouglas 31 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Omolade Bisiriyu-Olagunju I help businesses grow with data-driven strategies | Alx Certified Data Scientist | Business Strategist | Tech Transition Guide | Corporate Trainer 8mo Edited Report this post Do you know that Nigeria is about to host the biggest event ever?



Yes, and you should not be left out of it. The Africa Social Impact Summit (ASIS) is here!

The Africa Social Impact Summit is the pioneer gathering of leaders from the private and public sectors, civil society organizations, and development community to find innovative sustainable solutions to Africa's key developmental challenges.


Join thousands of other African changemakers as we transform the African Continent. 

Below are the major highlights of the event 

âœ” 2000+ global attendees
âœ” 50+ industry-leading speakers 
âœ” 54 countries will be represented
âœ” 6 powerful sessions
âœ” 6 thematic areas
âœ” 1 purpose

Why do you need to attend?

âœ” High-level networking
âœ” Continental Impact
âœ” Innovative solutions


Remember, you owe your present self a shot at greatness so your future self can look back and be proud.


I will be sharing more details on how to register and the event date in the comments

Happy Sunday everyone!

There is a gift for the first person with the right answer #Sunday #linkedinforcreators #ASIS #innovation 42 42 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in UR4Africa 187 followers 10mo Report this post Dear Reader,
We're thrilled to share some exciting news with you. First,  Public Art Africa is no longer a separate organization from ur4Africa though it has always been a subsidiary of UR4Africa , we are basically condensing platforms for effective management and to improve our productivity, UR4Africa oversees PAA as one of the projects under her.

WHAT IS UR4AFRICA?
UR4Africa Project, Inc., founded in 2013, is a pan-African space that creates a pathway for the global African diaspora to collaborate with African people to uplift Africa. 

As a registered 501c(3) organization, it is our intention to curate intersectional opportunities for people interested in community building, skill-sharing, investment, and exchanging positive stories about the continent of Africa. To achieve this, we initiated: public Art Africa project, The Exchange Program, The Think Tank and the Public Awareness Service.

Our vision for Public Art Africa is to create programs to engage and educate young minds, preparing them for the future by nurturing and harnessing their talents through active and quality mentorship.

The Exchange Program facilitates cross-cultural exchange and collaborations between individuals and organizations across Africa. Last year, we had a collaboration with OLA ( Otherwise Life For All) in Benin Republic, West Africa. we're also excited to welcome a volunteer from France, and many others.

Public Service Awareness
Our PSA initiatives focus on creating awareness through contents that reflect the beauty of Africa and that has the capacity to drive positive changes in Africa. 

The Think Tank
The Think Tank is a platform for critical thinking, and discourse of pressing issues facing Africa today. It is a team of different individuals from different fields to generate innovative solutions and ideas to address some of the continent's challenges, membership into this is completely free, you can jump in with just a mail.

Each of the programs are guided by shared purpose and the big picture is to connect Africans, build Africa and redefine the narrative through the spirit of Pan-Africanism. By "pan-Africanism" we refer to  the movement that aims to promote solidarity, unity, and cooperation among people of African descent, regardless of their geographic location.

We invite you to Join us on this journey of transforming Africa. you have questions or enquiries? Please visit UR4Africa.org , subscribe and follow our page on Instagram, LinkedIn and. ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡¼ After which I introduce Rwandaâ€™s philosophy of Agaciro as an idea worth reflecting on. #GlobalGateway #EUAfrica #Agaciro Friends of Europe 23,396 followers 1y Edited âThe Global Gateway Initiative can only be truly mutually beneficial if its projects are, at the very least, co-led by its partners.â

â¡ï¸ On its second anniversary last December, the European Unionâ€™s Global Gateway Initiative reached a milestone with the inauguration of BioNTechâ€™s mRNA vaccine manufacturing facility in the Rwandan capital, Kigali.

â¡ï¸ As the site targets development objectives and geopolitical priorities shared by both the EU and the African Union alike, it looks like a textbook example of what a â€˜mutually beneficial partnershipâ€™ between Europe and Africa should look like.

â“ Does this mean all such initiatives are equally balanced to the benefit of both partners? Not necessarily. 

â¡ï¸ Moving forward, the Global Gateway should provide its African partners with more institutional guarantees for ownership, enabling a more equal partnership where countries less resistant to pressure from donors enjoy this same sense of dignity.

â¤µï¸ Read this Critical Thinking article by Julien Heylen , former programme assistant for Global Europe and Digital & Data Governance at Friends of Europe, below. #CriticalThinking #EUGlobalGateway #EUAfrica Ownership and mutual benefits, a trade-off? EF-Tu \(elongation factor thermo unstable\) is a prokaryotic elongation factor responsible for catalyzing the binding of an aminoacyl-tRNA \(aa-tRNA\) to the ribosome. It is a G-protein, and facilitates the selection and binding of an aa-tRNA to the A-site of the ribosome. As a reflection of its crucial role in translation, EF-Tu is one of the most abundant and highly conserved proteins in prokaryotes.

Click here for the full article: https://bit.ly/4dgYdiB In 1971, the financial world changed forever with the advent of science-based investing. Research from academics like Gene Fama revealed that markets efficiently price in all available information, making traditional stock-picking ineffective. This breakthrough paved the way for index funds and the democratization of investing, allowing anyone to capture market returns without speculation. Women are key players in the food system, yet they often lack the recognition and resources they need. 

In the Mediterranean region, women contribute significantly to greening food systems. From producers and innovators to decision-makers, they are essential in driving sustainable practices. Despite structural barriers, their leadership ensures resilience and inclusivity. However, women's contributions are often undervalued, particularly due to unpaid agricultural work and involvement in informal or shadow agri-food labour market.Â Recognizing and supporting their role is vital for a greener future.

In Europe, women are transforming agriculture through innovative practices that prioritize sustainability and environmental stewardship. As key players in the green transition, theyâ€™re driving the adoption of agroecological methods, fostering biodiversity, and reducing agriculture's carbon footprint. Yet, they face challenges in accessing resources and decision-making spaces.

Empowering women is essential for creating a more resilient and sustainable food system. Discover more about womenâ€™s pivotal role in sustainable agriculture and join the movement for change!

Learn how initiatives like the NEXUS-NESS project and EU programs are supporting womenâ€™s leadership in greening agriculture: https://lnkd.in/d8EgmScw Discover how empowering women strengthens agriculture and food systems across the Mediterranean, fostering sustainability and social cohesion: https://lnkd.in/dTd_9mw6 Gender equality is key to building a more sustainable and inclusive WEFE Nexus. Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Trent Billette ğŸª¶â€™s Post Trent Billette ğŸª¶ Indigenous Motivational Speaker | Dene Tech Innovator ğŸª¶ | Social Entrepreneur | Community Builder | Proud Member of Buffalo River Dene Nation | Empowering Indigenous Entrepreneurs 2w Edited Report this post ğŸ“š My Journey as an Indigenous Entrepreneur: From Reading to Building a Knowledge Library ğŸ“š

When I first set out on this journey, I had a simple goal: read one book a month to sharpen my skills as an entrepreneur. But somewhere along the way, I realized this was bigger than just reading. I wasnâ€™t just consuming knowledgeâ€”I was collecting it, curating it, and applying it to build something greater: Indigpreneur.

As Indigenous people, our knowledge has always been passed down through stories, teachings, and lived experience. Today, books have become another way for me to learn from those who came before usâ€”leaders, thinkers, and changemakers who have built businesses, disrupted industries, and reshaped economies.

ğŸ“– Starting with â€œIndigenomics: Taking a Seat at the Economic Tableâ€ by Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D This book isnâ€™t just a readâ€”itâ€™s a blueprint. Hilton lays out how Indigenous people can reclaim economic power, create wealth in our communities, and move beyond surviving to thriving in business. Itâ€™s a powerful reminder that we donâ€™t need to fit into existing systemsâ€”we can build our own.

ğŸš€ How Indigpreneur Will Implement These Teachings:

âœ… Building Indigenous-Led Networks: Indigenomics highlights the need for strong Indigenous business ecosystems. Through Indigpreneur, Iâ€™m focused on creating a network where Indigenous entrepreneurs collaborate, share resources, and grow together.

âœ… Creating Wealth, Not Just Jobs: Hilton talks about the importance of ownership. Indigpreneur isnâ€™t just about helping Indigenous businesses startâ€”itâ€™s about helping them scale, sustain, and create long-term wealth in our communities.

âœ… Elevating Indigenous Innovation: Indigenous knowledge and ways of doing business are an advantage, not a limitation. I want Indigpreneur to champion modern Indigenous business modelsâ€”ones rooted in our values, but thriving in todayâ€™s economy.

ğŸ“¢ This isnâ€™t just about meâ€”itâ€™s about all of us. If youâ€™re an Indigenous entrepreneur, business leader, or changemaker, letâ€™s connect and share knowledge.

ğŸ† Join the Indigenous Entrepreneur Roundtable

At the end of this month, Iâ€™m hosting a roundtable discussion where weâ€™ll explore how we can take action on these ideas, share insights, and connect as Indigenous entrepreneurs.

ğŸ”— Register here: https://lnkd.in/g-EhkV57 ğŸ“– What books have shaped your mindset? How do you see Indigenous business evolving? Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenomicsâ€™ Post Indigenomics 4,887 followers 4mo Edited Report this post We are deeply grateful to TELUS for their ongoing commitment as our Platinum Multi-Year Events Partner, and for their participation in Indigenomics by DESIGN, SHE, BAY STREET, and the National Indigenomics AI Generative Study this year! Their contributions have been outstanding, and we appreciate how they continue to collaborate and play Indigenomics with us! 

TELUS engaged in various ways this yearâ€”as speakers, vendors, advisors, and hosts. At Indigenomics SHE, Kara Moss , Clinical Supervisor at TELUS Health, shared her insights on the Indigenous Women Leading in Corporate Reconciliation panel. At Indigenomics on BAY STREET, Jesslyn Dymond , Director of AI Governance & Data Ethics, contributed to the panel on AI and the Next Indigenous Economy, while also serving as an advisor on the National Indigenomics AI Generative Study. On Innovation Day, TELUS hosted an Indigenous Placekeeping Tour at TELUS Harbour, showcasing how culturally responsive experiences can be integrated into corporate spaces. Additionally, Amanda Lee, Emily Piccinin , Leila Ashurov , Chloe Santiago , Neil Conti, and Denis Lacasse engaged with conference attendees at DESIGN, SHE, and BAY STREET at the TELUS booth. 

We also want to extend our thanks to the TELUS team members we work with, including Kristen Sandhu , Stephanie Han , Yoelit Lipinsky, PhD , Christy Morgan and Marissa Nobauer â€”we appreciate you! 

We deeply value TELUS's commitment to playing #Indigenomics and walking with us in advancing economic reconciliation.

Thanks to tech and AI, this goal is within reach!
Â 
This yearâ€™s Summit of the Future by the International Telecommunication Union and UNDP is a powerful reminder that we need to put ourselves back on a better path. We are not on track to meet the goals we have set for our global community, and new challenges are already on the horizon.

This is especially true for health and care: our systems are creaking under ever-growing pressures, and the pace at which inequities are growing appears to outrun the speed of innovation. But there is hope.
Â 
I was delighted to take the stage and speak about the transformative potential that AI and advanced analytics bring to health and care. These tools can help us identify the true drivers of health and equip decision makers with the insights they need to design impactful interventions â€“ ultimately keeping us all healthy in the first place.

On September 24, the Novartis Foundation will reveal such AI-driven insights on potential determinants of heart health in New York City, doing our part in paving the way to a healthier and more equitable tomorrow. Stay tuned! #DigitalFutureForAll #SDGdigital #UNGA79 246 4 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in SFCS Architects 2,225 followers 4mo Report this post A massive highlight at the #ICAA2024 Conference was Mark Kronner's presentation on "Artificial Intelligence: Revolutionizing Well-being and Operations." Additional space needed to be open to accommodate everyone who was interested!

Kronner's insights centered around how AI is a transformative tool empowering staff and seniors in everything from streamlining daily tasks to enabling collaborative decision-making. The key? Thoughtful, personalized integration that respects individual autonomy while enhancing quality of life.

The packed session and expanded space sent a clear message: The senior living industry is embracing technological innovation like never before.

During the Canada-Italy Forum on AI & Well-Being, I had the opportunity to present "Multi-modal modeling of Eye Imaging to predict Dementia in the CALLIOPE Urban Health Initiative". This innovative approach leverages AI-driven algorithms and angio-OCT imaging to detect novel retinal biomarkers, offering a non-invasive, cost-effective way to classify neurocognitive diseases such as Alzheimer's.

ğŸ”¬ By combining retinal imaging with data from clinical, lifestyle, and socio-economic factors, we aim to:
- Improve early detection of dementia.
- Enhance prediction models using machine learning and multi-modal data fusion.
- Pave the way for integrative health solutions in urban contexts.

This work underscores the potential of technology and interdisciplinary collaboration in addressing the global dementia challenge, with over 50 million people affected todayâ€”a number expected to surpass 74 million by 2030.

Let's make a difference together. ğŸ’ª The Pause Technologies Inc. #AIMed #AIMedGlobal #femtech #thepauseai #womeninai #WomenInHealthcare #HealthEquity #AIInHealthcare #impact #disparity 33 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Ashley Thomas Director at Global Health Strategies 9mo Report this post This was great! Bilal A Mateen 's opening remarks about the threats of removing humans from the center of AI framed the conversations nicely, and closing remarks from Alain Labrique drove the point home by asking not "how" AI should be used, but rather "if" - a question that is best answered only when the problem is well-defined, the target/recipient population has decreased barriers to access (like compute power! H/t Agnes Kiragga ), and the foundational models used are very very _very_ well-understood. Curious to hear how funding organizations are creating AI-forward grant strategies, and how/if they are incorporating lessons learned by #digitalhealth / #tech4dev implementers over the past few decades. Digital Square at PATH 8,063 followers 9mo Edited ğŸŒâœ¨ Exciting developments in digital health! âœ¨ğŸŒ

On June 2nd, PATH and Digital Square at PATH convened at the 3rd Meeting of the G20 Brasil 2024 Health Working Group for a co-branded event, "AI for Science & Health: Ensuring Equitable Impact." Supported by the Wellcome Trust and co-hosted with the World Health Organization , GIDH, and the World Economic Forum , the event addressed how artificial intelligence (AI) can transform healthcare, especially in low- and middle-income countries.

Discussions covered:
ğŸ¤– The role of AI in improving clinical decision support and medical product development
ğŸŒ The importance of localizing digital innovations to benefit the Global South
âš  Overcoming challenges such as algorithm biases, data quality issues, and privacy concerns

Pictured below, Ana Estela Haddad , Secretary for Information and Digital Health for the Brazilian Ministry of Health, spoke to Brazilâ€™s perspective on how the G20 can help facilitate and harness the potential of AI in LMICs: â€œItâ€™s important that we work collaboratively together and with responsibility, especially when we think about ethical use of AIâ€¦ and that we keep on working on an equitable way to develop strength in our health systems.â€

Our collective goal is to channel AI's potential while ensuring ethical considerations and equitable access to healthcare innovations. This event was a significant step towards a future where AI-driven solutions support global health equity. ğŸŒğŸ©º #G20Health #AI4Health #GlobalHealthEquity #DigitalHealth #DigitalTransformation 10 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in LAMIA RAHAL Woman founder I Health tech I Strategy I Public policy I Government affairs I Regulatory affairs | market access | Business development I 2mo Report this post Weâ€™re thrilled to announce Health Nexus Africa membership to the HealthAI - The Global Agency for Responsible AI in Health Community of Practice â€” a global forum where diverse voices come together to turn ideas into action and advance #ResponsibleAI governance in health.

At the unique intersection of Health, AI, and Regulation, the CoP is designed to foster meaningful collaboration among policymakers, regulators, researchers, civil society, and private sector leaders. 

What makes the CoP special?

âœ…  It brings diverse perspectives to the table, including those from low- and middle-income countries, ensuring that local needs and interests shape global AI governance.

Discover Indigenous economies with Carol Anne Hilton | Indigenomics posted on the topic | LinkedIn Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenomicsâ€™ Post Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1y Report this post "Indigenomics" takes you on a captivating journey, unraveling the intricate web of Indigenous economies. Carol Anne Hilton masterfully intertwines traditional knowledge with modern economic principles, offering a unique perspective on how Indigenous communities can harness their strengths to drive sustainable economic development.

Overview
Indigenomics lays out the tenets of the emerging Indigenous economy, built around relationships, multigenerational stewardship of resources, and care for all. Highlights include:

â€¢	The ongoing power shift and rise of the modern Indigenous economy
â€¢	Voices of leading Indigenous business leaders
â€¢	The unfolding story in the law courts that is testing Canada's relationship with Indigenous peoples
â€¢	Exposure of the false media narrative of Indigenous dependency

As the Founder of Tipi Horse, I am incredibly proud of our work in helping foster meaningful Indigenous engagement and cultural awareness within Northwestern Ontarioâ€™s growing mining sector.

Thunder Bay is quickly becoming a key service and supply hub, supporting 9 active mines and over 18 exploration projects. Tipi Horse is honoured to be part of this expanding industry, where we are working to bridge the gap between mining operations and Indigenous communities.
