Remember Theranos? Elizabeth Holmes promised revolutionary blood-testing technology and dazzled everyone with confidence and ambition. But behind the scenes, the tech didnâ€™t work. When the truth came out, trust crumbled, and the fallout was massiveâ€”not just for the company but for everyone who believed in it.Â  

Now, look at Cotopaxi. Theyâ€™ve built their brand differently, with purpose and transparency at the core. From committing a portion of profits to fight global poverty to crafting sustainable products, Cotopaxi doesnâ€™t just make promisesâ€”they deliver. Their actions have created a loyal community that believes in their mission.Â  

The takeaway? 

Trying to build connections on false faces or exaggerated pretenses is like laying a foundation on quicksand. It might hold for a moment, but it wonâ€™t last. I was privileged to attend the Thrive Women's Summit organized by the Women Power House led by Faith Fetaru .

Hereâ€™s what stood out for me:
ğŸŒ¹ The importance of collaboration and how it impacts the growth of a business or organization, shared by Henriette Paula Mugisa, Belinda Esaete Regina, and Constansia Nakinda:
ğŸ“Œ Tapping into each other's already established market.
ğŸ“Œ Reaching more people and creating greater impact.
ğŸ“Œ Widening networks.
ğŸ“Œ Learning from each other.
ğŸ“Œ Helping each other achieve their vision.

ğŸŒ¹ Every woman is a queen in her kingdom and has 7 powers, as explained by Jacqueline Asiimwe :
ğŸ“Œ Power of Purpose: Why are you still alive? Why were you born?
ğŸ“Œ Power of People: Who are the people attached to your purpose? The people you are meant to serveâ€”how do you treat them?
ğŸ“Œ Power of Place: Where do you want to create impact? Is it in your professional space, family, or your community?
ğŸ“Œ Power of Privilege: What privileges do you have that can support your purpose? Is it your personality, education, background, experiences, or exposure?
ğŸ“Œ Power of Pleasure: What brings you satisfaction and joy? How often do you make time for itâ€”whether itâ€™s a hobby, self-care, or a passion?
ğŸ“Œ Power of Purse: What are your financial habits? Whatâ€™s your generosity quotient? How are you managing the resources you have?
ğŸ“Œ Power of Pain: How do you deal with your pain? Does it control you, or are you using it for your good?

ğŸŒ¹ Every person is a leader, and your purpose is your area of leadership! Betty Ogiel highlighted the 3Aâ€™s of leadership:
ğŸ“Œ Assess: Who are you? What are your strengths, weaknesses, and purpose?
ğŸ“Œ Accept: After self-assessment, accept who you are. Change what you can and accept what you cannot.
ğŸ“Œ Action: Thereâ€™s no change or transformation without action. Take action!

Hosted by Business Today Executive Director Rahul Kanwal, this conversation unpacks the concept of a "Geopolitical Recession" and explores how the world must prepare for it. Brende sheds light on the economic, political, and technological dynamics reshaping global landscapes, from rising geopolitical tensions and economic disparities to the transformative power of AI, green energy, and international collaboration. How will the geopolitical and economic shifts affect businesses and individuals?

We discussed how much Davosâ€”and the worldâ€”has changed since 1999. Back then, optimism about European integration, globalisation, and the tech boom shaped the discussions. Today, in 2025, we stand at a crossroads: faced with climate urgency, AI governance, and deepening inequalities, leaders must choose between collaboration or fragmentation, action or inaction.
Â 
Martin shared memories of Davos 2000 when President Clinton became the first sitting U.S. president to attend. His visit symbolised a belief in global cooperation, which is much like what weâ€™re striving for today.
That same year, the GAVI Alliance was launched at Davos, a partnership that has since saved millions of lives by ensuring vaccine access worldwide.

I see this daily in my work, primarily through partnerships with healthcare companies and philanthropic foundationsâ€”organisations whose commitment to global health and equity continues to drive real change.

Ogen's message was clear: First Nations are determined to be active participants in shaping their own futures. They seek partnerships built on respect, trust, and a shared vision for economic prosperity.
 
The Cedar LNG project, spearheaded by the Haisla Nation , stands as a groundbreaking example of Indigenous ownership in the LNG sector. The Coastal GasLink pipeline offered First Nations along its route a 10% equity stake, ensuring long-term revenue streams, procurement opportunities, jobs, and training.

Title: Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D on LinkedIn

#economicreconciliation #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #communityâ€¦ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D | 11 comments Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D Chief Executive Officer | Certified board director | Indigenous business | Passionate about ESG | Supporter of sustainable resource extraction 2mo Report this post Over the last year Tlicho Government has been forming a relationship with Fortescue an Australian mining company that prides itself on its environmental stewardship and Indigenous partnerships. Late last year I had the opportunity to travel to Australia with the Tlicho Chiefs to tour some of Fortescueâ€™s operations and to meet with various Indigenous groups that Fortescue works with throughout their operations. It was truly an inspiring trip with a great company that lives and breathes its values. 

Earlier this week while at the AME Roundup show Tlicho Government signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Fortescue to assist in developing the Tlicho lands for future mineral development ( https://lnkd.in/gjAD8DTP ). Truly a groundbreaking moment as the nation continues to move forward and develop its economic future. I for one could not be more proud to work with this group and help build a robust economy for the region. 

Congratulations Tlicho on an amazing step in your economic journey. #economicreconciliation #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #community #mining #exploration #criticalminerals #AME #roundup #NWT #yellowknife 312 11 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Jesse Cody Owner at Red Spade Ent. Thanks to all who joined us! Letâ€™s continue striving for excellence! ğŸ‘ #LeanTransformation #ContinuousImprovement #Leadership #Manufacturing 29 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Danielle Orozco Cosio, PhD Co-Founder, CEO @ Ontologic | Mission-driven collaborator 9mo Edited Report this post BIO International Convention was a huge opportunity and learning experience. My key takeaways from attending for the first time last week: 

ğŸ» Satellite events are where the real value is. We spent time on the exhibition floor and at satellite events, and hands down, made more meaningful connections at satellite events. This was because most people on the conference floor were salespeople, and we were more focused on having conversations about the science and business problems. At events run by Bullpen and several other organizations we were able to meet with decision makers, founders, and investors that gave great insights we'll be taking home with us, and will ideally lead to partnerships and deals in the coming weeks. 

ğŸ’° Commercialization is king. The founders and CXOs we met all had amazing scientific and technological innovations at the core of their companies, but the problems everyone was looking to solve were around money and market. How do you fund the science? How do you get it in the hands and bodies of users? How can we make the business growth align with the mission? When you're learning to be a scientist most of the emphasis is on the hard scientific problems, but once you step into the business of science, it's all about engineering human systems. 

ğŸ¤ The best way to form relationships is in person. Ontologic was founded post-pandemic, and as a software company, most of our work can be done remotely. But when you're limited to a 1h virtual panel or a 30m zoom meeting you don't make the same personal connection that you do in person. I was so happy to run into friends coincidentally on the conference floor and have conversations I likely wouldn't have purposely sought out with people I just happened to meet at satellite events. It strengthens relationships in a very human way that isn't captured in a virtual setting, and I plan to make time for in-person social events as much as possible moving forward. 

Would love to hear others' takeaways! Ontologic 524 followers 9mo Our leadership team had such an amazing time at #BIO2024 ! We can't wait to share updates about the exciting #networking connections and #partnerships we made in San Diego last week - and are excited to do it all again Wednesday and Thursday at #FOGBoston ğŸ¤©  See you there! 37 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Emma Johnson Life Sciences VC 10mo Edited Report this post Thanks to all that joined the closing panel session of #BioEquityEurope as the conference wrapped up by looking to the future and heard from Campbell Stewart of Novo Holdings , Therese Liechtenstein of M Ventures , Gabriela Ecco of +ND Capital and Anne Grahl of Pureos Bioventures We spoke about: 
ğŸ’° the role of investors
âœ…how we can support portfolio companies to break out from the noise, and to navigate challenges
ğŸ¤– the investment opportunities that are created by enabling technologies such as AI and novel research methods that are unlocking new insights into biology
ğŸ§¬ But, how investment fundamentals in biotech remain the same 
ğŸ§ª And, that the key to winning investor interest is to have breakthrough science that ignites our curiosity enough to partner with a team for the long term 125 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Shefali Singh Developing â€œDBMTâ€@Ecofunomics LLP.| Serving 1000+ students, entrepreneurs, & academicians. |R&D Specialist | Unlocking powerful insights with data analysis | GeoStrat Insights  | Crafting effective business strategies| 5mo Report this post DÍiÍsÍcÍoÍvÍeÍrÍ. Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenomicsâ€™ Post Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1y Report this post "I love the concept of Indigenomics which talks about the actual metrics, design, and research for understanding Indigenous economic strength and development. 

We need to tell this new success story and outline the needs in responding to this emerging growing economy. 

Indigenomics is an economic platform to connect to the GDP, identify targets, create collective actions that support wealth generation within our communities. $100 billion Indigenous economy - that is the number we need to be paying attention to." - Clint Davis Indigenomics invites dialogue, and thought provoking insight into the possibility of the Indigenous relationship both in Canada and beyond. It explores the pathway of the threshold of the Indigenous relationship and modern economies. 

Join us next week for Indigenomics in ACTION to garner the essential tools and knowledge required to be active partners in our collective response to advancing the 100 Billion Indigenous economy.

A huge Masi Cho to all the community members who joined us yesterday for our recruitment drive and information sessions about the employment opportunities at the Giant Mine site, as part of the upcoming Core Area Building Demolition project!
 
Your engagement and enthusiasm mean a lot, and we're thrilled to see such interest in these important employment opportunities.

Over the next 2 years the industrial buildings onsite will be demoed and materials disposed of. 

The Tlicho Investment Corporation & Group of Companies has partnererd with True North Environmental to provide the necessary labour.  The TIC team will be providing recruitment and information sessions for the project!

 *   Whati Culture Centre: Monday, February 24, 4-7:30 pm

Today until Sunday, the ice is booked for 136 hockey games. All part of the 16th Annual Mushkegowuk Cup. Welcome teams, players, families, and hockey fans. 

Events like the Mushkegowuk Cup help northern communities thrive. One long weekend of great hockey is expected to bring in over $2 million to support local hotels, restaurants, and retailers. Amazing!

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D Chief Executive Officer | Certified board director | Indigenous business | Passionate about ESG | Supporter of sustainable resource extraction 2w Report this post Finishing up a busy week at the Prospectors and Development Association of Canada (PDAC) conference in Toronto. Had the opportunity to connect with lots of colleagues while proudly representing Tlicho Investment Corporation & Group of Companies with members of the team and Tlicho leadership. 

Several of us sat down on a panel discussing a decarbonized mining world. Some great examples from across the North for both active and exploration mining project all of which had significant Indigenous involvement. 

It was announced that I have joined the board for Kingfisher Metals Corp. Excited to join Dustin Perry, P.Geo. and the team in their journey to develop the next world class properties in the golden triangle.  They have a great vision and are focused on creating value for the Tahltan nation on the lands that they operate on.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D Chief Executive Officer | Certified board director | Indigenous business | Passionate about ESG | Supporter of sustainable resource extraction 6d Edited Report this post I had the opportunity to present with my fellow panelists at Canada House in London yesterday on the Canadian natural diamond industry.

Some of the key points included:

- The co-management of mining within the NWT between Indigenous groups, government and industry. 

- The best practices of socio-economic agreements and Impact Benefit Agreements that have resulted in meaningful employment, capacity building, economic opportunity and infrastructure. 

- The planned reclamation of the mines before they are even started ensuring that there isnâ€™t a negative legacy at the end of mine life. 

- How the mining sector has impacted Indigenous communities both positively and negatively. 

- The eye watering experiences of Lily James and her team experiencing -50 for the first time (full disclosure itâ€™s still darn cold for us northerners as well. 

Thank you for the invite to participate Natural Diamond Council and to Raluca Anghel for organizing. Amazing event. #naturaldiamonds #mining #esg #indigenousbusiness #indigenomics #fashion #jewelry #nwt #yellowknife #canada 357 28 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Wendy Larson Leader in Digital Transformation / Empowering companies to outpace the competition through digital transformation 6d Report this comment Such a great opportunity for you Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D ! Thatâ€™s why Iâ€™m supporting CanFlowthrough.com â€”a national campaign to extend flow-through shares to Canadaâ€™s technology sector.

Flow-through shares have helped build Canadaâ€™s mining and energy industries for decades. Itâ€™s time to give our digital economy the same chance.

If youâ€™re a founder, investor, policymaker, or just someone who believes in keeping Canadian innovation in Canadian hands, visit www.canflowthrough.com and add your voice.

Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 2mo The Indigenomics Institute is excited to launch  Indigenomics 50-  an ambitious challenge designed to guide 50 leading companies and organizations through the Indigenomics LEGO DESIGN Reconciliation Action Planning Sessions in 2025. This initiative leverages an innovative, interactive approach that integrates the principles of collaboration, creativity, and accountability to support organizations in embedding reconciliation outcomes into their core strategies.

Kicking off in Vancouver on April 7th, the sessions will take place throughout the year across the country. Participants will co-create actionable reconciliation plans that align with economic inclusion, cultural respect, and partnerships with Indigenous communities. 

Be part of reconciliation-driven innovation! 

Email info@indigenomics.com to register. At TELUS, we firmly believe in the responsible use of AI and recognize the importance of diverse voices in shaping our digital future.

Botanical Products & Gift Boxes 1y Report this post PEER MENTORING IN BUSINESS!

I've had the honor of learning from very strong and successful women and men in business!  

It didn't take me long to realize that I could not and should not attempt to manage, operate or grow my business on my own!  I needed to learn from the business women and men who had done this before me!  I learned very quickly that we were not in competition, and so many successful business people were willing to help me grow my business!

I learned from several business books published by successful business women and I shamelessly support the writings and teachings from  Arlene Dickinson, Venture Communications.  I had chats with the successful beauty brand #Cheekbone creator, Jen Harper, and successful female leaders from #indigenomics , Carol Anne Hilton; #yukonsoaps , #RavenReads , #Indigenousbox , #BearsLairTV creator Geena Jackson and so many more peer mentors and successful business people across Canada.  I am so grateful!!

I also have a business coach who helps me  to  find resources for the growth  and management of my business.  

I encourage everyone to find their peer mentors in business! #peers #businessmentors #businessincanada #businessmanagement #businessbooks #businesssuccess 7 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in 1,129 followers 832 Posts 1 Article View Profile Connect More from this author Big News! Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 5mo Report this post #indigenomics Olthuis, Kleer, Townshend LLP 1,389 followers 5mo In our latest blog post 'Good corporate governance must take into account Aboriginal rights,' authors Nick Kennedy , Jaclyn McNamara and Thadsha Chandrakumaran highlight the Supreme Court's recent refusal to hear the appeal inÂ Thomas v Rio Tinto Alcan Inc, 2024 BCCA 62 [Saikâ€™uz]. InÂ Saikâ€™uz, the British Columbia Court of Appeal found that Aboriginal fishing rights were capable of grounding a claim in nuisance against a private entity, but that Rio Tinto Alcan Inc. (â€œRio Tintoâ€) had a complete defence because its actions were authorized by statute.

The Supreme Courtâ€™s refusal to hear this appeal was a missed opportunity to advance reconciliation. The Court could have done so by abolishing the statutory authorization defence for infringements of Aboriginal rights and title, thereby allocating a greater share of the risk of liability onto private entities. If the Supreme Court had taken this bold step, it would have increased the likelihood of these claims being settled, either by the private entities themselves or by the Crown under pressure from the private sector.

Description: Jan 17, 2025  Â·  We are thrilled to introduce Lance B., a recipient of the 2024 Indigenomics Scholarship. Lance Black is Anicinape from Apitipi Anicinapek Nation in Ontario.
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #scholarshiprecipients #indigenousexcellenceâ€¦ | Indigenomics | 11 comments Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenomicsâ€™ Post Indigenomics 4,887 followers 2mo Edited Report this post Celebrating Indigenomics Scholarship Recipient: Lance Black! 

We are thrilled to introduce Lance B. , a recipient of the 2024 Indigenomics Scholarship. Lance Black is Anicinape from Apitipi Anicinapek Nation in Ontario. He is the Director of Negotiations and Contract Management for his Nation and an MBA candidate at Ivey Business School. Lance represents his community in mining negotiations while also leading Apitipi Resources Inc. as President. By night, Lance is a DJ and has a passion for underground dance music playing Indigenous events on occasion.

We are proud to celebrate Lanceâ€™s inspiring journey as he continues to pave the way for economic reconciliation and community empowerment. #Indigenomics #ScholarshipRecipients #IndigenousExcellence #Indigenomicsscholarships 101 11 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Gilles Laderoute Real estate investor, Chair of Time To Lead Christian Concert committee, Former BRM Mayor and Councillor, Entrepreneur,  Father, Grandfather and Christian 1mo Report this comment Congratulations Lance!!

Check out our website here: https://lnkd.in/e7VdsqaJ Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in John Laurent Culture & Leadership consultant 7mo Edited Report this post Kiwiblog lists some of the grants made by the Marsden Fund using taxpayer money. Hilarious 

â€¢ $360,000 to study Big Things such as the Ohakune Carrot, with a focus on â€œa critical gaze to the privileging of PÄkehÄ-centred narratives in current research on roadside â€œBig Thingsâ€ and â€œWeaving together feminist, participatory, and filmic geographies, this project seeks to re-centre alternative stories currently hidden in the Big Thingsâ€™ shadowsâ€œ

â€¢ $360,000 to collect disabled indigenous stories about climate change with â€œestablishing how such stories resist ableist narratives and theorise and advance disability-centred ways of creating sustainable and just environmental futures.â€œ

â€¢$861,000 to explore dark nudges and sludge on social media in relation to advertising alcohol.

â€¢ $861,000 to help decolonise ocean worlds from imperial borders

â€¢ $861,000 to link celestial spheres to end-of-life experiences to â€œcreate opportunities to rekindle the ancient connection to the stars and re-imagine the meaning of death, while also advancing understandings about the practical application of MÄori astronomy in contemporary times

This research journal promises to be an enlightening exploration of the complex intersection of culture, environment, and economic change, which is so often overlooked in discussions surrounding oil exploration.
The Urhobo people's heritage and history, deeply entwined with their ancestral lands, set a powerful backdrop for the narrative of transformation brought about by the discovery and exploitation of oil. Your work sheds light on how such seismic changes affect not only the environment but also the social fabric, cultural identity, and livelihoods of the community.
The title "Roots and Shifts: The Urhobo People and the Coming of Oil" poignantly captures the essence of this transformation â€” the roots representing the cultural and environmental richness of the community, while the shifts signify the profound disruptions and challenges brought by the arrival of the oil industry.
Your approach to chronicling this history is invaluable, and I look forward to diving deeper into how these changes have reshaped the lives of the Urhobo people. It is crucial to explore such topics from a local, grassroots perspective to create a more holistic understanding of the effects of resource extraction on indigenous communities. This journal will no doubt foster greater dialogue around responsible resource management and community engagement.
I eagerly await the next installment of this series, and I commend your commitment to highlighting the voices of those who are often left out of mainstream discussions about oil and development. #OilImpact #CulturalHeritage #EnvironmentalChange #CommunityResearch #IndigenousRights #SustainableDevelopment #BlackGold Ogheneruemu Siemuri Graduate || Environmentalist || Ex- Intern at Tudaka Analytical Limited || Editor || Teacher || Fashion Designer|| Baker || Ecowriter ||Student at Delta State University, Nigeria 2mo Edited ğŸ“¢ New Research Journal Alert!

If we break down the terms, then Makar means Capricorn and
Sankranti means enty of the sun. Hence Makar Sankrati simply means entry of the sun into the zodiac sign of Capricorn. This is the day when the sun begins its northward journey in the sky, from the Tropic of Capricorn to the Tropic of cancer.
 This celestial event has a profound effect on the biosphere and the
environment, due to the changes in the Earth's energy dynamics. 
This shift results in longer days, higher temperatures, and a boost in
photosynthesis, which supports plant growth and enhances
agricultural cycles. It also influences animal behavior, triggering migration patterns in birds and awakening hibernating species. The warming effect
accelerates biological activity across ecosystems, from forests to
grasslands.
Beyond ecological impacts, the increase in sunlight benefits human
well-being by enhancing mood and energy levels, contributing to
social and cultural celebrations like Makar Sankranti, Pongal, Bihu and Lohri.
One festival, so many names !
Makar Sankranti will begin on 14 th January at 9.03 AM IST.
Greetings and best wishes for the auspicious festival. #MakarSankranti #CapricornSun #SolarJourney #WinterSolstice #EnergyShift #BiosphereImpact #EcologicalChange #LongerDays #AgricultureCycle #PhotosynthesisBoost #NatureAwakening #MigrationPatterns #HumanWellBeing #CulturalCelebrations #FestivalsOfIndia #Pongal #Bihu #FestivalSeason #NewBeginnings #SolarEvent #MakarSankranti2025 #AuspiciousOccasions #GoodVibes â€¦more Makar Sankranti: The Scientific basis https://www.youtube.com/ 19 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Dr Angela C Meyers Author, Coach, Consultant. Enhancing Human Thriving. 3mo Edited Report this post Last month, I hosted an international Polymath Retreat in Corfu, Greece with brilliant minds from Canada, the USA, Brazil, England, Switzerland, and the Netherlandsâ€”a true global gathering. 

We had a diverse, well-balanced group, with roughly half male and half female participants. 

Our mission was bold: to begin tackling some of the worldâ€™s most pressing global issues.

Did we figure out how to save the world in a three-hour workshop? No. But did we start an important conversation and document our insights? Absolutely. And will we build from this foundation? Without question. 

This is just the beginning, but itâ€™s a necessary start.

Humanity must self-organize differently if we are to solve the polycrisis on a global scale. 

Who can rise to the challenge? Polymathsâ€”the systems thinkers, the big-picture problem solvers.

Congratulations Caleb! Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y Congratulations to Caleb Maurice- the  Indigenomics DESIGN 2023 Scholarship Recipient!
The Indigenomics Institute Scholarship was established to honour the resilience of Indigenous people who were systematically denied a seat at the economic table of this country.
The scholarship goes to Indigenous students enrolled in Business, Commerce or Finance academic programs across Canada in either Bachelor or Masters Programs.
Proceeds from revenues from the Indigenomics Store, comprised of t-shirts, mugs, candles, jewelry and tea and other products will go towards the distribution of annual Indigenomics scholarships.
This is the 5th scholarship that has been awarded since 2022 and the Indigenomics Institute is pleased to welcome Vancity as a partner to the Indigenomics Scholarship. #Indigenomics #indigenouseconomy #100billion 23 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Gil Yaron Managing Director, Circular Innovation 1y Report this comment Way to go Caleb Maurice !!! Title: Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D on LinkedIn
Description: Oct 12, 2023  Â·  #esg #business #criticalminerals #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #community #prosperity. No alternative text description for this image. 84Â ...
Extracted_Text:
#esg #business #criticalminerals #indigenomics #indigenousbusinessâ€¦ | Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D Chief Executive Officer | Certified board director | Indigenous business | Passionate about ESG | Supporter of sustainable resource extraction 1y Edited Report this post Enjoyed presenting with Rob McPhee at the Business Council of British Columbia Business Forum. 

We kept it short and punchy focussing on:

- The TNDC journey which requires a strong team, supportive community and industry /government support. 

- A drive towards a decarbonzed mining jurisdiction which will be the first Tier 1 carbon neutral mining jurisdiction in Canada.

- The need for Government and Industry to continue investing in Indigenous communities and businesses and the areas they reside in. Indigenous communities are often the gatekeepers for projects to move forward. Bring Indigenous communities into the opportunities in a meaningful way as true partners. 

Thank you again for Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC) to present. Great crowd!!! #esg #business #criticalminerals #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness #community #prosperity 84 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Layne Tucker Indigenous Founder ECHORFID/PIPETALKER 2011 Founder Prostar Technologies. Title: Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D posted on the topic | LinkedIn
Description: Mar 1, 2024  Â·  Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author xÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
Indigenomics NOW: A guide to interconnectedness | Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D posted on the topic | LinkedIn Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y Report this post Indigenomics NOW draws inspiration from the powerful Nuu-chah-nulth concept of â€œtsawalk," which translates to "one." This profound principle reminds us that all living beings, from humans and animals to the very plants that sustain us, are fundamentally interconnected, forming a single, harmonious whole.

Within the framework of Indigenomics, "tsawalk" becomes a guiding light, to acknowledge the intrinsic interconnectedness of our economic systems with the natural world. Indigenomics NOW is designed to reflect the natural world and serves to advance an economic narrative that is shaped by the natural world.

Indigenomics NOW serves as a powerful platform to translate this philosophy into action. November 14th ,2024. Registration opens soon.

#energytransition #cleanenergy #indigenomics #gridmodernizationâ€¦ | Don Richardson Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Don Richardsonâ€™s Post Don Richardson CEO @ Minogi Corp., Interim CEO @ Noozhoo Nokiiyan LP | Spearheading First Nation Investments 3mo Report this post This week I had the honour to fill in for Chief Kelly LaRocca of the Mississaugas of Scugog Island First Nation (MSIFN) in a panel discussion titled "Energy Grids and Storage â€“ Investing in a Cleaner Future" sponsored by the Globe and Mail in partnership with Indigenous Clean Energy (ICE). 

Ontario's energy project growth is happening at a pace we have never seen, and First Nations like MSIFN are at the epicenter. Moderator Matt McClearn from the Globe and Mail's Energy, Natural Resources and Environment Team focused on the challenges and solutions for the energy transition, including the rapid growth of First Nation investments and co-development of significant projects. I am proud of our work at MSIFN through Minogi to accelerate clean energy investments with our First Nation and private sector partners with new and creative investment solutions.

We had an informative discussion with co-panelists Jason Rioux , Chief Development Officer of NRStor Inc. , and Simmer Anand , Senior Manager, Indigenous RelationsÂ of Hydro One . Thanks to the Globe and Mail ( Lisa Wichmann ) and ICE ( James Jenkins ) for creating the stage for this important conversation. #EnergyTransition #CleanEnergy #Indigenomics #GridModernization #IndigenousPartnerships #Sustainability The Globe and Mail Events 1,851 followers 3mo PANEL | Energy Grids and Storage â€“ Investing in a cleaner future, moderated by Matt McClearn , Data Reporter, The Globe and Mail Don Richardson , CEO, Minogi (joining virtually) Jason Rioux , Chief Development Officer, NRStor Inc. Simmer Anand , Senior Manager of Indigenous Relations, Hydro One #GlobeGathering 52 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Dave Mowat 3mo Report this comment Getting out on the front end of sustainable energy development and innovation is key in these dynamic times. And as First Nations people and communities our place in this landscape is an important and necessary objective.  A research hub Don, I think at the FN level, to feed into this industry is another, I think, worthy endeavour. State of the art, sustainable energy innovation centre/hub! By swapping out their old engines for the cutting-edge Waukesha VHP Series Five engines from INNIO. These engines not only reduce methane emissions by 90% but also cut CO2e intensity by 20%! ğŸŒ±ğŸ’¨

The best part? Enstor didn't have to choose between profitability and sustainability. The reUp program allowed them to upgrade to the latest tech while reusing existing infrastructure, making it a win-win for both the environment and their bottom line. ğŸ’¡ğŸ’°

This project is a shining example of how innovation and sustainability can go hand in hand. Kudos to Enstor for leading the way! ğŸ‘ #WaukeshaEngines #EnergyInnovation #SustainableSolutions #CarbonNeutral #OilAndGas #ClimateAction ğŸŒğŸ”‹ğŸ’¡

What do you think? ğŸ˜Š 13 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in John Feddersen Founder & CEO, Aurora Energy Research Limited 11mo Edited Report this post Excellent video Henry Schmandt ! A little technical, but I wholeheartedly recommend for anyone investing in nodal markets. 

The Aurora Energy Research teamâ€™s development of capabilities for flow-based nodal analysis provides an important example of â€œuseful complexityâ€ in power modelling.

George Box famously said: â€œall models are wrong, but some are usefulâ€.

As a modelling company first and foremost, perhaps the most important (and often hardest) strategic decision for Aurora is deciding how much complexity to incorporate into our models.

Complexity in models is expensive: it increases solve time and compute; and takes time and deep expertise to code and debug. 

For many years and in many markets, Aurora have explored various ways to model nodal pricing in power markets (e.g. extrapolation based on history; structural statistical relationships) but none of them provide the flexibility and richness of Fundamental Security Constrained Economic Dispatch (SCED) modelling. 

A really great explanation here of why we go to the effort to do it, and why it is so important for anyone investing in nodal markets. In an era where innovation is the cornerstone of progress, the conversation around decentralized science (DeSci) and decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs) in longevity biotech is timely and vital. 

The recent Longevity+DeSci Summit in NYC, hosted by Lifespan.io , was a pivotal event that presented a fascinating panel discussion on the intersection of decentralized science (DeSci) and autonomous organizations in longevity biotech. 

The summit featured an impressive lineup of panelists. These thought leaders each brought a unique perspective and expertise, contributing to our understanding of how DeSci and DAOs can revolutionize our engagement with longevity biotech. The synergy between traditional biotech and emerging decentralized frameworks will pave the way for unprecedented breakthroughs. 

As leaders and innovators, it's crucial that we stay ahead of these conversations and actively leverage them to foster growth and collaboration in the biotech sphere. I highly recommend watching the entire discussion for insights into the future of longevity and how we can collectively push the boundaries of science and technology. 

You can access the video here: https://lnkd.in/e8T665Zz . Lifespan.io Longevity News 8,360 followers 6mo Panel discussion entitled "The Role of DeSci and DAOs in Engaging the World in Longevity Biotech" at the Longevity+DeSci Summit NYC (EARD 2023) hosted by Lifespan.io (Lifespan Extension Advocacy Foundation) Panel speakers include: Keith Comito -President and Co-founder of Lifespan.io Jelani Clarke Ph.D. Clarke, Ph.D.
-Core Leadership at DeSci World Azeem Khan -Head of Impact at Gitcoin Eleanor Davies  
-Longevity Dealflow at VitaDAO Natasha Vita-More, PhD, MPhil, MSc - 1st Vita-More, Ph.D.
-Longevity and Evolution Expert at Digital University Chauncey St. John -Founder of Angel Protocol

We are deeply grateful to the First Nations Major Projects Coalition for their support as the Content Sponsor of the Indigenous Wealth Building session at Indigenomics on BAY STREET. 

This important session invited dialogue on how Indigenous trusts and investment strategies have evolved significantly over the last 50 years. Through increasing settlement values and innovative strategies, trusts and investments have become powerful tools for driving economic development and supporting social programming in Indigenous communities.

For thousands of years, wealth has been expressed through giving, the transaction, the distribution through ceremony and based upon the quality of recognition of relationship and connection to each other, to our environment, and to resources with respect for life at the heart of both the economy and ceremony. 

This is Indigenomics.

The technology behind developing a Universal Oxygen carrier is proceeding.  
Reminding people that animal trials showed no increase in respiration despite taking out blood.  There's a reason why we can only donate 1 pint of blood because if you took out more the heart would have to pump harder to get same amount oxygen to the parts of the body with less blood volume.  That means you have to circulate a lower volume of blood more times to keep the same output.  Since respiration didn't increase its reasonable to conclude that the animals got oxygen from the molecule.

This research journal promises to be an enlightening exploration of the complex intersection of culture, environment, and economic change, which is so often overlooked in discussions surrounding oil exploration.
The Urhobo people's heritage and history, deeply entwined with their ancestral lands, set a powerful backdrop for the narrative of transformation brought about by the discovery and exploitation of oil. Your work sheds light on how such seismic changes affect not only the environment but also the social fabric, cultural identity, and livelihoods of the community.
The title "Roots and Shifts: The Urhobo People and the Coming of Oil" poignantly captures the essence of this transformation â€” the roots representing the cultural and environmental richness of the community, while the shifts signify the profound disruptions and challenges brought by the arrival of the oil industry.
Your approach to chronicling this history is invaluable, and I look forward to diving deeper into how these changes have reshaped the lives of the Urhobo people. It is crucial to explore such topics from a local, grassroots perspective to create a more holistic understanding of the effects of resource extraction on indigenous communities. This journal will no doubt foster greater dialogue around responsible resource management and community engagement.
I eagerly await the next installment of this series, and I commend your commitment to highlighting the voices of those who are often left out of mainstream discussions about oil and development. #OilImpact #CulturalHeritage #EnvironmentalChange #CommunityResearch #IndigenousRights #SustainableDevelopment #BlackGold Ogheneruemu Siemuri Graduate || Environmentalist || Ex- Intern at Tudaka Analytical Limited || Editor || Teacher || Fashion Designer|| Baker || Ecowriter ||Student at Delta State University, Nigeria 2mo Edited ğŸ“¢ New Research Journal Alert!

If we break down the terms, then Makar means Capricorn and
Sankranti means enty of the sun. Hence Makar Sankrati simply means entry of the sun into the zodiac sign of Capricorn. This is the day when the sun begins its northward journey in the sky, from the Tropic of Capricorn to the Tropic of cancer.
 This celestial event has a profound effect on the biosphere and the
environment, due to the changes in the Earth's energy dynamics. 
This shift results in longer days, higher temperatures, and a boost in
photosynthesis, which supports plant growth and enhances
agricultural cycles. It also influences animal behavior, triggering migration patterns in birds and awakening hibernating species. The warming effect
accelerates biological activity across ecosystems, from forests to
grasslands.
Beyond ecological impacts, the increase in sunlight benefits human
well-being by enhancing mood and energy levels, contributing to
social and cultural celebrations like Makar Sankranti, Pongal, Bihu and Lohri.
One festival, so many names !
Makar Sankranti will begin on 14 th January at 9.03 AM IST.
Greetings and best wishes for the auspicious festival. #MakarSankranti #CapricornSun #SolarJourney #WinterSolstice #EnergyShift #BiosphereImpact #EcologicalChange #LongerDays #AgricultureCycle #PhotosynthesisBoost #NatureAwakening #MigrationPatterns #HumanWellBeing #CulturalCelebrations #FestivalsOfIndia #Pongal #Bihu #FestivalSeason #NewBeginnings #SolarEvent #MakarSankranti2025 #AuspiciousOccasions #GoodVibes â€¦more Makar Sankranti: The Scientific basis https://www.youtube.com/ 19 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Dr Angela C Meyers Author, Coach, Consultant. Reducing Human Suffering. Enhancing Human Thriving. 3mo Edited Report this post Last month, I hosted an international Polymath Retreat in Corfu, Greece with brilliant minds from Canada, the USA, Brazil, England, Switzerland, and the Netherlandsâ€”a true global gathering. 

We had a diverse, well-balanced group, with roughly half male and half female participants. 

Our mission was bold: to begin tackling some of the worldâ€™s most pressing global issues.

Did we figure out how to save the world in a three-hour workshop? No. But did we start an important conversation and document our insights? Absolutely. And will we build from this foundation? Without question. 

This is just the beginning, but itâ€™s a necessary start.

Humanity must self-organize differently if we are to solve the polycrisis on a global scale. 

Who can rise to the challenge? Polymathsâ€”the systems thinkers, the big-picture problem solvers.

We have shown you the path to the top.
We call upon you to do the climbing.â€
~ Chief Commissioner Murray Sinclair
TRC Commission

The #Indigenomics by Design conference has served to inspire, educate, and humble me. The thought leaders, change agents, and community builders that have presented and participated in the event have made clear what #indigenouspower is and the impact of that power and success.

Some sources of inspiration (and this is not at all comprehensive so I encourage future attendance at the event!) include:

ğŸ”‹Indigenous Peopleâ€™s are leading the clean energy transition. 
â–«ï¸â€Indigenous inclusion means a just transition to a clean energy future.â€ ~ Carol Anne Hilton, MBA â–«ï¸ Research from a 2020 Indigenous Clean Energy Social Enterprise report identified 197  Canadian companies in the clean energy sector.
â–«ï¸ Research from Chris Henderson was cited, noting â€œIndigenous communities are the third largest owners of clean energy companies in Canada.â€

ğŸ§­ The theory of change must chart the straightest line between the current and future state. This must involve meaningful and deep consideration of what economic reconciliation means and a commitment and plan to advance it. Without this understanding, there is a risk of advancing projects merely for marketing purposes, missing true impact. 
â–«ï¸ Recommended reading: Raven Impact Measurement Framework (RIM)
â¡ï¸ https://lnkd.in/g-jhVn4Q by Raven Indigenous Capital Partners . 

ğŸ¤ Partnerships are key to advancing economic development and building indigenous prosperity.

Further reflections of the learnings of today and yesterday are required. Deepest gratitude to all in the room and event organizers for creating this space and opportunity. 25 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Karen Lamare 1y Report this comment Thanks for sharing! Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Natasha Delany BA, MBAâ€™s Post Natasha Delany BA, MBA Founder of Indigenous Projects & Events | Public Speaker/Facilitator | Transformation & Business Coach for Indigenous Woman | 2024 Finalist for GIFEW Evolutionary Awards 8mo Report this post Room is booked for this amazing conference in Winnipeg, Manitoba where I will be presenting on my ğŸ’ Diamonds Mastermind course, a 6 month online course for Indigenous Women Entrepreneurs.

Have you checked out the powerful Indigenomics SHE agenda? Day 2 includes an incredible afternoon focused on Indigenous Wealth Dynamics featuring three plenary sessions:

Financial Management - this session we will hear from certified financial planners on how to create financial well-being and intergenerational wealth

Personal Side of Wealth - this session will explore the personal side of Indigenous wealth and financial realities that we confront. Strength based and trauma informed with the goal to empower- inviting people to ponder and connect to their lived experience.

Pricing Strategies For Products & Services For Indigenous Businesses - this session will highlight various pricing strategies and things to consider as many Indigenous Entrepreneurs, creatives and service providers struggle with knowing the "right" price.

Learn, grow, and connect with like-minded Indigenous women in business management, entrepreneurship and economic development.  Register now!

* REV Global:Â At REV Global, we equip businesses with the tools and resources they need toÂ thrive. Stronger businesses create more jobs, drive innovation, and fuel economic growth. This creates a ripple effect of positive change.
* Ayana Foundation:Â The Ayana Foundation fosters a supportive community where founders can connect, share experiences, and learn from each other.Â EmpoweringÂ andÂ upliftingÂ these individuals is key to their success, which translates into a wider impact on the world.
Together, REV Global and ayana Foundation create a powerful ecosystem for impact. One provides the tools, the other fosters the connections. Both are necessary to empower founders and businesses to reach their full potential and drive positive change.
This is my "why." Title: Alison Warwick Fernandes' Post - LinkedIn
Description: Sep 11, 2024  Â·  Delighted and honored to be speaking at the upcoming Indigenomics on Bay Street conference October 16-18, 2024!
Extracted_Text:
Delighted and honored to be speaking at the upcoming Indigenomics on Bayâ€¦ | Alison Warwick Fernandes Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Alison Warwick Fernandesâ€™ Post Alison Warwick Fernandes Senior Manager | Supply Chain - Indigenous Procurement & EDI Procurement, ESG | Ontario Power Generation 6mo Report this post Delighted and honored to be speaking at the upcoming Indigenomics on Bay Street conference October 16-18, 2024! 

I'll be addressing Sustainable Economic Reconciliation and Empowerment with a focus on Indigenous Procurement and Opportunities, highlighting the importance and crucial need to change the narrative to include Indigenous peoples, communities, and businesses in conversations and decision making right from the start.  

Looking forward to insightful conversations and meaningful action! Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 6mo Edited Indigenomics Institute is excited to have Cullen Price , Manager, Ontario Securities Commission and Alison Warwick Fernandes , Senior Manager Supply Chain Indigenous Programs, Ontario Power Generation join us to speak on the Corporate Canadaâ€™s Response to TRC Call to Action #92 and Indigenous Procurement. 

These sessions will explore how businesses are advancing economic reconciliation and how Indigenous procurement is driving economic growth by integrating Indigenous participation into supply chains across government and corporate sectors. Learn about opportunities, challenges, and key insights from leading experts.

Don't miss out! Seats are filling fast. Registration closes Oct 9th. https://lnkd.in/geMXdZPA #Indigenomics #EconomicReconciliation #Indigenousbusiness #baystreet #canecon #canpoli #cdnpoli #ontecon 62 9 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Alison Bradley Director Nuclear Projects Supply Chain  Ontario Power Generation 6mo Report this comment You will be amazing. Like Reply 1Â Reaction 2Â Reactions See more comments To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Communities Economic Development Fund Manitoba 365 followers 9mo Report this post The First Nations Major Projects Coalition (FNMPC) held their 7th Annual conference â€˜Our Collective Advantage: Indigenous Consentâ€™ in Toronto on April 22-23, 2024. 

Communities Economic Development Fund sponsored 13 attendees representing 8 Manitoba First Nations attended the conference including:

â€¢	Norway House Cree Nation
â€¢	Garden Hill First Nation
â€¢	Tatakwayak Cree Nation
â€¢	Misipawistik Cree Nation
â€¢	Bunibonibee Cree Nation 
â€¢	Mathais Colomb First Nation
â€¢	Kiciwapa Cree Nation
â€¢	Northlands Denesuline First Nation

The conference was FNMPCâ€™s biggest event by far, with over 1500 delegates, 200+ companies and over 450 Indigenous representatives. 

The main theme was showcasing how companies that honour and incorporate Indigenous consent across their business and supply chains hold a collective advantage over those who do not. 

Key topics including the unveiling of the National Indigenous Electrification Strategy, Free, Prior and Informed Consent, Canadian Mining and First Nations, and Indigenous Women in Finance. To learn more about the FNMPC, visit www.fnmpc.ca/ 12 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in FÃ¶reningen fÃ¶r utvecklingsfrÃ¥gor (FUF) 5,347 followers 3mo Edited Report this post Minerals from the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) are essential for digitalization and the green transition â€“ areas where Swedish companies lead the way. However, their extraction and trade are often linked to serious human rights violations, such as sexual violence and forced labor.

Friends of Panzi Hospital and FUF invite you to an important discussion on the role of businesses in promoting a responsible mining industry that supports peace and sustainability in the DRC and globally.
Â 
We are proud to present an esteemed panel of speakers including Nobel Peace Prize laureate Dr Denis Mukwege; venture capital investor Nyambo Sabuni; award winning journalist Staffan Lindberg; Swedenâ€™s ambassador to DRC 2019-2024 Henric RÃ¥sbrant; and experts from both civil society and the business sector who under the guidance of moderator Malou von Sivers will discuss:

HOW CANâ€¦
â€¦we balance power dynamics between multinational corporations and weak states to ensure fair resource benefits?
â€¦cross-sector collaboration drive innovation and sustainability while reducing exploitation risks?
â€¦regulations like CSDDD (Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive) strengthen resource management and contribute to peace?
Â 
Join this vital dialogue on Jan 20 and contribute to a sustainable future! Link in bio. #Sustainability #ResponsibleBusiness #MiningIndustry #DRC #SwedishCompanies #EthicalValueChains #CSDDD #PanziHospital #FUF #GreenTransition #Digitalization Malou von Sivers Staffan Lindberg Henric RÃ¥sbrant Eric Kajemba Nyamko Sabuni Henrik Hallgren Alice Blondel Joakim Wohlfeil European Partnership for Responsible Minerals (EPRM) Diakonia Swedwatch International Council of Swedish Industry (NIR) Aftonbladet 19 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Christos Balaskas Vice President, Commercial, Growth and External Relations (Greece) 10mo Report this post It has been a great honor to participate in the â€œEmpowering Change: Greece's Journey Towards a Sustainable Energy Landscapeâ€ panel, moderated by @Patti Domm, FWA Board Member and Emmy award-winning financial journalist, at the @Financial Women's AssociationÂ International Business Conference held in Athens.

During the discussion with esteemed fellow speakers, I highlighted the pivotal role that critical #rawmaterials play not only in national security and economic growth, but also in #Europe â€™sÂ climate goals, strategic autonomy and #greentransition .
Â 
In this direction, Critical Raw Materials Act (CRMA), the flagship legislative initiative to ensure EUâ€™s secure and sustainable supply of #criticalrawmaterials , creates a remarkable opportunity for #Greece , one of the most well-endowed mineral European countries, to exploit its mineral wealth in a #sustainable way.
Â 
In fact, more than 15 mineral raw materials included in the list of strategic and critical mineral raw materials, have been traced in Greek territory, while our #copper and #gold porphyry deposit at the transformational #Skouries project on the Halkidiki Peninsula in Northern Greece, will play a game â€“ changing role for our country, upon commencement of commercial production in Q3 2025. #HellasGold #ResponsibleMining #FWAIBC2024 #FWAIBCGreece 56 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Gaylor Montmasson-Clair Working for just transitions in the Global South 4mo Report this post Excited to share Southern Transitions ' 1st policy paper on #criticalmineral #valuechains in Africa, written with Lauren Hermanus and Anthony Dane . Download here: https://lnkd.in/d9cYNJfr 31 5 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Ketakandriana Rafitoson, PhD Executive Director, PWYP / Vice-Chair, Transparency International 3mo Report this post I am excited to be working with colleagues from #NRGI , #SOMO and other key experts this week, at the prestigious Bellagio Center, to build a common strategy on transition minerals value addition & fair benefit sharing. We are giving shape to a core element of the UNSG Panel on Critical Minerals!

This panelâ€™s recent report proposes the creation of a High-Level Advisory Group to promote "fair benefit-sharing, meaningful value addition, & economic diversification in low- & middle-income (LMIC) producer countries. 

To be really meaningful, this Group must:

âœ… Confront deep-seated global power imbalances in trade relations. Free trade has become a huge barrier to LMICâ€™s development, locking them into exporting raw material. The system needs to change to deliver shared value & economic equity.

âœ… Look at "value-addition" in every sense. It needs to include transformation of minerals in higher levels of the value chain, particularly in clean energy technologies!

âœ… Promote collaboration between Southern countries over competition, to build cross-regional value chains. 

âœ… Finally, whoâ€™s in the Advisory group really matters to break the status quo. It must include bold voices from CSOs, Indigenous Peoples and government representatives of both consumer and producer countries - especially those challenging global inequalities and trade frameworks.

We must ensure that the Advisory group starts on solid grounds and doesn't overlook these priorities. PWYP and partners are committed to making it happen! Zimbabwe Environmental Law Association APRI - Africa Policy Research Institute #TNIInstitute #PCGTW #GlobalJusticeUK 133 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Powering Australia 1,600 followers 7mo Report this post Australian Cooperative Research Centres (CRCs) have incredible convening power to solve industry problems, by bringing together nearly 1700 representatives from industry, government and academia from 18 countries and 4 continents, according to a report released this week.

The Powering Australia and the Future Battery Industries Cooperative Research Centre teams are proud to have contributed to the â€˜Mapping and quantification of CRCsâ€™ work on decarbonisationâ€™, report written by ACIL Allen and launched at Parliament House by Cooperative Research Australia .

The report provides independent analysis of the contribution of CRCs to Australia's ambitious decarbonisation goals and challenges policy makers to consider flexible funding models for CRCs to ensure their research programs remain responsive to changing industry needs.

Here are six distinct priority areas that the strategy is firmly anchored on which contribute to the achievement of the AU Vision.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Shannin Metatawabin ICD.Dâ€™s Post Shannin Metatawabin ICD.D CEO at National Aboriginal Capital Corporation Association (NACCA) 2y Report this post Thank you Jeffery for making the introduction s and connecting with the Indigenous leaders.   having CPPi as partner is important to the work of making an impact. #indigenousprosperity #indigenousnationbuilder #indigenomics CPP Investments | Investissements RPC 322,835 followers 2y We recently held our first-ever Indigenous Business Forum in Toronto, strengthening our relationships with some of Canadaâ€™s leading Indigenous financial organizations and gaining a deeper understanding of their unique capabilities.

Our President and CEO, John Graham ,Â spoke about our own investments, such as B.C.-based Premium Brands Holdings Corporation , which was part of "the single largest investment in the seafood industry by any Indigenous group in Canada" through its acquisition of Clearwater Seafoods LP in partnership with a coalition of Mi'kmaw First Nations.

â€œWe seek the best possible investment opportunities â€“ wherever they may be,â€ Graham says.

Thank you to the First Nations Major Projects Coalition , the First Nations Financial Management Board , the First Nations Finance Authority , NACCA , the Indigenous Growth Fund , the Alberta Indigenous Opportunities Corporation , Longhouse Capital Partners and the Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business for sharing your perspectives and insights. 

---

Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y Edited Report this post The Global Centre of Indigenomics(GCOI) is proud to announce a powerful collaboration with MOVE37XR ! 

A partnership set to redefine the landscape of innovation and economic empowerment for Indigenous communities globally.
MOVE37XR, a leader in advanced technologies, is bringing its expertise to the Global Centre of Indigenomics, fostering innovation, sustainability, and Indigenous economic growth. 

Together, we aim to create an inclusive and thriving ecosystem that embraces the rich tapestry of Indigenous knowledge and the limitless possibilities of technological advancement.

This collaboration is a commitment to shaping a future where Indigenous communities lead in the realms of technology, economics, and sustainability. We believe that by merging tradition with innovation, we can unlock unprecedented opportunities and drive positive change on a global scale.

Subscribe to our newsletter for updates as we unite to celebrate diversity, foster collaboration, and shape a world where Indigenomics and technology converge for the advancement of all. https://lnkd.in/gCDfKpBA #Indigenomics #Move37XR #Tech #Indigenouseconomy #GlobalPartnership #Innovation #Sustainability 32 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Jenn McRae Community Wealth Strategist 1y Report this comment Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D have you seen the Social Cogs model yet? Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 3mo Report this post Congratulations to our Global Center of Indigenomics board member on earning her Doctorate! Big congratulations Dr. Alisha Murphy!!  you rock! Dr. Alisha L. Murphy Indigenomics 3mo Edited ğŸ“ Historic Milestone ğŸ“

Last Friday, I had the incredible honor of earning my Doctorate of Economic Development from New Mexico State University, becoming the first Native American to receive this degree.

This journey has been one of perseverance, passion, and purpose. My doctoral work focused on Navajo entrepreneurship and economic developmentâ€”critical areas that guide my efforts to create sustainable growth and opportunities for the Navajo Nation and other Indigenous communities.

I am deeply grateful for the support of my family, mentors. I am also grateful for my colleagues, and the organizations that have championed the work toward strengthening tribal economic development along the way.

As I look to the future, I am inspired to continue advancing tribal economic development, advocating for data sovereignty, and creating pathways that uplift our communities.

Thank you to everyone who has supported me on this journeyâ€”this is just the beginning! #Doctorate #EconomicDevelopment #NavajoNation #IndigenousLeadership #DataSovereignty #EducationForChange #Indigenomics 83 5 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Ron Norman Director of Pacific Rim Chiropractic Inc. The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences has awarded this year's Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel to ğƒğšğ«ğ¨ğ§ ğ€ğœğğ¦ğ¨ğ ğ¥ğ®, ğ’ğ¢ğ¦ğ¨ğ§ ğ‰ğ¨ğ¡ğ§ğ¬ğ¨ğ§, ğšğ§ğ ğ‰ğšğ¦ğğ¬ ğ€. ğ‘ğ¨ğ›ğ¢ğ§ğ¬ğ¨ğ§ for their groundbreaking research on how societal institutions shape a nation's prosperity.
ğŸŒ Their work underscores a fundamental truth: inclusive institutionsâ€”those that serve the broader population rather than the interests of a select fewâ€”are crucial for sustained economic growth and development. Their research helps explain why some countries prosper while others struggle, despite similar natural resources or historical circumstances.

When European colonization reshaped much of the world, the type of institutions introduced played a pivotal role in determining future prosperity. Nations with inclusive political and economic systems often experienced long-term success, while those with extractive institutionsâ€”designed to benefit elites at the expense of the populationâ€”saw stagnation and decline.
The laureates also highlight why institutional reform is often difficult: those in power prefer short-term gains and control, while inclusive changes offer long-term benefits for society. In times of political unrest or revolution, however, the path to democracy and inclusive institutions becomes a possibility.

This research is critical in addressing one of our time's greatest challengesâ€”reducing global income inequality. Their findings provide essential insights into how better governance and institutional reforms can pave the way for more equitable, sustainable development.

Three immigrants to the U.S.â€”Daron Acemoglu (Turkey), Simon Johnson (UK), and James Robinson (UK)â€”have won the 2024 Nobel Prize in Economics for their groundbreaking research on how institutions shape a nation's prosperity.

ğŸ” Did you know?
Immigrants have been awarded 31% of U.S. Nobel Prizes in Economics, contributing transformative advancements in fields like medicine, physics, and chemistry. These achievements highlight the vital role immigrants play in driving innovation, expanding knowledge, and fostering growth in America.


Post Credit: Stuart Anderson, Forbes @forbes #NobelPrizeDay #ImmigrantAchievements #ImmigrationMatters #GuerreroLawFirm #NobelWinners #GuerreroImmigrationSolutions Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Paul Boucher Researcher at Synopia in international relations, history, geopolitics, and strategic intergovernmental governance / Former archaeologist in the Brazilian Amazon / Professor of international relations. 8mo Edited Report this post I am very proud to participate at the 2nd #TransatlanticSymposium on #SustainableDevelopment in #HigherEducation the  10 and 11 October 2024. After #MIT , the #HAW and the #ESSSR have chosen the #PXLUniversity in #Hasselt My article titled "Environmental destructions: a macroeconomic approach leaded by anthropology" will detail how modern macroeconomy is the resultant of a huge clash between geopolitical, strategical, psychological and social reasons. The upcoming multipolar world will be more than never the theater of states competition where exploring new lands is crucial for food, tools, energies, living places, factories, mines, transports, tourism, military or technical tests. Most of these aspects has direct and indirect impacts on natural areas. This predation-dependence duality defined by a permanent need for supplies of societies is not conductive for a sustainable economy. Until now, the context was torn by a certain opposition between fierce conservatism and an excessive quest for profit.

A closer look at the whole operatory chain from several examples can lead us to understand all the processes which lead countries, consumers and even native people to consent to destroy natural areas yet necessary for interspecies coevolution. This unviable situation can be solved by a better understanding of each mechanism often caused by a lack of global dialogue and diverging interests.

It is also a proposition for some diagnostics in line with the #UnitedNations #SDGs (Sustainable Development Goals) which can be applied to different scales (local, national and international). All indicate several solutions residing on symbiotic economy, innovation, salary guarantee, transdisciplinary dialogue, diplomacy, interconnection between areas and global cooperation between universities, compagnies, government and civil society. From there, future perspectives will emerge.

Thanks to all the team. #anthropology #science #intelligence #ecology #diplomacy #UNO #economic #nature #sustainebleeconomy #strategy #innovation #technology #geopolitics 15 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Vibhu Jain, PhD Portfolio Leader | Innovation | Marketing | Strategy with focus on AI in Drug Discovery, Synthesis Solutions in Chemistry and Materials Science 5mo Edited Report this post ğŸ‰ Congratulations to the 2024 Nobel Prize Winners in Economic Sciences! ğŸ‰

Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James A. Robinson have been awarded the 2024 Nobel Prize in Economics for their pioneering work on how political and economic institutions shape national prosperity. They have shown how inclusive institutions, such as democratic governance and free markets, promote long-term economic growth by providing access to opportunities for all. Conversely, extractive institutions, which are designed to benefit a small elite (often seen in dictatorships or monopolistic economies), hinder development by limiting the majorityâ€™s access to resources.

Their influential book, Why Nations Fail, provides examples such as:

	â€¢	North vs. South Korea: Despite having the same cultural and historical roots, North Koreaâ€™s extractive institutions have led to poverty, while South Koreaâ€™s inclusive institutions have driven economic success.

	â€¢	Colonial Latin America vs. Colonial North America: The Spanish colonizers implemented extractive systems in Latin America, focusing on resource extraction, whereas settlers in North America established more inclusive institutions, fostering long-term prosperity.

This research explains why some countries thrive and others lag behind, offering vital insights into reducing global inequality. #NobelPrize #Economics #WealthInequality #InstitutionalEconomics #InclusiveGrowth #GlobalDevelopment #DaronAcemoglu #SimonJohnson #JamesRobinson Sources: NobelPrize.org , Business Insider 27 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Kadir Tas CEO @ KTMC AGENCY | Finance Management 5mo Edited Report this post Congratulations to Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James Robinson on winning the 2024 The Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences! Your groundbreaking work on the role of #institutions in #economicgrowth has reshaped our understanding of #globaldevelopment . This recognition is truly well-deserved!

U.S.-based economists Daron Acemoglu (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), Simon Johnson (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), and James Robinson (University of Chicago) have been awarded the 2024 Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences. Their prize-winning work, â€œInstitutions as the Fundamental Cause of Long-Run Growth,â€ explores how economic and political institutions shape the development and #prosperity of nations. They argue that inclusive institutions, which allow broad participation in economic and political life, lead to sustained economic growth. In contrast, extractive institutions, which concentrate power and #wealth , hinder development and perpetuate #inequality . This research has had a profound impact on how we understand global disparities in wealth and development. â€¦more Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in The Zambakari Advisory, L.L.C. 112 followers 5mo Report this post The 2024 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded to Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James Robinson for their groundbreaking research on the role of institutions in shaping economic prosperity. Their work, particularly focusing on the colonial past, demonstrates how the establishment of inclusive institutionsâ€”protecting property rights and allowing for broad economic participationâ€”leads to long-term prosperity. In contrast, countries with extractive institutions, designed to enrich elites at the expense of the broader population, experience short-term gains but long-term stagnation. 

Their research, which highlights the institutional roots of inequality, has influenced economic and political thought worldwide. While their findings favor democratic institutions for sustainable growth, they also acknowledge that authoritarian regimes can achieve short-term economic success, though at the cost of instability and innovation. Their work is particularly impactful in understanding global inequality and the persistence of economic gaps between nations, with a focus on how colonial history shapes modern economies. https://lnkd.in/gjeNZrwH #EconomicNobel #InstitutionalEconomics #GlobalInequality Three Receive Nobel in Economics for Research on Global Inequality https://www.nytimes.com Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in CNR-IRISS Istituto di Ricerca su Innovazione e Servizi per lo Sviluppo 1,525 followers 4mo Edited Report this post ğŸ“ŒStarting tomorrow the Conference "The Future of Hope: an interdisciplinary dialogue"
ğŸ”Over 40 professors and researchers from diverse fields will take part in the Conference to share the findings of their work. Topics to be explored include social innovation, history, theology, medicine, ICT, spatial planning, and artificial intelligence - each framing the theme of hope (understood as vision, orientation, and propensity) within its social, technical, and economic implications.

ğŸ‘‰ Giuseppe Pace , senior researcher at #Cnr_Iriss ,Â will take part in the Conference focusing on #sustainability and #culturaltransition . He will present key outcomes from two international projects: the Marie Curie-funded #TREND project and the Underground4Value COST Action. Additionally, today he participated in the closed-door meeting â€œVisions of Hope for Europe and beyondâ€ within the Roundtable on Sustainability and visions of Future.

Thanks to Renata Salvarani and Guido Traversa from UER - UniversitÃ  Europea di Roma for providing such a great opportunity for interdisciplinary debate and discussion between researchers and policy makers to reflect on how #hope can drive contemporary #challenges and help define visions and solutions for a more #sustainable and #inclusivefuture . 

Find out more ğŸ‘‰ https://lnkd.in/dMQ7TCRM Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche CNR DSU - Dipartimento Scienze Umane e Sociali, Patrimonio Culturale #Cnr_Iriss UER - UniversitÃ  Europea di Roma Centro di Formazione Integrale COMECE - The Catholic Church in the EU 3 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Karrie Brown (she/her) Workforce Decoder: Seeing Connections + Creating Solutions as a Business Solutions Manager at West Michigan Works! 5mo Report this post I didn't win the Nobel Prize for Economics this year. I wasn't even in the running, but it is something I follow closely (I know, I am a nerd). 

The winners Daron Acemoglu, Simon Johnson, and James A. Robinson, explored how societal institutions shape prosperity. Their research shines a light on why nations face such different economic realities based on historical and systemic influences. It is worth reading.

While I didn't win, I am enormously proud to be part of the industry sector engagement efforts in my region. Working alongside talented individuals to address systemic workforce issues and tackle inequalities at a local level is an honor. 

By focusing on the collaboration between industries, educators, and workforce development teams, weâ€™re helping to create a more equitable futureâ€”one where everyone has the chance to prosper.

Building better systems, better institutions, and creating lasting change is rewarding in ways I cannot explain. It is future focused and I know it is making a difference. #SectorStrategies #WorkforceDevelopment #EconomicEquity #CommunityImpact #Proud https://lnkd.in/gTGaXgA3 The Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 2024 nobelprize.org 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Qamar Yaseen Makki Founder of Eagle Eyes World | FMCG Sales Leader | Business & Market Growth Strategist | Sales & Leadership Insights 5mo Edited Report this post Nobel Laureates Acemoglu, Johnson, and Robinson: Unveiling the Power of Institutions in National Prosperity

Key Findings:

1. Institutions Drive Wealth: Economic and political systems are key to a nation's prosperity.

2. Colonial Legacy: European colonization left lasting impacts through the types of institutions introduced.

3. Enduring Influence: Institutions persist over time, shaping long-term development.

4. Path to Change: Theoretical tools explain how institutions evolve and how reforms can promote growth.

Hedley Award for Excellence in Social and Environmental Responsibility for its holistic approach to developing a three-year heavy equipment operator program at this years AME Roundup. 

This was an incredible team effort with many partners to make it happen.  The program includes a drivers license program, technical skill development and leadership competencies. It is awesome to watch the program grow and positively impact so many Tahltan members.

The HEO program is a great example that resource projects and Indigenous communities can follow to assist members in gaining mobility, employable skills and meaningful career paths.

AfriMine is thrilled to announce a groundbreaking partnership with iSE (InnovaciÃ³n en Sistemas EnergÃ©ticos) in South America! This collaboration underscores our commitment to fostering growth, innovation, and professional development in the global mining community.

Hereâ€™s what this partnership entails:
1ï¸âƒ£ Training Programs: Development and delivery of specialized training courses for AfriMine members to enhance skills and knowledge.
