4ï¸âƒ£ Regional Expansion: Promotion of educational programs across Africa and neighboring regions to empower future leaders.

Together, AfriMine and iSE are paving the way for a more interconnected, informed, and innovative mining sector. ğŸŒŸ #WorldMiningDay #AfriMine #iSE #MiningInnovation #KnowledgeExchange #Networking 39 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Above the Horizon Wellness 19 followers 9mo Report this post Pat Blair 's appreciation for his family's mining heritage shines as he holds his grandfather's pickaxeâ€”a symbol of the industry's evolution.

His commitment to passing down stories and values to the next generation is evident, reflecting on the strides made in mining.

During Pat's assessment, his outstanding leadership growth stood out. Prioritizing safety and advocating for workers' rights, both on and off the job, exemplifies his dedication.

We extend our heartfelt gratitude to Pat for his efforts in achieving certification. Your contributions are invaluable to Mining Industry Human Resources Council (MiHR) and Centre of Training Excellence in Mining (CTEM) It was a privilege to assess Pat for his Surface Miner Certification. Wishing him continued success in all his future endeavours.

â€œMining to me is a journey back to my roots. Growing up with parents who were miners instilled in me a curiosity about the industry from an early age. Following this path was a natural inclination, and I'm grateful I did.
In this journey, I've delved deeper into the world of rocks and minerals than I ever imagined. I've forged friendships that I know will endure a lifetime. Witnessing mentorship within the crews, regardless of age differences, has been truly inspiring. It's a testament to the power of training and the willingness to learn from one another.
I firmly believe that collective involvement in training and mentorship can transform the mining industry into a safer and more fulfilling environment for all. Being certified isn't just a badge of achievement; it's a reminder of the expertise I've gained and the responsibility I carry as a professional in my field.â€

These past two years have been an incredible ride filled with challenges, victories, and invaluable lessons. Each hurdle I faced and triumph I celebrated has played a crucial role in shaping the person I am today. From navigating the complexities of mining to collaborating with amazing teams, every experience has been a cherished lesson in resilience, adaptability, and continuous learning.

I am thankful to SROL ( Thor Explorations Ltd ) for providing me with opportunities for growth and development. Every day with SROL has been a chance to push my boundaries, embrace new challenges, and grow both personally and professionally.

None of this would have been possible without the unwavering support of mentors, managers, and colleagues who have been there to guide and inspire me every step of the way. I am profoundly grateful to everyone who believed in me and helped me soar to new heights.

Looking forward, I'm brimming with excitement for the adventures that lie ahead. Each day, I'm driven to make a meaningful impact in the mining industry and contribute to a more sustainable and resilient future for generations to come. There's still so much to learn, explore, and achieve, and I can't wait to dive in headfirst.

Mr. Pete recently completed law school at Peter A. Allard School of Law at UBC, where he was particularly interested in First Nations legal traditions, business organizations, taxation and economic development. He is also a social media manager for Alpine Legal Services and he sits on the Chilliwack Cultural Centre's Board of Directors.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y Edited Report this post Indigenomics is Indigenous economic intelligence in motion. Â 
Â 
It is the practice of bringing an Indigenous perspective into economic and social development. It works to connect community economic development practices and principles for building an inclusive local economy.Â 
Â 
Next week 31 leaders are joining the Indigenomics Institute team in Winnipeg to share how they activate Indigenomics as leaders in procurement, investment, equity ownership, trusts, entrepreneurship, finance and technology.Â 
Â 
Indigenomics SHE starts Monday. The event brought together 20 visionary leaders from academia, business, civil society, government, and indigenous communities to advance global solutions that can help truly value nature in our economy.
Â 
While there has been significant progress in environmental-economic accounting over the past two decades, many approaches still face challenges in gaining traction due to socio-economic and political barriers. These challenges hinder widespread adoption of strategies that place nature on an equal footing with financial capital.
Â 
In this context, the convening aimed to challenge traditional growth paradigms, propose a bold vision for mainstreaming natural capital in decision-making, and identify actionable solutions for policy, data, and finance.
Â 
Swapanâ€™s involvement in this critical dialogue reinforces IORAâ€™s commitment to driving impactful change and innovation in the pursuit of a world where economic development goes hand-in-hand with environmental stewardship.
Â 
The event was a powerful reminder that while we have made significant strides, thereâ€™s still much to be done to ensure that the value of our natural resources is truly reflected in economic decisions. #NaturalCapital #Sustainability #Leadership #Innovation #TeamIORA 39 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in SORA 314 followers 4mo Report this post ğŸ™ï¸ On Stage Now!

Title: Jen Newsted on LinkedIn: #indigenomics #reconciliation #telus
Description: Dec 1, 2023  Â·  Jen, thank you for being real. I am grateful for our conversations and the tough but extremely helpful questions you have asked me this yearÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #reconciliation #telus | Jen Newsted Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Jen Newstedâ€™s Post Jen Newsted Activating Social Impact & Reconciliation Commitments | Independent Contractor | Settler Disrupting The Status Quo 1y Edited Report this post This year I was gifted ample connection to many fantastic humans who walked alongside the Indigenomics Institute to advance #Indigenomics A trio of fantastic humans that I want to shine my gratitude on are Tashia Kootenayoo, Stephanie Han and Jen Howton from TELUS . It has been a delight to work with these three, to engage in truthful and curious conversations, and have their support in advancing economic reconciliation. Much gratitude to each of you for how you show up!

Last night I read TELUS' recently released 2023 Indigenous Reconciliation and Connectivity Report and I would encourage folks to do the same. https://lnkd.in/g3Yuk7xm I encourage folks to read it for three reasons. The first reason is we, non-Indigenous folks, are grossly overdue on our collective duty to be responding to truth and reconciliation. The second reason is because I have experience both working in telecommunications and leading the Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business Progressive Aboriginal Relations program and I know just how much persistent, intentional effort is required to prioritize reconciliation and shift behaviours inside both giant and small working environments as the barriers to allow change to transpire can and do run deep within each of us as individuals, as a collective and in the colonial system we exist within. 

The third reason is when I read this report I can see that TELUS is both acknowledging they have learning to do AND that they are implementing their learnings from the Indigenous voices they are learning from. This is what reconciliation looks like my friends. 

It looks like Johnny Kelto III being the first voice we hear from followed by acknowledgments of the obligation and responsibility that we non-Indigenous folks/businesses have to ensure there is no longer misappropriation of Indigenous art/artists. 

It looks like bringing our responsibility to be responding to TRC Call to Action 92 to life through prioritized actions that are progressing, not just words in polished corporate copy on websites. 

Give the Indigenous Reconciliation and Connectivity Report a read and invite curiosity in to ask where reconciliation is at with your company/business/self and what will your company/business/self start shifting to ensure you are progressing in persistent, intentional reconcili-ACTION?

No matter how big or small our places of work are reconciliation is required, and it is not difficult. The difficulty, is a barrier that stems from the discomfort of being responsible to acknowledge difficult truths. We must have truth centered in order for reconciliation to happen. So let's get truthful. #Reconciliation #TELUS 27 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Stephanie Han Senior Program Manager at TELUS 1y Report this comment It's a privilege to be on this journey with you, Jen! Like Reply 1Â Reaction Jen Howton Senior Strategy Manager - Reconciliation Strategy @ TELUS 1y Report this comment Jen, thank you for being real. I am grateful for our conversations and the tough but extremely helpful questions you have asked me this year about our work. I appreciate you and I recognize the hard work you are doing both professionally and personally. You are a rock star! Like Reply 1Â Reaction 2Â Reactions Nathan Grandjambe, MBA Collaborating in resurgent Indigenous sovereignty and prosperity, and more sustainable and equitable relations for all 1y Report this comment hay hay, thank you for inviting so many great people onto your journey of reconciliation and connection. It is a pleasure and honour to count you among my relations. All crown lands have not been subject to any competent or specific legislation modifying or extinguishing our lands and resources. That is the basis for unceded lands and resource! Imagine a space where creativity, purpose, and  leadership come together to design pathways for economic reconciliation. This interactive session brings together organizations and businesses to develop reconciliation innovation using LEGO as a tool for collaborative economic design.

The Indigenomics LEGO DESIGN Session is an opportunity to collaborate, learn, and innovate in a hands-on experience that strengthens Indigenous economic growth and design. Together, weâ€™ll transform ideas into models for Reconciliation Action Planningâ€”brick by brick.

Like Reply 2Â Reactions 3Â Reactions See more comments To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Kristy Barnaby, MHA CEO/Founder of Barnaby & Associates, a technical advisory and consulting firm specializing in Procurement [Policies, Processes, Standards, Indigenous Participation Plans] and Quality Management Systems. 8mo Edited Report this post In our work, we see this all too often. Not only does it harm the Indigenous individual being exploited, used, and appropriated solely for their Indigenous identity but it also puts projects at great risk. When major projects are at great risk, the investments made with intentions to reach communities are not realized, and the outcomes or impacts are not achieved. This means exacerbated socioeconomic inequities of Indigenous communities. This behaviour dictates how [or if] these project investments have true impact on the Canadian economy. There's significant negative economic impact of tokenism, appropriation, and exploitation of Indigenous Identity- to the country. It's not just an 'Indigenous problem'. 

Want to begin to understand the topic more? Start with Len Pierre â€™s FREE webinar! There are current studies examining this behaviour and its technical implications. My idea of a 21st-century magazine consists of three pillars:

1. The Magazine itself, featuring original thoughts on the most interesting stories of our time.

2. Programs that study particular topics over a long period to produce valuable insights.

3. Live Events that engage people directly and invite them to "join the discussion."

So whether you want to read a definitive Chronicle of human civilization, explore the 24 World Districts that make up around 95% of our population, or discover forgotten cinematic masterpieces curated by a New Yorker playwright, SocietyReview.org will be your first address. Title: Jen Newsted's Post - LinkedIn
Description: Jun 9, 2023  Â·  #Reconciliation #IndigenousHistoryMonth #Indigenomics Â· View organization page for Indigenomics, graphic Â· Indigenomics. 4,665 followers. 1yÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
#reconciliation #indigenoushistorymonth #indigenomics | Jen Newsted Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Jen Newstedâ€™s Post Jen Newsted Activating Social Impact & Reconciliation Commitments | Independent Contractor | Settler Disrupting The Status Quo 1y Report this post I had a conversation with a white woman earlier this year about reconciliation and they had shared that if they can't get it right their organization wasn't going to go anywhere near it.

This perspective is one that many individuals and businesses have across the country, this isn't new news.

It is a problematic perspective because it continues to uphold racism and systems of oppression. 

We are each, individually, and collectively, responsible to be righting relations and actively responding to Truth and Reconciliation Call to Action 92. 

It is phenomenally straightforward what we are meant to do, as example:
Listen to Indigenous voices.
Learn from Indigenous voices.
Invest in Indigenous voices.
Support Indigenous voices.
Be led by Indigenous voices.
Believe Indigenous voices.

When I think about folks who say they don't want to get it wrong so they aren't going to do anything, I wonder why they are so comfortable to share their very obvious tells that they haven't taken any of the above straightforward steps, that they aren't interested in taking a look within, and they have no concern about the harms they continue to uphold.

If you just don't know where to start, here is a suggestion, get in the room where Indigenous folks are leading and sharing. 

There is an incredible opportunity in Toronto this November and every sector I have been part of advertising, healthcare, tech, non-profit, tv and film, telecommunications absolutely have no reason to not be in this room. 

Let's get in this room and start shifting our individual and collective accountability into impactful actions that right relations and ensure prosperity for those whose lands we keep saying we live, work and play on.

Let's show up beyond our continued copy and paste acknowledgements of being on stolen land and step into dismantling the barriers we know exist and that we are benefitting from. #Reconciliation #IndigenousHistoryMonth #Indigenomics Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1y Edited The Indigenomics Institute welcomes Raylene Whitford and Frank Busch as conference emcees for Indigenomics on BAY STREET- the 100 billion dollar Indigenous economy conference, taking place November 21 - 23, 2023 in the City of Toronto !

Indigenomics on BAY STREET will be the largest Indigenous economy focused coming together of leadership across the corporate / private sector, governments and Indigenous business to bring focus, meaning and visibility to the emerging 100 billion dollar Indigenous economy and situating that within growing Indigenous economic influence!

Conference delegates joining from outside of Toronto can enjoy the Indigenomics conference rate for their stay at The Westin Harbour Castle, Toronto !

Early bird registration ends June 30, register today to save! https://lnkd.in/evegFEqn #Indigenomics #TorontoEvents #EconomicDevelopment #EconomicReconciliation #CANECON #EconomicGrowth 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in 2,136 followers 656 Posts 1 Article View Profile Follow More from this author An invitation: support & celebrate empowerment of women in Vancouver. I start and grow organizations, create conversations and channel ideas that each serve a more just, joyful and connected world. 9mo Report this post A mindset that restores our relationship to earth, and each other, as a deep â€œamongnessâ€ is more than a triple bottom line. Itâ€™s a way of #livingfromoneness .

Weâ€™re all in this earthship together - you do everything right and your country or economy or the climate goes sideways, there arenâ€™t exemptions. Maybe you protect your people in the short run, but anything beyond crisis response weâ€™re all together now, and that calls for new economies and governance models. 

A regenerative mindset is beyond sustainable- itâ€™s deeply for life. Bridget McKenzie 9mo I've updated my new paper with this graphic. 
This paper aims to reframe and state the case for the roles of Culture in response to the Earth crisis, to generate new areas for investment and evidence-gathering. 

I've defined some key terms, set out how the Earth crisis is a â€˜culture crisisâ€™, and identified the barriers to an effective Cultural response.

I then suggest some new thematic areas of Cultural practice. 

How can Culture be an agent for a shift to a Regenerative culture and respond to the emergency in ways that aim for Transformative Adaptation and Resilience?

Have a read and let me know what you think. https://lnkd.in/eyrwNqDU 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Andrea Deverell Exploring Sustainable and Regenerative Futures in Higher Education 9mo Report this post This is an excellent synthesis of the interconnected nature of the challenges we face and actionable frames to move forward. I've defined some key terms, set out how the Earth crisis is a â€˜culture crisisâ€™, and identified the barriers to an effective Cultural response.

I then suggest some new thematic areas of Cultural practice. 

How can Culture be an agent for a shift to a Regenerative culture and respond to the emergency in ways that aim for Transformative Adaptation and Resilience?

WATCH; Anthony Viljoen , CEO, explain how the new ownership structure will accelerate development of its key assets in Namibia. 

Watch â–¶ï¸ https://lnkd.in/e3gURgDS Andrada Mining Limitedâ€¯(AIM: ATM, OTCQB: ATMTF), the technology-metals producer with mining and exploration assets in Namibia,â€¯is seeking to increase the ownership of its main operating subsidiary (â€œUTMCâ€) from 85% to 100%, through the acquisition of the 15% interest currently held by the Small Miners of Uis ("SMU"). 

Total consideration is to be satisfied through the issue of Â£0.5m of ordinary shares in Andrada, Â£0.78m in cash over 240 monthly instalments and the transfer of the Companyâ€™s 85% interest in license ML129, which is now non-core to Andrada, but regarded as a valuable opportunity for SMU to drive economic growth across the Erongo region in Namibia.  

Following completion of this transaction, Andrada will own 100% of UTMC, ensuring fair economic exposure to the development of the licenses in Namibia for all parties, further streamline operations for accelerated value creation and enable UTMC to apply for specific project financing solutions. 

Anthony Viljoen, Chief Executive Officer of Andradaâ€¯explains: 
- Why the restructuring process took so long 
- How the restructuring will help attract strategic partners to Andradaâ€™s lithium assets 
- Why the lithium assets may soonâ€¯account for approximately 70% of the companyâ€™s overall revenues 
â€¯- How Andrada has become aâ€¯triple asset developer, producer and cashflow generator 
- Why the companyâ€™s tin assets are so valuable and why the  price rally in the metal will continue 
- The multiple revenue streams materialising from Andradaâ€™s one mining operation strategyâ€¯ 

Viljoen commented; â€œWe don't see this as a departure of our relationship with the SMU. In fact, if anything, it's strengthened our ties with them. It's given the SMU a renewed focus in terms of assisting us with our corporate social responsibilities and ensuring that our success on UIS is carried over to our other assets because a key part of this restructure is making sure that our entire portfolio realizes value.â€â€¯ 

Reasons to addâ€¯ATMâ€¯to your watchlist: 
- Andrada is a multi-asset, multi-commodity, multi-decade opportunity on multiple assets 
- Globally significant and JORC-compliant mineral resource estimate of 138 million tonnes 
- Open-pit mining, tin oxide coarse crushing, only being 230km from a port means low production costs and competitive logistics prices 
- Resource contains high purity lithium constituting of 0,73% at 1,45 million tonnes of lithium carbonate equivalent 
- Andradaâ€™s cash flow allows the company to develop its assets organically 
- The partnership with theâ€¯Bank ofâ€¯Windhoekâ€¯means the company doesnâ€™t have to solely rely on dilutive equity funding for development capital berenberg Tavistock Hannam & Partners #ATM #Andrada #Mining #Tin #Lithium #Namibia â€¦more Andrada Mining acquisition elevates the miner toâ€¯emerging mid-tier status https://www.youtube.com/ 18 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in SearchSpace AI 243 followers 7mo Report this post Gold Fields is set to acquire Osisko Mining in a massive $2.16 billion all-cash dealğŸ’°

Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y What we set out to do with Indigenomics SHE was to amplify the voices of what are our experiences as Indigenous women in business- to create a space of a strengths based narrative of really how are we killing it â€“ thereâ€™s difficulties, thereâ€™s challenges, there's so much that weâ€™ve overcome, andÂ to come together to support each other, to build a network and be able to advance this perspective. What we are doing is essential. Essential for our families. Essential for our communities. Essential for our futures. â€œ Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D , opening remarks Indigenomics SHE. Â

Title: Audra Young's Post - LinkedIn
Description: Feb 29, 2024  Â·  Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author xÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #10towatch #treaty4territory #mnsregion3 #cityofregina | Audra Young Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Audra Youngâ€™s Post Audra Young Director Indigenous Relations and Community Development City of Regina 1y Report this post Thank you Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D for this acknowledgement. The City of Regina is early on the pathway of reconciliation, we have much work to do. We are honored to have been entrusted to do this work with the guidance and direction of the Indigneous Procurement Advisory Committee. #INDIGENOMICS #10TOWATCH #Treaty4Territory #MNSRegion3 #CityofRegina Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y â€œReginaâ€™s Indigenous Procurement Policy is a commitment to creating a thriving environment where Indigenous entrepreneurship can flourish,â€ shares Audra Young , Director of Indigenous Relations.

Shining a spotlight on The City of Regina , who is recognized as a distinguished recipient on the 2023 Indigenomics #10TOWATCH List and commended for their efforts to build economic reconciliation, inclusion and design business relationships to support the growth of the Indigenous economy, at the Indigenomics BAY STREET Conference.

The City of Regina is demonstrating its commitment to reconciliation through their Indigenous Procurement Policy. (IPP) 

The municipality has outlined a minimum goal of achieving 20 percent engagement for Indigenous procurement. This is a major step along the journey to economic reconciliation as a municipality and a clear step forward for economic reconciliation. 

This is Indigenomics in ACTION! Title: Angela DeMontigny on LinkedIn
Description: Mar 31, 2022  Â·  #economicreconciliation #indigenouswomenentrepreneurs #indigenomics ... #economicreconciliation #indigenouswomenentrepreneurs #indigenomicsÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
#economicreconciliation #indigenouswomenentrepreneurs #indigenomicsâ€¦ | Angela DeMontigny Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Angela DeMontignyâ€™s Post Angela DeMontigny Designer, Artist, Visionary, Pioneer, Entrepreneur, Mentor ~ Indigenous Fashion, Wellness & Public Art 2y Report this post Thank you Jen Newsted for amplifying and supporting Indigenous women entrepreneurs! #economicreconciliation #indigenouswomenentrepreneurs #indigenomics #decolonizedbusiness #economicinclusion #indigenouswellness #indigenousbusiness Jen Newsted Activating Social Impact & Reconciliation Commitments | Independent Contractor | Settler Disrupting The Status Quo 2y Economic reconciliation was the topic that MÃ©tis entrepreneur Vanessa Lesperance, MA, GDBA founder of Mindful Managers, a space that is devoted to workplace spirituality, increasing employee well-being and decolonizing business, shared about in a recent learning circle.

Vanessa is also the lead for the Lift Circle at Indigenous Lift Collective who are co-creating the conditions for Indigenous women entrepreneurs to thrive.

In our learning circle Vanessa offered two definitions of economic reconciliation:

â€œEconomic reconciliation is a form of reconciliation in action. It is a commitment by all stakeholders involved to create meaningful paths of self-determination, relationships and equitable partnerships.â€ - Chief Leanne Joe

â€œEconomic reconciliation is the space between the lived realities of Indigenous Peoples, the need to build understanding of the important Indigenous relationship, and the requirement for progressive actions for economic inclusion.â€ - Carol Anne Hilton

Last week Rexall Pharmacy Group ULC launched an Indigenous Wellness end aisle pilot in 10 locations across the country.Â 

Three brands owned and led by Mohawk, Cree and MÃ©tisÂ women entrepreneurs. Here is what they had to say about this pilot:

"This opportunity is Reconciliation in action. When you lift up female-led, Indigenous brands, you lift the entire Indigenous community.â€ April Mitchell-Boudreau founder Lofttan.

This wonderful partnership and unprecedented pilot program to support and promote Indigenous, women-owned businesses and brands is what the Indigenous community and this country needs. Angela DeMontigny founder Lodge Soy Candles.

â€œAs a descendent of a residential school survivor, I am appreciative that Rexall is honouring the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canadaâ€™s Calls to Action. kinanÃ¢skomitin (thank you, I am grateful to you).â€ Carrie Armstrong founder Mother Earth Essentials.

As individuals and as businesses we can each activate our economic reconciliation. Hire Indigenous leaders like Vanessa for learning circles. Purchase products from Indigenous owned businesses like Lofttan, Lodge Soy Candles, Mother Earth Essentials. Ask the businesses you support to start carrying Indigenous brands. #Reconciliation https://lnkd.in/g_ZZybPx 26 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in 5,107 followers 1,645 Posts 9 Articles View Profile Connect More from this author Distinguished designer-in-residence Angela DeMontigny mentors students in the School of Fashion on creating ready-to-wear fashion that tells a story Angela DeMontigny 6y International Press Release World Indigenous Fashion WeekÂ® Angela DeMontigny 8y Hamilton's James St. N. is decorating for the HOLIDAYS! Title: Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation | Anthony Viel
Description: Sep 29, 2022  Â·  Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author xÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation | Deloitte Canada | Anthony Viel Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Anthony Vielâ€™s Post Anthony Viel Chief Executive Officer at Deloitte Canada 2y Report this post In 2020, the Canadian government announced their intention to acknowledge the hardships and injustices #Indigenous communities have faced at the hands of former Canadian leaders. A Truth and Reconciliation Day was announced, and tomorrow we commemorate the second annual recognition of the ongoing need for reconciliation in this country.
Â 
When it comes to #reconciliation , making long-term progress demands that our actions be grounded in accountability and transparency. Deloitte 's Reconciliation Action Plan year-two update report: Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation, shares some of the ongoing efforts we have made to fund Indigenous groups and their allies, adapt our systems, and provide resources for our employees to educate themselves about Indigenous culture. The road to reconciliation is long and, at times, challenging, but we continue to strive toward being better listeners and doing our part in contributing to reconciliation efforts. 
Â 
In honour of this important day, we have given our people tomorrow off in the hopes they will use this time to reflect and continue to educate themselves â€“ be it attending a workshop, reading a book from an Indigenous author, donating to a local Indigenous-run charity, or learning more about the rich culture and history of Indigenous peoples. On this day, and throughout the year, our primary focus must be to listen, learn, and do our part.Â We hope our actions will serve as inspiration for others to do the same. https://lnkd.in/gVcfsg7U Our progress on the shared path for reconciliation | Deloitte Canada www2.deloitte.com 257 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Ailyn Bayubo Sales And Marketing Specialist at LAC Group 2y Report this comment Thanks for posting Like Reply 1Â Reaction 2Â Reactions Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. I like this piece with insights from David Saunders of Briter Bridges

While commercial funding has declined, non-commercial and semi-commercial investors are stepping up to support innovative solutions. This shift towards smaller deals and a focus on early-stage ventures is shaping the future of #agritech in #Africa . 

Gender diversity is crucial for a thriving agritech ecosystem. While there's been an increase in mixed-gender founding teams, all-women-founded teams still face significant challenges. According to Saunders, mixed-gender founding teams saw their share of funding increase from 7% in 2023 to 15% currently. However, all-women-founded teams still account for only 2% of total funding. 

Saunders believes the agritech funding bubble has deflated but can still be sustained. While non-commercial support is crucial, continued commercial interest is needed to prevent further decline. Research has found that if the gap in opportunities for Indigenous communities was closed, it would result in a boost of more thanÂ $30 billionÂ toÂ Canada'sÂ GDP.Â

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Indigenous economy could hit $100B Report this article Jessy Bains Jessy Bains Public relations manager, Indeed Canada Published Nov 27, 2023 + Follow Indigenous business leaders believe their economy is on track to reach $100 billion a year within a few years, reports CBC News . Indigenomics Institute founder Carol Anne Hilton says the number serves as a motivational â€œmarkerâ€ to which Indigenous businesses can aspire. Bill Lomax, CEO of the First Nations Bank of Canada, says that lessons he learned in the U.S. can be used to reach the goal. They include getting governments and companies to increase their use of Indigenous suppliers, as well as expanding the community's presence in the gaming and cannabis industries. Editorsâ€™ Picks Lynne Groulx Member of Metis Nation Ontario, human rights defender, resiliency lodge builder, reconciliation believer. 1y Report this post Strategic partnerships with Indigenous-led businesses will create new jobs and opportunities. It also means there is a potential for Indigenous-led businesses to grow into a huge, multi-billion-dollar economy.

Whatâ€™s required is a mix of the right policies that Canada does not have right now. We need to ensure government procurement creates space for sourcing from Indigenous-led businesses. We also must see greater alliances between the business community and Indigenous-owned enterprises.

As weâ€™ve seen, Indigenous Women and Gender-Diverse+ Peoples are leading the way in creating new and exciting businesses that make a big impact in their local communities and create economic growth.
Supporting these small businesses with the right tools to grow creates hope.

As Indigenomics CEO Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D said:
â€œI feel very much that this is a powerful time to be alive, where Indigenous people are picking up business as a tool and using it as a stake in the ground to say we're still here." https://lnkd.in/g9TSHaQ7 What is 'Indigenomics'? We believe in equipping individuals with the skills, tools, and innovative tokenomics frameworks needed to lead and shape the technologies of the future, ensuring Indigenous voices are at the forefront of innovation.

Tokenomics represents an opportunity to align traditional Indigenous values, such as reciprocity, sustainability, and community governance, with technology. By leveraging blockchain and decentralized systems, Indigenous communities can create equitable economic models that prioritize long-term prosperity, self-determination, and resource stewardship.

Through our AI, blockchain, and tokenomics training, weâ€™re addressing historical gaps by providing meaningful pathways for growth, agency, and creativity. This initiative goes beyond education, itâ€™s about cultivating leaders who can bridge the gap between tradition and technology, driving progress while uplifting Indigenous values and principles.

Together, we are shaping and cultivating a future where Indigenous communities lead with confidence, vision, and impact.

If you are in Vancouver please take advantage of this opportunity to see This IS NOT a Ceremony. National Film Board of Canada Indigenomics 4,887 followers 1y Edited With 12 days left to register for the 5th annual Indigenomics by DESIGN event in Vancouver we are offering 20% off 4 ticket packages all week to celebrate the countdown to Indigenomics in ACTION!

The Indigenomics Institute welcomes Deborah B. , Justin Holness , Carol Anne Hilton, MBA , Paul Lacerte , Michelle Bryant-Gravelle , Michael Bonshor , Nathan Grandjambe , Derek Hansom , Mike Werstuik , Joanne Stone-Campbell, MBA , Jeanette (Jen) Turner , Will Harding, MBA , Sarah Best , Kevin Barlow , Bonnie Harvey, Lee Sinclair, Kathryn M. , Alison Tedford Seaweed , Christy Smith-Hadath , Delanie Bulldog, Jay Mearns , Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D , Danalee Baker , Dean Montgomery , Robin Chakrabarti , Mike Campol , Geena Jackson , Chad Rickaby , Darwin Douglas , Flavio Caron , June Anthony-Reeves , Sarah Hrycenko, Lauren Kelly , Leah Bartko , Marissa Nobauer , James Delorme , Lawrence Lewis , Eli Enns to the Indigenomics DESIGN stage! Plus a few more to be announced!

From emerging trends in the 100 Billion Indigenous economy to economic reconciliation action planning these speakers will share their knowledge and expertise on how to advance the 100 billion dollar Indigenous economy in technology, export, finance, human resources, real estate, economic development and more allowing conference attendees to garner the essential tools and knowledge needed to be active participants creating value in the modern economy!

The DESIGN conference will kick off with an Indigenous wine tasting reception Wednesday May 24th led by sommelier Diana Claxton ! This reception is complimentary for registered attendees and for those unable to join the 2-day conference tickets are $45 to attend this unique reception.

During the conference attendees will experience an immersive virtual reality film with Niitsitapi writer and director Ahnahktsipiitaa Colin Van Loon 's cinematic VR experience This Is Not A Ceremony! While also being able to activate economic reconciliation shopping the Indigenomics Market!

Indigenomics events serve to invite leadership, dialogue, and action in advancing the Indigenous economy. We invite you to join us and invite your community! Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Isobel Alice O'Connellâ€™s Post Isobel Alice O'Connell Head of Sustainability/ ESG Strategy & Impact :+20yrs Global Exp. in Stakeholder, Issue, Investor & NT Risk Management : Human Rights : Board Director : Named Global 50 Women SustainabilityX Magazine 9mo Edited Report this post Thank you Institute of Corporate Directors Vancouver Chapter and Deloitte Vancouver for hosting an informative member appreciation event on a rainy summer night. 

Thanks Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D for your fireside chat on how boards can recognise the need to set the stage on how to grow the story of Indigenous economic potential through #indigenomics and how companies can truly embrace #truth and #reconciliation . Indigenomics is a collective economic response to the legacy of the systemic exclusion of Indigenous peoples in Canadaâ€™s economic development. It is a platform for economic reconciliation on the balance sheet of Canada, and not being viewed as a liability.

Indigenous groups and communities have celebrated their culture and heritage on June 21 because the significance of summer solstice. National Indigenous Peopleâ€™s Day is also part of the month long Celebrate Canada program, which also includes Saint Jean-Baptistâ€™s Day (June 24), Multicultural Day (June 27) and Canada Day (July 1). 

A personal insight, I am starting to see the emerging Indigenous economy best described in the words of Canadaâ€™s greatest ice hockey player, Wayne Gretzky: â€œSkate to where the puck is going, not where it has been.â€ 25 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Michael De Bonis   HBA, CHRE, SHRM, CTI certified. CEO, Breakpoint Human Capital Management, Transition and Performance Coaching for Leaders. Award Winning Chief People + Integrations Officer for Interim or Fractional leadership. Board Member. Keynote Speaker. 9mo Report this post National Indigenous Peoples DayÂ is a day recognizing and celebrating the cultures and contributions of theÂ First Nations,Â Inuit, andÂ MÃ©tisÂ Indigenous peoples of Canada.

The day was first celebrated in 1996, after it was proclaimed that year by thenÂ Governor General of CanadaÂ RomÃ©o LeBlanc, to be celebrated annually on June 21.

To build respectful relationships, acknowledging the land is an important part of reconciliation. It honours the authentic history of North America, its original people and tells the story of the creation of this country that has historically been missing.

The indigenous people although they comprise only 6.2% of the world's population, safeguard 80% of the planet's biodiversity. Through diverse community-led actions â€“ such asÂ community-owned renewable energy projects, land-based education initiatives, cross-cultural climate conversations, language revitalization programs, and ceremonyÂ â€“ communities are reconnecting with their traditional knowledges, cultures, spiritualities, and lands.

From groundbreaking innovations to transformative leadership and partnerships, Indigenous peoples are paving the way for a brighter future. Itâ€™s time to amplify their voices and initiatives, foster employment opportunities, and strengthen collaborations.

Key opportunities:

âœ… Support Indigenous innovation: Invest in Indigenous-led startups and initiatives that drive sustainable growth and prosperity
âœ… Enhance employment: Create more opportunities for Indigenous employment, improve working conditions, and ensure fair representation in all sectors.
âœ… Build strong partnerships: Foster collaborations between Indigenous communities, businesses, and government to drive mutual growth and development.

Our new Future in Focus on National Indigenous Peoples Day features op-eds on these issues from: Patricia Baxter and stephen lindley , Co Chairs of Indigenous Works James Jenkins , Executive Director of Indigenous Clean Energy Kelly Lendsay , Marie Delorme, and Manley Alan Begay, Jr. for Luminary

Read their insights now: https://lnkd.in/ewr2R4mY #NationalIndigenousPeoplesDay #IndigenousInnovation #Leadership #Partnerships #InclusiveFuture #Canada #IndigenousEmployment #SustainableGrowth #CommunityCollaboration #FutureInFocus Future in Focus: National Indigenous Peoples Day - TheFutureEconomy.ca thefutureeconomy.ca 2 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Siddharth Raval Director of Revenue Generation 9mo Report this post Honoring the Contributions of First Nations to Canada's Social Fabric...

Today, I take a moment to express our deepest gratitude and respect for the First Nations communities and their invaluable contributions to the rich, diverse social fabric of Canada.

For thousands of years, First Nations peoples have inhabited and cared for the lands we now call Canada. Their profound knowledge, cultural practices, and spiritual traditions have not only shaped the environment but also the very essence of what it means to be Canadian.

Cultural Heritage: The vibrant art, music, dance, and storytelling traditions of First Nations enrich our cultural mosaic. From the intricate beadwork and carvings to the powerful drum circles and powwows, their creative expressions inspire and unite us.

Stewardship of the Land: First Nations have long been the stewards of the land, advocating for sustainable practices and environmental conservation. Their deep connection to nature teaches us the importance of living in harmony with our surroundings and protecting our planet for future generations.

Community and Values: The values of community, respect, and interconnectedness championed by First Nations serve as a guiding light for all Canadians. Their emphasis on kinship, mutual support, and respect for all living beings offers us a blueprint for a more inclusive and compassionate society.

Wisdom and Knowledge: The wisdom passed down through generations of First Nations Elders and Knowledge Keepers is a treasure trove of understanding and insight. Their teachings on health, governance, and justice enrich our collective knowledge and pave the way for a more equitable future.

As we move forward, it is crucial to continue recognizing and honoring the contributions of First Nations peoples. Let us commit to fostering a deeper understanding and appreciation of their cultures, histories, and rights. Together, we can build a Canada that respects and celebrates its First Nations heritage.

Miigwech, Hiy Hiy, and thank you to all First Nations communities for your enduring legacy and for helping to create a stronger, more diverse, and united Canada.

Today, I vouch to contribute towards upskilling you of the First Nations Communities... #FirstNations #Canada #IndigenousHeritage #CulturalDiversity #RespectAndRecognition #Innivec 15 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Terralingua and Langscape Magazine 1,312 followers 9mo Edited Report this post Today, we celebrate National Indigenous Peoples Day, honoring the First Nations, Metis, and Inuit, who contribute significantly to the cultural and social fabric of the country widely known as Canada, located on what some First Nations call Turtle Island.ğŸ¢ğŸ

These Indigenous communities have a long and rich history of resilience, vibrant cultures, and profound wisdom. Despite multiple challenges, they have maintained their unique cultural practices, languages, and traditions for centuries. Their traditional knowledge systems, tested and refined over time, inspire wisdom on sustainable living and community well-being â€“ crucial insights in today's ever-evolving world. ğŸŒ

As we honor their legacy, we must move beyond recognition and take meaningful actions. âœŠğŸ½ Support First Nations and Indigenous communities worldwide and actively foster reconciliation and justice by advocating for their rights and sovereignty. As an organization and as individuals, we recognize and respect:

- The diversity of Indigenous cultures and worldviews and their roles in Canadaâ€™s past, present, and future.

- Our collective responsibility to share natural resources revenues and close gaps in socio-economic conditions between Indigenous and non-Indigenous people. 

- Our role in the journey towards reconciliation by advancing Indigenous knowledge systems in all our work.

- Our privilege to live, work, and play on Indigenous land. 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Coalition for a Better Future 2,160 followers 7mo Report this post Economic reconciliation is crucial for fostering #inclusive #economic #growth , and ensuring that Indigenous Peoples hold leadership positions is a key part of that. 

According to our #Scorecard report ( https://bit.ly/3vEuTCX ), representation of First Nations, Inuit, and MÃ©tis in management positions â¬‡ decreased to 2.4% in 2023 from 2.7% the previous year. Tabatha Bull , President and CEO of the Canadian Council for Indigenous Business emphasizes the importance of understanding why these numbers declined and suggests three ways for corporate Canada to transform their approach to #recruiting and #retaining Indigenous leadership:

ğŸ’¡ 1) Change the decision-making process at the board level. Consider embracing consensus decision-making and recognize that Indigenous Peoples may take time to assess the long-term impact of decisions on future generations.

ğŸ’¡ 2) Focus on recruiting for potential, not just experience. Relying solely on a candidate's years of experience will restrict the pool of Indigenous talent.

ğŸ’¡ 3) Prioritize intentional training and development. Ensure Indigenous hires receive the necessary training to prepare them for leadership roles.

What does economic growth mean to you? #GrowthforAllCdns #BetterFutureforCanada First Nations Finance Authority , First Nations Major Projects Coalition Jesse McCormick , BlackNorth Initiative , Dahabo Ahmed-Omer, Alberta Indigenous Opportunities Corporation , Canada's 2SLGBTQI+ Chamber of Commerce (CGLCC) , FCC / FAC , Justine Hendricks , ACCES Employment , Heather Scoffield Patty Hajdu , Jamie Schmale Blake Desjarlais , â€¦more 6 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in WeBlackSheep 32 followers 2mo Report this post ğŸŒ Canada at a Crossroads: Economic & Political Challenges in 2025 ğŸ‡¨ğŸ‡¦

As we enter 2025, Canadians are navigating a landscape shaped by economic anxiety, regional disparities, and generational divides. Here are some key insights shaping our nation:

ğŸ’° Economic Anxiety: Rising costs, inflation, and housing unaffordability dominate concerns, creating a â€œscarcity mindsetâ€ that impacts everyday life.

ğŸ¡ Regional Divisions: From western skepticism of federal climate policies to Ontarioâ€™s housing crisis and Quebecâ€™s cultural distinctiveness, divisions are stark.

ğŸ‘¥ Generational Divide: Fragmented information consumption, older Canadians on traditional media, younger ones on platforms like TikTok, creates challenges for national unity.

ğŸ¯ Political Opportunity: With traditional partisan lines blurring, Canadians are looking for bold leadership that prioritizes affordability, job creation, and tangible solutions over ideology.

As voters seek competence and stability, 2025 offers a critical moment for leaders to bridge divides and deliver on economic and social challenges. The path forward will require empathy, innovation, and a commitment to uniting a divided nation.

Title: Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN ...
Description: Nov 27, 2024  Â·  Carol Anne Hilton, founder of the Indigenomics Institute, sees a "tidal wave" of Indigenous business growth driven by increased access to capital and improvedÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
Indigenous people involvement in business on the rise says author - APTNâ€¦ | Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN) Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN)â€™s Post Saskatchewan Indigenous Economic Development Network (SIEDN) 3,828 followers 3mo Report this post ğŸ“ˆ A Tidal Wave of Indigenous Entrepreneurship: Insights from Carol Anne Hilton ğŸŒŠ

Carol Anne Hilton, founder of the Indigenomics Institute, sees a "tidal wave" of Indigenous business growth driven by increased access to capital and improved internet in rural areas. Indigenous women, in particular, are leading the way, starting businesses at five times the national rate and securing roles on corporate boards. Hilton, an award-winning leader from the Nuu chah nulth Nation, sees this growth as a step toward economic reconciliation.

According to Hilton, the rise in Indigenous entrepreneurship is also due to a changing mindset in Canadaâ€™s banking sector. As Indigenous leaders now hold positions on the boards of major financial institutions, new doors are opening for Indigenous business ventures.

Hiltonâ€™s book, Indigenomics: Taking a Seat at the Economic Table, aims to ignite a $100 billion Indigenous economy. This November, the Indigenomics Institute will host a 24-hour Indigenous global economic forum, spotlighting 36 speakers to discuss the future of Indigenous business.

ğŸŒ "Weâ€™re building an ecosystem of successful Indigenous business leaders, providing stories and support to inspire others." â€“ Carol Anne Hilton #IndigenousEconomy #Indigenomics #IndigenousEntrepreneurs #EconomicReconciliation #BusinessGrowth https://loom.ly/fcm44aI Indigenous people involvement in business on the rise says author - APTN News https://www.aptnnews.ca 5 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts CXGLOBE 94 followers 11mo Report this post Traditional knowledge has long been overlooked in the world of business. But now, Indigenous communities are delivering sustainable solutions to a wide range of issues and reshaping the modern economy. 

With more than 476 million Indigenous people living in 90 countries across the world, building positive connections is crucial. And with Indigenous businesses gathering momentum, playing an important role in reshaping modern economies and driving reconciliation, it has become a force that can no longer be ignored.

In Australia, the number of Indigenous businesses increased by more than 47 percent between 2016 and 2021, with their collective contribution to the Australian economy rising at least 59 percent to sit in the range of A$8.5 billion (US$5.5 billion) to A$12 billion (US$7.8 billion).

In Canada, the Indigenous economy was valued at US$35.9 billion in 2020, around 2.2 percent of Canadaâ€™s gross domestic product. The Toronto-based Indigenomics Institute is confident it is on track to more than triple in size and is working to secure the Indigenous business sectorâ€™s place at the table.

In New Zealand, the last 10 years has seen the MÄori asset base grow at a significantly faster rate than the overall economy to a current valuation of more than US$42.5 billion. According to forecasts, it will reach US$60.8 billion by 2030.

In modern business, we seem to forget the symbiotic nature of â€˜whoâ€™ we are delivering to, and only focus on â€˜whatâ€™ we are doing. Traditional business, on the other hand, is alwaysÂ focused on relationships before the business. 

If the founders and entrepreneurs focus on building these relationships and solve for real-world problems, we will create greater value for not only those communities but for the whole world, while protecting traditions and creating the world a better place. #entrepreneurship #innovation #problemsolving #indigenousbusinesses Harnessing Indigenous innovation boosts opportunities for all theceomagazine.com 2 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Anmol Rattan Singh Policy Researcher | Co-Founder, PANJ Foundation 7mo Report this post I read this interesting piece a while back, and hereâ€™s my brief take on it. https://lnkd.in/giEyPVPd It's safe to say that most of us are acutely aware that the bedrock of development in Punjabâ€”and indeed, across the Global Southâ€”rests on the shoulders of knowledge equity. The notion of providing economic advisory support is not just about offering expertise; it's about empowering local voices, fostering innovation, and challenging the entrenched hierarchies of perspectives.

Punjab, with its dynamic socio-economic landscape, is uniquely positioned to lead by example. Yet, we must confront the reality that knowledge inequities have often stifled our region's potential to influence its own development trajectory. When foreign experts dominate the discourse, we risk sidelining the very voices that are most attuned to the complexities and nuances of our local context.

At PANJ (Policy Advisory and Network for Joint Progress) Foundation, we believe that true progress in Punjab requires an entrepreneurial approach to redressing these inequities. This isn't merely a matter of fairnessâ€”it's a strategic imperative. This diversity is crucial, especially when grappling with the "wicked" problems that require innovative, interdisciplinary solutions.

We must also redefine what it means to be an "expert". Expertise should be recognised not solely by published papers or foreign credentials but by an individual's deep understanding of local contexts and their capacity to innovate within them. This redefinition can unlock a wealth of untapped potential within Punjab, ensuring that our region's development is driven by those who live and breathe its challenges and opportunities.

Moreover, addressing knowledge inequities in Punjab is not just about levelling the playing fieldâ€”it's about future-proofing our economic and development strategies. By investing in local talent and fostering strategic partnerships, we can build robust knowledge systems that are resilient and adaptable to the demands of an ever-evolving global economy.

The time for action is now. Let us engage in this critical dialogue, challenge the status quo, and together, lay the foundation for a more equitable and prosperous future for Punjab. PANJ Foundation is committed to being at the forefront of this movement, and we invite thinkers, innovators, and change-makers to join us in this mission. Dr. Rajwant Singh | Harjeet Singh | Jalnidh Kaur | Dr Madan M Singh AULAKH | Dr. Preet Deep Singh | Gauravdeep Singh | Tejpreet Chopra | Manmohan (Mac) Sarin | Navkaran Singh | Dr. Harmeet Singh | Narain Batra | Satinder Grover | Amarjit Singh | Vikram R Singh | Sehaj Singh | Karan Avtar Singh | Surinder S. Jodhka | Khushwant Singh | DP Singh | Seema Bansal | Lakhwinder Singh | Harpreet Singh Arora | Tridivesh Singh Maini | Hamraj Singh | Dr. Jatinder Kaur Arora Economic advisory work: knowledge inequities in the Global South https://onthinktanks.org 18 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in INASP 5,363 followers 8mo Report this post ğŸŒğŸ“Š What and whose knowledge counts in economic advisory work and in engagement with governments in the Global South? Knowledge inequities continue to challenge this work. Local contexts are often overlooked, leading to recommendations that may not be effective or sustainable. At INASP, we believe in strengthening inclusive and locally-driven knowledge systems to address these disparities.

In partnership with On Think Tanks, INASP Executive Director Jonathan Harle and INASP Associate Leandro Echt looked at this problem in depth in their recently published review. 

Read the blog post here: https://lnkd.in/erQtb-PR Find the full review here: https://lnkd.in/eH7rbKHE #GlobalSouth #KnowledgeEquity #EconomicAdvisory #INASP #OnThinkTanks #EquitableKnowledgeEcosystems Economic advisory work: knowledge inequities in the Global South https://onthinktanks.org 17 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Spatial Foresight 1,864 followers 6mo Edited Report this post Spatial Foresight is proud to have contributed to theÂ 'Study on Benchmarking the Socio-Economic Performance of the EU Social Economy.'

The project had two interconnected aims: to represent the #socialeconomy of today based on current data as well as to identify methodological and operational tools to improve this representation. The study collects and analyses quantitative and qualitative data the social economy ecosystem as well as their contribution to a sustainable, innovative and resilient economy and society. 

ğŸ“ŠÂ Key figures:
ğŸ”¹At least 11.5 million peopleâ€”representing 6.3% of the employed populationâ€”are engaged in the social economy.
ğŸ”¹Across the 27 EU Member States, the social economy comprises over 4.3 million entities.
ğŸ”¹MoreÂ than 246,000 social enterprises have been identified.
Â 
It was a fascinating experience working on this emerging topic alongside Euricse and CIRIEC International (via CIRIEC-EspaÃ±a ). A special thank you to our team leader Silke N. Haarich Haarich and team members Sandra Spule , Marcela MÃ¤der Furtado , Kirsti Hagemann , and Jean Claude Zeimet for their excellent collaboration.
Â 
The study was led by Euricse and commissioned by the European Innovation Council and SMEs Executive Agency (EISMEA) and DG GROW.

ğŸ”—Â Read the full report here: https://lnkd.in/ew-MkTGH Study on benchmarking the socio-economic performance of the EU social economy is now published! eismea.ec.europa.eu 18 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in pk mutch Serial SME Entrepreneur. University Educator. Socialist, "Five i" Feminist and Post Growth Economy Activist. Columnist/writer for rabble.ca. 8mo Edited Report this post Recently, Canadian busines leaders, elites, and small biz associations are whispering "productivity" to each other like McGuire, the uncle, purred the word "plastics" into 
Dustin Hoffmanâ€™s Benjamin's ear as the ultimate "secret to success" advice in the movie, The Graduate.

Productivity. Conservatives, bank and think tank studies, and rhetoric in media is already mounting. It will emerge as a slick, manufactured election issue for Canadians. 

Increased productivity, meaning essentially increasing sales, removing regulatory hurdles, while producing more, faster at lower cost, increases GDP, and the potential to create wealth ---for all but in truth, primarily for foreign/domestic owners/ shareholders. Trickle down economics rhetoric rides again. 

Investment in productivity centered tech and innovation is not in itself bad. The issue is where the wealth it creates goes. 

Not to us.

Surely we have learned?

In this time in our collective history, GDP growth via increased productivity with continued ecological rape and significant increase in taxation of corporate wealth created is the wrong thing to focus on if we want all life to thrive and live in balance.  In today's world, that means reclaiming, increasing funding to, and public soverign control of land, housing, healthy local food, healthcare, essential infrastructure, and investment in and all-access to world class education opportunities. 

A corporate and business elite defined and motivated productivity agenda helps the few and not the many. Don't be fooled. Again. 

If The Graduate was re made today, I like to believe it would feature a loving radical, modern socialist, intersectional feminist Aunty, in clear voice at a Palestinian protest rally (not a Rosedale party) passionately cupping Benjamin's face, saying honey, its "peace, solidarity, post growth economics". #postgrowth #productivity Growth is enriching an elite and killing the planet. We need an economy based on human rights | Olivier De Schutter theguardian.com 16 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Omer Abdalla Community Builder and Serial Entrepreneur 10mo Edited Report this post Economic reconciliation with Indigenous communities is not just a moral imperative, but also a significant opportunity for all Canadian business owners. It's about fostering partnerships that respect Indigenous sovereignty, culture, and rights, and creating economic opportunities that benefit both Indigenous and non-Indigenous Canadians.

Today I got to hear from leading experts in the field of Indigenous Economic reconciliation. Lindsay Brant, M.Ed, PhD Candidate (ABD). , Jarret Leaman , Rhode Thomas , Shyra Barberstock, PhD , Rye Karonhiowanen Barberstock, PhD , spoke beautifully on the colonial systems that exist within Canada, and the barriers to breaking down said systems.

For many years, the economic marginalization of Indigenous communities has contributed to the socio-economic gaps that we see today. Economic reconciliation seeks to address these disparities by ensuring that Indigenous peoples have equitable access to resources, opportunities, and decision-making processes. The Canadian Government follows a requirement for federal departments and agencies ensures a minimum 5% of the total value of contracts are held by Indigenous businesses, a number in line with the population percentage of Indigenous peoples on Turtle Island.

Investing in Indigenous partnerships means tapping into rich cultural heritage, innovative business practices, and a growing market of consumers who value social responsibility. Itâ€™s a chance to learn from each other and build a more inclusive economy that respects and incorporates Indigenous knowledge and traditions. 

I learned today that the Land we live on can be seen as curriculum, a curriculum we need to understand, respect, and implement in our business practices. 

How are you incorporating principles of economic reconciliation in your business? I would love to hear practical solutions I myself could implement!

Together, letâ€™s honour the land we are on. I acknowledge that I live and work on the traditional territories of the Mississaugas of the Credit, the Anishinaabe, the Haudenosaunee, and the Wendat peoples. 14 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Pharis Mavia Sales representative at LEJA.  
cybersecurity analyst.
CEO CyberVault.
Director at Catering angels ğŸœğŸ² 4mo Report this post Today, we gather to celebrate the incredible strides made by many countries that were once labeled as "third world" nations. These countries, often underestimated, have demonstrated resilience, adaptability, and ambition, transforming challenges into remarkable growth stories. The term "third world" may imply a position behind the rest of the world, but the reality we see today tells a different storyâ€”one of rapid development, innovation, and a drive to reshape their futures.

One of the driving forces behind this economic growth is the entrepreneurial spirit that thrives in these nations. With young, ambitious populations, many countries are investing in small and medium enterprises, providing platforms for job creation and wealth generation at the grassroots level. This momentum has paved the way for a burgeoning middle class, which, in turn, stimulates demand for goods, services, and infrastructure.

Moreover, we cannot overlook the role of technology in this transformation. Mobile technology, for instance, has redefined access to banking and financial services, particularly in regions where traditional banking infrastructure is limited. In East Africa, for example, mobile payment systems like M-Pesa have revolutionized commerce, enabling millions to participate in the economy without needing a bank account. This digital revolution is creating unprecedented opportunities for financial inclusion and economic participation.

Another crucial factor in this economic growth is the commitment of these countries to invest in education and skill development. Governments are increasingly prioritizing education, recognizing that a skilled workforce is vital to a competitive economy. From vocational training programs to partnerships with international educational institutions, these investments are equipping the youth with the tools they need to succeed in the global market.

Foreign direct investment (FDI) has also played a pivotal role. Investors worldwide are recognizing the potential of emerging markets and are channeling funds into industries such as manufacturing, agriculture, technology, and renewable energy. In fact, some of the worldâ€™s fastest-growing economies today are in Africa and Southeast Asia, where foreign investments are creating jobs and infrastructure and driving exports.

Ladies and gentlemen, while these achievements are cause for celebration, there is still much work ahead. Many of these nations continue to face challenges related to income inequality, political stability, and environmental sustainability. However, the positive trajectory we see today gives us reason for optimism. With continued commitment to sustainable growth, investment in people, and innovation, these countries are well on their way to shaping a future where they stand not behind but alongside the worldâ€™s most developed economies.

Let us be inspired by their journey and look forward to a world where opportunity, prosperity, and success are truly global. 6 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in GOALOOPÂ® - Connecting the World through GoalsÂ® 615 followers 9mo Report this post Shrink the #Economy , Save the World?

Economic #growth has been ecologically costly â€” and so a movement in favor of â€˜degrowthâ€™ is growing. Techno-optimists place their faith in #innovation ; degrowthers place theirs in social movements. Both sides lay claim to being the genuine realists. Each insists that we simply donâ€™t have enough time to do what the other side wants.

â€œGains in economic growth have too often buoyed the fortunes of the richest instead of lifting all boats. Prosperity even in the most prosperous countries hasnâ€™t been shared. But all the attention to #inequality is just a crack in the edifice of economic orthodoxy. Now a much more radical proposition has emerged, looming like a wrecking ball: Is economic growth desirable at all?

[...] today there is a burgeoning â€œpost-growthâ€ and â€œdegrowthâ€ movement [...] 

â€˜A Poverty of Imaginationâ€™

Given how keenly the degrowth movement disavows coercion, how is this wholesale transformation supposed to happen? â€œSeeds of degrowth communism are sprouting all over the world,â€ Saito writes, pointing to experiments in local governance in cities like Barcelona, which has pledged to be carbon neutral by 2050, and farming cooperatives in South Africa.

Even degrowthâ€™s skeptics may find that Saitoâ€™s examples of grass-roots organizing sound agreeably democratic and improvisational. But the prospect of global apocalypse that degrowthers keep emphasizing also has the perverse effect of making local measures sound acutely inadequate. Still, Saito says that such experiments do offer something crucial: an enlarged sense of whatâ€™s possible. Degrowthâ€™s critics, he writes, suffer from â€œa poverty of imagination that simply accepts the status quo as unchangeable.â€

As it happens, Susskind says precisely the same thing but in the reverse: that itâ€™s degrowthâ€™s advocates who suffer from a â€œlack of imagination.â€ The mirrored accusations are striking. Maybe it isnâ€™t a matter so much of imagination scarcity as of where that imagination is directed. Techno-optimists place their faith in innovation; degrowthers place theirs in social movements. Both sides lay claim to being the genuine realists. Each insists that we simply donâ€™t have enough time to do what the other side wants.

The intransigence of such zero-sum disputes is a reminder of why win-win fantasies are so attractive in the first place. Whatever the profound differences between degrowthâ€™s proponents and their critics, the scale of the climate crisis suggests one point of convergence: We need all the imaginative help we can get.â€

By Jennifer Szalai https://lnkd.in/embXvJSc #economy #markets #growth #revenue #income #justice #socialmobility #climatechange #AI #democracy #goals #connectgoals #goalmarket #technology #equality #health #humanity Shrink the Economy, Save the World? https://www.nytimes.com 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Nova SBE Leadership for Impact Knowledge Center 5,602 followers 5mo Report this post ğŸŒ New report about the #SocialEconomy published by the European Commission ! ğŸš€

We are proud to share that two reports from the Nova SBE Leadership for Impact Knowledge Center and the NOVA SBE Data Science Knowledge Center have been referenced in the report â€œBenchmarking the Socio-Economic Performance of the EU Social Economy.â€

This comprehensive report highlights the crucial role of the social economy across 27 EU Member States, with over 4.3 million entities employing at least 11.5 million people.

At the Nova SBE Leadership for Impact Knowledge Center , we are committed to building the capacity of social organizations, empowering them to deepen their impact and operational efficiency. Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Mason Ducharmeâ€™s Post Mason Ducharme PhD | Indigenous Executive & Capacity-Building Scholar | Specialist in Indigenous Governance 9mo Report this post ğŸ“¢ Calling for a Change: Strengthening Verification for Indigenous Scholarships

Over the past 15 years, I suspect that over $1,000,000 of Indigenous-specific post-secondary scholarships and bursaries have been accessed by pretendians. This misuse highlights a significant flaw in the current self-identification process for some scholarships, which often requires no documentation to prove Indigenous identity.

Many post-secondary institutions and private sector businesses allow applicants to self-identify as Indigenous without requiring any proof. In contrast, Indigenous organizations such as the National Indian Brotherhood Trust, Chief Joe Mathias, and Lilwat Nation mandate documentation like a status card or a community letter.

Having been in post-secondary education since 2010, Iâ€™ve observed that only about 20% of recipients of Indigenous scholarships or bursaries seemed authentically Indigenous, explicitly sharing their community, language, and culture. The remaining 80%, often vaguely identifying as MÃ©tis without specifying their community, appeared to exploit the self-identification process, thereby diverting much-needed financial support from genuinely Indigenous students.

The case of the Gill twins is a notable example of this exploitation going unpunished, and I believe there are many more cases out there. Itâ€™s clear that the self-identification process is flawed and primarily benefits pretendians.

We must eliminate self-identification for Indigenous scholarships to ensure that resources dedicated to Indigenous Peoples are used to close the socioeconomic gap for those who truly need and deserve it. #IndigenousScholarships #EducationEquity #StopPretendians #AuthenticityMatters 117 16 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Roxanne M. Environmental groups also preying on indigenous to obtain funding. Itâ€™s sick, so hard to trust anyoneâ€¦ would be nice to get to a point where we donâ€™t depend on government money and be able to protect it.

This needs to be shut down for sure, please let me what steps we can take to stop this. Reporting them is difficult I think there needs to be an audit and some legislation to prevent this. The main problem is that these schools and programs they donâ€™t care, not at all, cos for them itâ€™s guaranteed enrolment and money.

I personally donâ€™t have a problem with someone  doing this that is not native but is a supporter and advocate and has a solid understanding of the culture and like whateverâ€¦.

BUT if someone is doing this for the purposes of just taking advantage and not contributing anything to indigenous culture or straight up taking it away from potential candidates then that is very wrong and this issue has now escalated to a point where itâ€™s out of control.

Without having to disclose how I weeded through applications that had very high likelihood of being a â€œpretendianâ€ - itâ€™s definitely a thing!

In a thought-provoking article, Maleke Fourati, Associate Professor at the South Mediterranean University â€“ Mediterranean School of Business (SMU-MSB), currently on leave at the University of French Polynesia, explores the lingering effects of colonial influence on educational institutions in #Tunisia .

The study reveals that the enrolment of Tunisian students in colonial primary schools has significantly influenced literacy rates for decades. Notably, a 1% increase in enrolment in 1931 is linked to an approximate 1.8 percentage point rise in literacy by 2014. This enduring legacy highlights educationâ€™s crucial role in breaking the cycle of poverty.

Since gaining independence, Tunisia has made remarkable progress in reducing educational disparities, achieving near-universal primary education by 2014. However, challenges persist, especially regarding the quality of education.

Fourati stresses that while our history impacts our present, it doesnâ€™t dictate our future.
