Department of Procurement & Supply Chain Management at Makerere University Business School 4mo Report this post The age restrictions imposed by many scholarship programs targeting Africans are not only unrealistic but also profoundly unjust. Imagine a PhD scholarship for a needy African with an age limit of 35 years. Such limitations fail to acknowledge the unique challenges faced by numerous African students, thereby denying opportunities to those who have demonstrated immense resilience and determination. In many African countries, the journey to higher education is anything but straightforward. It is a path marked by significant personal sacrifice and unwavering perseverance. Many students start going to School late due to the long walk from home to school and back. In other cases, along the way, many students must balance their studies with work to support themselves and their families, which requires taking breaks from their education to earn money or dealing with life events such as early marriage or pregnancy, further delaying their academic progress. Such realities make it impossible for many African students to adhere to traditional educational timelines. So, when scholarships impose age limits, they exclude those who have had to navigate these non-traditional paths. I feel that a student who has worked for years to save for university fees or a young mother returning to school after raising her children is no less deserving of financial aid than someone who followed a more conventional route. 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Patrick Otundo Educator, Instructional Designer, Author, Writer 4mo Report this post A Brief History of Education in Kenya During the Pre-Colonial and Colonial Epochs

The education system has evolved from the pre-colonial, colonial, post-colonial right into the 21st century, influenced chiefly by individuals and committees appointed by the government. 

Since of these individuals were appointed by the government, most of their recommendations were based on prevailing political realities. This article describes how the Kenyan education system has evolved over the years.

Pre-colonial Education

Even though formal schooling was unheard of before the Europeans arrived in Kenya, there existed a form of education whose primary aim was acculturation or transmission of culture from generation to generation. 

The purpose of education in pre-colonial Kenya was to teach the communityâ€™s cultural practices to the young. 

The philosophy of education at that time tended to be more pragmatic as the older members of society would spend time teaching children the skills they needed for their day-to-day survival.

Colonial Education

During the colonial era, education was mainly to convert Africans to Christianity and create a skilled labor force for the colonial enterprise. 

Africans were required to acquire practical skills such as agriculture, carpentry, and masonry to work for European settlers. 

This happened in both missionary and government schools across the country. 

The first formal school in Kenya was established in 1846 by Ludwig Krapf and Johan Rebmann, two missionaries working with the Church Missionary Society (CMS).

According to Mackatiani C. et al., education before the 1908 Fraser Commission did not discriminate against students on account of their race.

The Fraser Commission was the first to recommend the segregation of the education system, with Africans getting training in practical skills, Indians in technical skills, and Europeans in academic-oriented disciplines. 

From the early 1920s to the early 1930s, the government established schools in Narok, Kericho, Kajiado, Tambach, Loitoktok, Kakamega, and Kagumo. 

In 1949, Beecher led a government-appointed committee to establish the Royal Technical College, which became the University of Nairobi. 1 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Startup Pakistan 761,582 followers 5mo Report this post Pakistanâ€™s Ministry of Religious Affairs announced scholarships aimed at non-Muslim students to enhance educational opportunities for minority communities, which constitute less than 5% of the population. The government is committed to promoting inclusivity through initiatives like the Prime Ministerâ€™s Minority Scholarship Scheme and the Pakistan Minorities Scholarship Program. 

These programs offer financial support covering tuition, stipends, book allowances, and travel grants based on academic merit, financial need, and citizenship.

A ministry spokesman stated that applications for this financial year's scholarships will be submitted online through the ministry's website. Approximately $210,000 (Rs60 million) has been allocated for this initiative. Eligibility requires non-Muslim students in government institutions to have scored at least 50% marks and to provide necessary documentation. #Pakistan #EducationForAll #MinorityScholarships #Inclusivity #ReligiousAffairs 574 17 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Yemi Ajayi Faculty Member, Researcher, Mediapreneur, Artist 3mo Report this post A BALANCED APPROACH TO Tertiary Education Trust Fund Tetfund 'S SUSPENSION OF FOREIGN #SCHOLARSHIPS Following the release of the memorandum announcing #TETFund 's decision to suspend foreign scholarships, a wave of responses has emerged across #academic circles and social media platforms. A significant portion of these submissions, rather than fostering constructive dialogue, have sought to rally academic #unions against the agency. This rising tide of dissent calls for a measured and intellectually grounded response, one that transcends emotion and embraces reason, offering a balanced perspective on this critical issue.

While it is understandable that some may feel concerned about the suspension of foreign scholarships by TETFund, it is important to approach this issue with a balanced and pragmatic perspective.

1. The Temporary Nature of the Suspension:
The word suspension signifies a temporary halt, not a permanent decision. This suggests that the program can be reinstated once the underlying challenges are addressed.

2. Valid Reasons for the Suspension:
TETFund has cited two key issues:

Abuse of the Scholarship: Unfortunately, many beneficiaries now view the scholarship as a pathway to permanent emigration ( _Japa_ ), rather than a means to gain #knowledge and return to contribute to #national #development (A grave concern).

Exchange Rate Crisis: With the #naira struggling against the #dollar , the funds that once supported thousands will now barely cover a few, through no fault of the agency.

3. Empathy and Pragmatism:
If we were in the position of the TETFund Secretary, would we continue to fund a program that yields diminishing returns? The logical decision would be to pause, reassess, and explore alternative solutions.


4. The Way Forward:
Rather than inciting unions against TETFund, we should encourage constructive engagement. Key unions/stakeholders such as #ASUU , #ASUP , et.al , can:

Collaborate with TETFund to design programs that prevent abuse, such as mandatory return clauses (With more severe consequences for any breach of agreement) and post-scholarship monitoring.

Advocate for Alternative #Solutions , such as domestic scholarships with #international collaboration or short-term overseas training.

Engage with the #Government to address the exchange rate issue or increase funding for education.

This is a call for responsibility and collaboration, not confrontation. By working together, we can restore the integrity of the scholarship program and ensure it serves its original purpose, which is tailored towards advancing Nigeriaâ€™s #academic and #economic development.

Caveat:
I personally have no affiliation with TETFund or any political entity, I have not benefitted from the scholarship, so it won't be construed as a beneficiary defending his benefactor, I do not know the executive secretary from Adam, but as an academic, I believe in standing tall for what is right and feasible always.

Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.Dâ€™s Post Paul Gruner, MBA, CPA, ICD.D Chief Executive Officer | Certified board director | Indigenous business | Passionate about ESG | Supporter of sustainable resource extraction 1y Edited Report this post Today marks my last official day with Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC) . It has been an incredible journey with some amazing progress made in a very short period of time. 

Key accomplishments that stand out for me:

- Bringing an amazing Sr. Leadership team together. The best I have ever had the honour of working with.

- Building out the drivers license, mentorship and Heavy Equipment Operators (HEO) programs to help our members and employees into cool jobs and advancing in their perspective careers.

- Revamping the safety program with a significant shift in safety culture and the roadmap to achieving COR certification. 

- Significant advancement for finance and accounting through outsourced payroll with an online tool to enhance employee value, shift in fiscal year end to improve reporting for the shareholder and a plan to go from a review to an audit.  

- Shift in construction delivery from time and materials into fixed bids. Becoming the general contractor for the TIA at Red Chris mine site and a refreshed fleet with a progressive maintenance program. 

- A focus on employee experience through the first employee survey (we did 2 to date), enhanced compensation and benefits, employee recognition program and exit interviews. 

- Enhanced communication plan with a brand refresh, 2 comprehensive reports per year, rich social media program and regular community engagement. 

I want to thank all of the dedicated TNDC employees. An amazing Sr. Leadership team.  A caring board of directors. A supportive community. Excellent industry and business partners that have supported us through our journey to date. 

Much awesomeness has been achieved and the journey is far from over. TNDC is growing and quickly being a national leader. 

Proud to be a small part of it all. 

Meduh (Thank you)!!!

Here are some of my favourite pictures over the last couple of years that I think captures the journey nicely. In this episode, we had the privilege of speaking with Dr. Moses Alobo , a distinguished physician, public health expert, and social impact entrepreneur, about the critical role of African voices in driving scientific innovation. Dr. Alobo leads the Science Innovation and Entrepreneurship team at the Science for Africa Foundation , where he works tirelessly to bridge the gap between cutting-edge science and the unique needs of the African continent.

In this insightful conversation, Dr. Alobo shared his vision for a future where scientific advancements are deeply rooted in local challenges, creating solutions that resonate with the realities on the ground. He emphasized the importance of aligning innovations with market demands, highlighting how science must respond to the specific needs of African communities to truly make an impact.

ğŸ’¬ â€œWhat I would really like to do is to make sure that health innovations, scientific innovations on the African continent, are actually working towards local problems. This 2025 is a very interesting year. https://lnkd.in/dZHij5Sv Welcoming Remarks and Special Address weforum.org Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Akira Dheena Software Engineer | Artificial Intelligence | Woman in STEM 5mo Edited Report this post Todayâ€™s welcome address at the SingularityU South Africa Summit 2024 by Dr. Peter Diamandis was nothing short of eye-opening! His insights on exponential mindsets, longevity, and the power of like-minded communities truly resonated with me. ğŸŒ±ğŸ§ 

He emphasized how finding a community of innovators and disruptors can reshape your mindset at any point in lifeâ€”allowing you to think bigger, adapt faster, and continuously evolve. This shift in mindset can lead to more progress in the next decade than weâ€™ve seen in the past century. ğŸŒâš¡

Dr. Diamandis also delved into the fascinating possibilities of extending longevity and how advancing technologies will push human potential to unprecedented levels. ğŸ’¡

The potential is limitless, and this is just the beginning. ğŸš€ Old Mutual South Africa #OldMutual21 #ExponentialMindset #ExponentialAfrica #Longevity #Innovation #TechForGood #FutureProofAfrica #FutureThinking 9 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Andreas Grape Founder and CEO @ Nordic Angels | European Angels | Davos Angels | Podcast Host â€Patric blir Ã„ngelâ€ I The State of European Angels I Angel Prize I Mingla.io I ACAP I Nordisia I Secondry 2mo Report this post Davos AngelsğŸª½


Europe can no longer afford a fragmented business community. Fragmentation holds Europe back, and by uniting, business angels we can leverage competence, experience, and capital to unlock network effects, drive growth, and secure Europeâ€™s position on the global stage

Individual investors have some influence, but as a group, business angels have immense powerâ€”perhaps the most significant untapped resource in Europe. Its a forgotten group that no one has built anything for before on their own terms.

Business angels are a critical voice for innovation, but they lack an independent organization to represent them in the media and to policymakers.

If we come together as a group, entrepreneurs will gain better access to capital. The capital is here in our region, but thereâ€™s a lack of coordination. If we solve that, entrepreneurs can focus on building their businesses instead of searching for capital in every corner of the world.

If you are in Davos during WEF let us know and we might have something for you. Dm please if you are around Thursday where will gather some of the most recognized Angels in Europe. Nordic Angels Ash Pournouri Mark Turrell unDavos Summit Global Conversations Finnish Flow Swedish Lunch Krim Talia Peter Westford Janna Salokangas Mattia Mor Gunhild Anker Stordalen #worldeconomicforum #wef In the picture, I had the pleasure of taking a stroll with Micael Dahlen (the happy professor) during the Swedish lunch last year, together with Alexander Widegren and Marcus Widegren * An unforgettable moment as the children of Klosters raced down the snowy slopes, their laughter and joy filling the crisp winter air, while we grown-ups had a serious conversation about the meaning of happinessğŸ˜…ğŸ¤£ 377 38 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Oliver Fortune Chikodzore Investor Relations, Regional Integration, Business Strategist, Author, Global Trade and Global Speaker 3mo Report this post Have you ever heard of the crab-bucket effect? The minute you start to ascend in life, the other crabs in the bucket pull you back downâ€”so you can be trapped in mediocrity with them. Itâ€™s driven by jealousy, envy, resentment, or all three.
 
 Imagine the very opposite effectâ€”where other high achievers are lifting you up to join them in pursuit of your dream.Â 
 Youâ€™ve probably heard that youâ€™re the average of the 5 people you spend the most time with. Where do you find these winners? How do you get around people who can both relate to having a grand vision but also raise the bar for what is possible?
 They flock to specific groups and events (birds of a feather flock together) like business conferences. ABLIS 2025 will help formÂ part of our tribe you need to elevate yourself to the next level. 
Join the Movement
Whether you are a policymaker, investor, entrepreneur, or business leader, ABLIS 2025 offers a unique convergence and marketplace to:
Gain strategic insights into Africaâ€™s economic opportunities.
Forge lasting collaborations for shared prosperity.
Shape the future of African business and leadership.
Visit www.theablis.com for more information and registration details.

Indigenomics 4,887 followers 3mo Edited The Indigenomics Institute is thrilled to highlight the First Nations Bank of Canada , a distinguished recipient of the Indigenomics 10 to Watch 2024 Award!

Established in 1996, First Nations Bank of Canada (FNBC) is the only Indigenous-owned Schedule 1 bank in the country. Bill Lomax , CEO, emphasizes the bankâ€™s unique position in the financial sector. "Weâ€™re part of the financial aspect of nation-building," he explains. The bank doesnâ€™t just offer generic services; instead, it works closely with Indigenous communities to understand and meet their specific needs. FNBC prides itself on tailoring solutions to the priorities of the nations it serves, which distinguishes it from larger commercial banks. 

Beyond financing, FNBC also plays a crucial role in helping Indigenous communities manage their financial assets. It works closely with First Nations on trust management, supporting communities as they manage settlements and other financial resources in a sustainable way. This is Indigenomics in action.

ğŸŒ I raised a few points regarding how AfCRA can help in the economic development of the African Continent: enhance the credit worthiness of our collective economies, reduce the credit rating bias that impose higher-than-normal credit risk premia, encourage the development of African domestic capital markets and foster regional integration among our collective markets in the continent. 

ğŸ¤– I also touched upon how AfCRA can innovate to stay ahead of evolving financial landscape such as leveraging technology and AI drive data and analysis, providing Africa-centric variables and dynamics in the analysis and create a digital platform for stakeholder engagement, among other points. These will help improve credit rating accuracy by analyzing a large quantum of economic, social and environmental data in realtime, all the while providing investors and researchers a more accurate assessment of African credit risks and dynamics. 

â˜‘ï¸ Eventually, Africa has a lot of potential and as a continent, can contribute significantly to economic development and innovation. Last night at 8 PM, I had the privilege of virtually attending the High-Level Dialogue on the Establishment of the Africa Credit Rating Agency (AfCRA) in New York. This pivotal event, organized by the African Peer Review Mechanism (APRM) and the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa (UNECA), tackled the pressing issue of unfair credit ratings for African nations.

My key takeaway? The establishment of AfCRA is a game-changer, poised to unlock Africaâ€™s true economic potential by providing fairer credit ratings. This initiative will pave the way for better access to global capital markets and lower borrowing costs, fuelling Africaâ€™s industrialization and economic resilience.

However, a well-known challenge remains: How will AfCRA ensure its ratings are accepted and trusted by global investors and financial institutions? This question is crucial for AfCRAâ€™s success in the realistic world. #AfCRA #EconomicGrowth #AfricaRising #FairCreditRatings #GlobalFinance 10 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Ashley E. Shah , president of The Rockefeller Foundation , said at the Mission 300 African Energy Summit in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. Bloomberg News Antony Sguazzin sums it up, â€œDubbed Mission 300, the initiative involves pledges from the The World Bank and African Development Bank Group that will be spent on projects across sub-Saharan Africa in return for countries putting in place regulations to attract private investment. Including private capital, and assistance from philanthropies such as the Rockefeller Foundation, the program could see expenditure of as much as $85 billion, although it was difficult to give a precise estimate,â€ Ajay Banga, the World Bankâ€™s president, said in an interview. It was an honor and pleasure to have you in our midst. #indigenomics #reconciliation #knowledge ğŸ’¡ğŸ“–ğŸ™ John McKenzie 2y Today, I was grateful to welcome Carol Anne Hilton â€” Founder of the Indigenomics Institute and author of Donner Prize-finalist, 'Indigenomics: Taking a Seat at the Economic Table' â€” to the TMX Market Centre.

Carol Anne graciously met with our team and presented an outstanding talk about bringing attention and focus to the growing Indigenous economy. In Carol Anneâ€™s words, Indigenous economic growth is good for everyone. 

I also had the opportunity to thank Carol Anne, personally for naming TMX Group to the 2022 Indigenomics Top 10 to Watch List, recognizing our efforts towards Indigenous reconciliation and inclusion. 

Carol Anne, on behalf of #TeamTMX , thank you for joining us today. Title: Nationsfirst on LinkedIn: #blockchain #selfdetermination ...
Description: Jun 17, 2024  Â·  #blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics. Play Video. Video Player is loading. Loaded: 0%. Play Back to start. Stream Type LIVE. CurrentÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
#blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics | Nationsfirst Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Nationsfirstâ€™s Post Nationsfirst 465 followers 9mo Report this post The Indian Act, established in 1876 by the Canadian government, was not designed to honor or leverage the economic wealth of Indigenous peoples. Instead, it was primarily set up as a tool for assimilation and control, imposing European governance structures, restricting Indigenous rights, and undermining traditional economic and social systems. This Act centralized decision-making by Canada, disempowering Indigenous communities and disconnecting them from their traditional governance and economic practices, which were deeply intertwined with their cultural and spiritual beliefs. 

To truly move towards self-determination, Indigenous communities may need to unlearn the systems imposed by the Indian Act and re-engage with their traditional ways. This involves revitalizing Indigenous legal systems and cultural practices and may include adopting modern technologies such as blockchain. Utilizing blockchain could provide transparent and secure methods for managing community resources and transactions, potentially even supporting the creation of a value-based currency that reflects Indigenous values and priorities. Such steps are fundamental in re-establishing Indigenous economic systems and governance structures on their terms and according to their traditional laws and practices. #blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics â€¦more 4 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Ethan Clark CEO & Co-Founder at Nationsfirst Technologies 9mo Report this post Now is a critical time in our history as Indigenous peoples. We stand at a crossroads, faced with the pivotal decision of whether we will determine our own governance and governments, or allow the colonial government to continue doing so through modern treaty agreements, â€œself-governmentâ€ agreements and land management acts. The emergence of blockchain technology presents a transformative opportunity to not only re-establish our sovereignty but also to ensure it remains immutable and incorruptible.

By leveraging blockchain, we can create a transparent and secure foundation for our governance structures, financial systems, and communal investments. This technology allows us to protect our cultural heritage, uphold our traditional laws, and manage our resources in a way that aligns with our values and needs.

Blockchain's decentralized nature empowers us to bypass the colonial frameworks that have historically undermined our self-determination. It offers a means to build a future where our governance is truly representative of our people, and where our decisions are made free from external interference.

At Nationsfirst, we are committed to harnessing this technology to pave the way for a new era of Indigenous sovereignty. Join us as we embark on this transformative journey to reclaim our identity, wealth, and culture. Learn more at www.nationsfirst.io and sign up to be the first to know when we launch. Nationsfirst 465 followers 9mo The Indian Act, established in 1876 by the Canadian government, was not designed to honor or leverage the economic wealth of Indigenous peoples. Instead, it was primarily set up as a tool for assimilation and control, imposing European governance structures, restricting Indigenous rights, and undermining traditional economic and social systems. To truly move towards self-determination, Indigenous communities may need to unlearn the systems imposed by the Indian Act and re-engage with their traditional ways. Utilizing blockchain could provide transparent and secure methods for managing community resources and transactions, potentially even supporting the creation of a value-based currency that reflects Indigenous values and priorities. Such steps are fundamental in re-establishing Indigenous economic systems and governance structures on their terms and according to their traditional laws and practices. #blockchain #selfdetermination #indigenomics Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in #KALAKOVERSE NEWS 1,050 followers 5mo Report this post ğŸ”¥ BREAK-THE-WEB !! ğŸ”¥ #KD : ğŸ™ï¸~ â€˜ Hi folks,
I am Kevin Douglas. 

As I mentioned in my last interview in Duba, in my novels, I try to simplify certain concepts.
In #KALAKO for example, Blockchain was one of the most exciting concepts to demystify.

** Let us all transport ourselves in spirit to an African village. Imagine the blockchain as a parley tree, under which villagers gather to make important decisions.Â ğŸ‘ï¸
Â 
ğŸ¥Š Instead of all decisions being made by a chief, each and everyone has a say in the matter, and the decision is made together. 

ğŸ–ğŸ¼ - This is what is called Â«Â decentralization in blockchainÂ Â»: everyone has a role to play and no one controls everything ! Â´ âš’ï¸
Â 
** Now imagine that every time a decision is made under the parley tree, it is engraved in the bark of the tree. ğŸ¦ 

â˜‚ï¸ - This way, everyone will be able to see what has been decided and no one will be able to erase or modify the marks. This is what is called Â«Â immutability in blockchainÂ Â»: once information is added, it cannot be changed.Â ğŸ™ğŸ¾
Â 
** Additionally, whenever a new decision is carved into the tree, it is linked to all previous decisions. If someone tries to change a previous decision, it will affect all subsequent decisions, which will be easily noticed by everyone. 

âš”ï¸ - This is the Â«Â hash effectÂ Â»: a function that links all the blocks together in the blockchain.Â âŒšï¸
Â 
ğŸ© ~ Furthermore, before a decision is carved into the bark of the tree, everyone must agree. 

- This is what is called Â«Â blockchain consensusÂ Â»: everyone must verify and approve a piece ofÂ  information before it can be added.Â âŒ›ï¸
Â 
** Finally, imagine that there is an oracle in this village who predicts the weather in the coming days. If his predictions come true, he receives a payment. 

ğŸ’ - This is similar to Â«Â proof of workÂ Â» in blockchain, where those who solve a complex problem (like predicting the weather) are rewarded. 

** In fact, the blockchain is like a digital parley tree ğŸ¦  â€¦ where everyone has to express themselves, where all decisions are engraved so that everyone can see them, and where everyone must give their agreement before a new decision can be made. ğŸ¥Š #Tech #A .i #KD #KALAKOTV #ADMP #DLT #Delhi #Dubai #Doha #Lubumbashi #ManUtd #LaurynHill #FashionWeek â€¦more 7 5 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Anthony Richard CEO of Universe.com | Leader | Innovator | Blockchain, Web3 and AI Technology enthusiast | Strategist | Futurist | Building for Africa 3mo Report this post We are in the last month of the year!

The Constitution allocates specific powers to both, allowing states to cater to regional needs while ensuring national unity. However, political bargaining and regional demands can sometimes challenge this balance, just as we see with the tension between centralization and decentralization in the tech world.

In tech, decentralization, such as with blockchain, empowers individual nodes or systems to function independently while maintaining security and transparency across the network. This is similar to how states operate in a federal system: they have the autonomy to address local issues but are part of the larger national framework. Decentralization fosters innovation, resilience, and responsiveness, allowing each unit to adapt to its unique context.

The key, both in governance and tech, is finding the right balance. The strength lies in decentralizationâ€™s ability to innovate and adapt, while also ensuring coordination and unity in a larger system. #Federalism #Innovation #Politics #BalanceofPower #Technology #Decentralization 13 Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Ivan B. Linde Sustainability Technology Liaison | Open to GREAT Collaboration Opportunities | Open Networker LION 5mo Report this post ### Tether's Bold Move: Boron-Backed Tokens in Turkey 

In an ambitious effort to integrate blockchain technology beyond traditional uses, Tether has approached the Turkish government with a cutting-edge proposal: digital tokens backed by boron. This initiative reflects Tether's aim to extend its stablecoin influence, exploring the utility of natural resources like boron in stabilizing digital currencies. By leveraging blockchain, Tether seeks to offer a transparent and efficient system that taps into Turkey's boron-rich reserves, potentially revolutionizing how value is transferred and stored.

The collaboration with Turkey underscores the company's strategic vision to innovate in the stablecoin market by exploring unique asset-backing options. Tether envisions this partnership as a path to both strengthen the digital currency ecosystem in Turkey and present a model that could be replicated globally. The utilization of boron, a high-demand mineral with diverse applications, underlines a commitment to sustainability and resource-backed financial solutions.

This proposal comes at a time when countries are increasingly exploring digital currencies' potential to reshape their financial landscapes. If realized, Tetherâ€™s boron-backed tokens could offer Turkey a robust new vehicle for economic development, securing a future where digital and physical assets coalesce seamlessly.

Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 1y Report this post â€œConnectivity is the foundation of our reconciliation strategy. We know that reliable access to technology supports Indigenous Peoplesâ€™ access to education, career opportunities, healthcare, and social support. TELUS is committed to bringing connectivity to more Indigenous communities working closely with Indigenous governments and organizations, along with provincial and federal governments,â€ shares Marissa Nobauer , Director of Reconciliation, Community Engagement and External Relations.

Today we are shining a spotlight on TELUS, who is recognized as a distinguished recipient on the 2023 Indigenomics #10TOWATCH List.

TELUS is taking significant strides in supporting Indigenous communities through their multi-faceted reconciliation strategy. Their reconciliation strategy is co-designed with Indigenous communities, focusing on fostering relationships grounded in Indigenous Ways of Knowing and supporting Indigenous Youth and communities.

Here's a glimpse of their initiatives:

â€¢	Connectivity: Providing high-speed internet access to over 197 Indigenous communities and aiming to connect 20 more Indigenous lands, recognizing its crucial role in education, healthcare, and economic opportunities.
â€¢	Investing in Indigenous Businesses: Striving for 7.5% investment in Indigenous-owned businesses by 2026 through their Pollinator Fund and actively increasing procurement spending with them.
â€¢	Empowering Indigenous Women: Expanding their Mobility for Good program to support Indigenous women facing violence.

TELUS' dedication to Indigenous empowerment shines through their initiatives.

EF-Tu \(elongation factor thermo unstable\) is a prokaryotic elongation factor responsible for catalyzing the binding of an aminoacyl-tRNA \(aa-tRNA\) to the ribosome. It is a G-protein, and facilitates the selection and binding of an aa-tRNA to the A-site of the ribosome. As a reflection of its crucial role in translation, EF-Tu is one of the most abundant and highly conserved proteins in prokaryotes.

Click here for the full article: https://bit.ly/4dgYdiB In 1971, the financial world changed forever with the advent of science-based investing. Research from academics like Gene Fama revealed that markets efficiently price in all available information, making traditional stock-picking ineffective. This breakthrough paved the way for index funds and the democratization of investing, allowing anyone to capture market returns without speculation. Title: Register for Indigenomics SHE conference in Winnipeg - LinkedIn
Description: Sep 5, 2024  Â·  This summit brings together visionaries, innovators, and decision-makers from Europe and Africa to tackle some of the most pressing challengesÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
Register for Indigenomics SHE conference in Winnipeg | Jen Newsted posted on the topic | LinkedIn Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Jen Newstedâ€™s Post Jen Newsted Activating Social Impact & Reconciliation Commitments | Independent Contractor | Settler Disrupting The Status Quo 6mo Report this post Friends, and especially those in, around, or with connection to Winnipeg- are you registered for the upcoming Indigenomics SHE conference taking place September 23 & 24 yet?

The reason I ask is because I get lots of asks from folks looking for connections or introductions to Indigenous folks that I might know. 

Here's the secret to you skipping the step of having to ask me who I know: Activate your reconciliation commitments by intentionally prioritizing getting yourself into spaces that are Indigenous led so that YOU are in fact doing the work to meet, connect, cultivate relationships with Indigenous leaders and businesses. 

The learning that comes from being in Indigenous led spaces, like the annual events the Indigenomics Institute hosts, are phenomenally rich and imperative for our reconciliation responsibility. But you know this because I have been telling you which is why you are reaching out to me. Remember this is our shared responsibility.

Indigenomics SHE has 40 Indigenous leaders who will share their insights, experiences, challenges, successes in government, law, finance, tech, education, communications, fashion, art, tourism, culinary, corporate canada, entrepreneurism.

The conference will be hosted and emceed again this year by three epic humans who are shining brightly in the image from last year's SHE conference. Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D , CEO and founder of Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre of Indigenomics & the Global Indigenous Technology House, Ashley Richard Director, Indigenous Entrepreneurship University of Waterloo and Diane Roussin BA, BSW, M.S.M. ğŸ¦¦ Project Director, The Winnipeg Boldness Project.

Keynotes are from Laurie Sterritt Managing Partner Pathways Executive Search and Victoria LaBillois, MBA owner of Wejipeg Excavation and founder Eloquent Hostess. 

Additionally, in the room are representatives from Women Entrepreneurship Knowledge Hub (WEKH) , TELUS , Vancity , Alliance Trust Company, Calgary, Canada , BFL CANADA , RBC and Scotiabank who are all actively contributing to #Indigenomics as partners and sponsors.

Reconciliation is about relationships and relationships do not happen in documents collecting dust. Please get in this room AND bring your c-suite, your board members, your teams, your clients because my goodness the opportunities that we have to actually show up in reconciliation are abundant - shift status quo behaviour so you stop being the barrier of why you/your company's reconciliation isn't progressing. 

If you can't physically be there you can still contribute by committing to an Accessibility package that will allow for Indigenous folks to participate on your behalf. This is also how we start to cultivate relationships. 

Finally, here's another super simple way to action reconciliation: Copy the link below and put it in your newsletters. It isn't difficult friends, unless we make it.

Passionate and writing about inclusion, power dynamics, regenerative cultures, community & change-making 7mo Edited Report this post ğŸŒ Exciting news: I'll join the Gathering Of Tribes in Portugal from September 11th to 15th! This event brings together regenerative entrepreneurs, change-makers, activists, and community builders across ecosystems for a co-created experience where we connect, learn from each other, and build community across different initiatives. Initially, I had some reservations (the use of "tribes" did raise a few questions...). However, this event genuinely seems to be a space where regenerators want to share, learn, and remember that weâ€™re working towards the same goals and cooperation is the way. ğŸ¤ğŸŒ±

As part of my participation, Iâ€™ve chosen to join Claudia Marras at the CoPartnerUp camp, where Iâ€™ll be offering workshops on facilitation, to help participants enhance their power to foster collaboration and co-creation in their teams. I was drawn to this camp because of its focus on fostering meaningful collaborations and partnershipsâ€”areas that are deeply aligned with my work at Moving Mindsets Facilitation . ğŸ’¬âœ¨

âš¡ï¸ My intention in joining the Gathering goes beyond simply connecting and collaborating. By co-creating a global community of changemakers and facilitators, we can contribute to building a culture of care, genuine transformation, and collective liberationâ€”all while recognizing the deep disparities that exist in our world, perpetuated by structural barriers and systems of oppression. This collaborative (and often privileged) work must aim not only for greater equity but also for dismantling the oppressive structures that continue to perpetuate injustice. âœŠ

ğŸ“£ If you're coming or want to know more about the Gathering (or join me at CoPartnerUp camp), feel free to message me! Letâ€™s connect, share ideas, and work together towards collective liberation and a culture of care for ourselves, each other, and the planet. ğŸŒ¿â¤ï¸ #GatheringOfTribes #Regeneration #CoCreation #Facilitation #Collaboration #CollectiveLiberation #Care #SocialJustice #Sustainability #Changemakers 19 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in World MAP [Meaning&Purpose Summit] 54 followers 3mo Report this post The World Meaning and Purpose Summit is more than just an eventâ€”it is a movement.

A movement to inspire concrete actions that transform not only our own lives but also our communities and the world around us. This is a call to those who believe that the future belongs to those who dare to live and lead with purpose.

In a world facing a crisis of meaning, many individuals who believe in and dedicate their lives to bringing purpose into the world often feel isolated. Despite their passion and commitment, we can frequently find ourselves navigating this journey alone, feeling the weight of a world that doesnâ€™t always prioritize purpose and meaning.

At the World Meaning and Purpose Summit, we aim to change that. By connecting globally, we create a powerful network of like-minded individuals who share a common vision of a more purposeful world. Together, we will build a community that offers support, encouragement, and inspiration, reminding each of us of our unique calling and the impact we are meant to make.

We believe that by fostering meaningful dialogue, creating connections, and encouraging actionable insights, we can empower individuals and organizations to lead with authenticity, resilience, and purpose. 4 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Nanaimo Prosperity Corporation 812 followers 6mo Report this post The Summit You Canâ€™t Afford to Miss

The State of The Island Economic Summit is more than just an eventâ€”itâ€™s a game-changer for Vancouver Islandâ€™s economy. ğŸ’¼âœ¨

With conference delegates spending an average of $390 per day and the conference centre injecting $105 million into Nanaimo since 2008, the impact is substantial. ğŸ’µğŸ“Š

But, this summit isnâ€™t just about numbers; itâ€™s about driving real prosperity. By fostering valuable partnerships among business owners, community leaders, and entrepreneurs, it's propelling the Island forward. ğŸŒŸ

And itâ€™s not just about the local scene. Hosting this summit enhances Vancouver Islandâ€™s reputation as a key economic hub, attracting interest and investment.

Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s in store:

ğŸ”· Action Lab Workshops: Dive into hands-on learning.

Nanaimo Prosperity Corporation is excited to see you there. Donâ€™t miss out! 

For more details, click the link in the comments.ğŸ”—ğŸ‘‡ 21 3 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Planet Health Innovation Network 521 followers 7mo Edited Report this post We had the privilege of hearing from Lucas Hunter of B Lab , a remarkable nonprofit organisation, at the recent Planet Health Table discussion. Lucas highlighted a critical insight: â€œTo transform the system companies understand that they must work in a collective way.â€ ğŸ¤ B Lab Spain is paving the way for this transformation by creating spaces where diverse organisations can come together, connect with key stakeholders, and collaboratively drive change for #Health and the #Planet â€” both environmentally and socially. ğŸŒ±

One standout initiative is Barcelona + Bâ€”an alliance of businesses, educational institutions, the public sector, social and cultural entities. This alliance exemplifies Lucas and his teamâ€™s ambitious vision for a more interdisciplinary approach to tackling global challenges. ğŸŒ

However, as Lucas pointed out, â€œThe biggest challenge we are facing as a movement is to settle the expectation between times.â€â³ The public sector often moves slowly, taking years to implement regulations, which can be a significant hurdle for private sector initiatives. Yet, it's through these challenges that innovation thrives, as both sectors learn to work together more effectively.

Letâ€™s keep pushing forward, inspired by B Labâ€™s vision and commitment to collective action! ğŸš€ #Sustainability #Collaboration #Innovation #PublicPrivatePartnership #Sustainability #PlanetHealth Jordi Serrano Pons , Jordi AlcalÃ  TorrÃ³ , Luismi Roura , Trinidad De Frutos Herranz , Kathrine Raleigh , Manel Balcells , Michael Donaldson , Magnolia Restrepo SÃ¡nchez , Montse Guardia Guell , Claudia Fernandez de Cordoba Farini , Elena Codina , Anna Sala Cunill , Jaume Duran Navarro , Esteve Picola , Carla Oliva Morell , Sonia HernÃ¡ndez-MontaÃ±o Bou , Josep Maria Pique Badia , Marta Anglada Roig , Lucas Hunter , Joan Bigorra , Tim Eaves 61 2 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Institute Of Neurodiversity (ION) 22,060 followers 6mo Edited Report this post The Institute Of Neurodiversity ION is joining the United Nations at the
ğŸŒ Summit of the Future on 22-23 September in New York. Find out more about the event at https://lnkd.in/gfqeZHi9 ğŸŒ What is the Summit of the Future?
The Summit is a high-level event, bringing world leaders together to forge a new international consensus on how we deliver a better present and safeguard the future.

ğŸ¤ Effective global cooperation is increasingly critical to our survival but difficult to achieve in an atmosphere of mistrust, using outdated structures that no longer reflect todayâ€™s political and economic realities.

ğŸŒŸ This once-in-a-generation opportunity serves as a raise the profile of neurodiversity and demonstrate that international cooperation can effectively achieve agreed goals, tackle emerging threats, and seek new opportunities.

Why the Summit matters
ğŸ”„ The speed and complexity of developments have outpaced our systems for cooperating and coping.

ğŸŒ The benefits and opportunities of progress are spread unevenly, with the majority of people left behind.

âš ï¸ The risks and threats are also unevenly felt, disproportionately impacting the most vulnerable.

ğŸŒ Multilateral governance, designed in simpler, slower times, is not adequate to todayâ€™s complex, interconnected, rapidly changing world.

âœ¨ The Summit is an opportunity to take the next steps towards neuroinclusion. 

ION received special accreditation to attend in person as one of the only neurodiversity-focused civil society organisations. Kim Shah , Country Lead of the Institute of Neurodiversity ION Canada , and our Global Lead Silvan Ruthenberg (ğŸ”–) will be representing our members, advocating for our #humanrights and #neuroinclusion globally.

ğŸ¤ We hope to forge many new connections, partnerships, and alliances to jointly create a more inclusive and sustainable world!

ğŸ“… If you are in New York 19 â€“ 24 September â€“ for the SOTF or otherwise and would like to meet, please get in touch. 26 4 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Jason Luboyera CEO & Founder lead b2b LinkedIn Social Selling | I can help you attract quality business relationships & leads 3mo Report this post Happening tomorrow. You should join me!! [4th of December in Cape Town].

Iâ€™m honoured to be speaking at the SEADE R&I Summit, hosted at the Cape Town International Convention Centre (CTICC). 

This summit brings together visionaries, innovators, and decision-makers from Europe and Africa to tackle some of the most pressing challenges of our timeâ€”climate tech, digital transformation, and sustainable development.

Why am I so passionate about this? Because Africa has an extraordinary opportunity to redefine its place in the global innovation ecosystem. 

This isnâ€™t just about participatingâ€”itâ€™s about leading. 

With the right collaboration and investment, we can shape solutions that not only uplift Africa but also contribute to a more interconnected and sustainable global society.

The SEADE R&I Summit is unique because it unites some of the smartest minds to understand how we move forward together as a global society. 

Itâ€™s not just about conversations; itâ€™s about creating actionable steps to bridge the innovation gap between continents.

Iâ€™d love for you to reflect on these questions:

1. What does the future of climate tech and digital transformation look like when Europe and Africa collaborate?

2. How can we better position Africaâ€™s talent and resources to shape global solutions?

If youâ€™re passionate about these topics or simply curious about whatâ€™s possible when innovation knows no borders, I invite you to join the conversation. 

Letâ€™s challenge assumptions, explore opportunities, and inspire change.

This event is hosted in collaboration with Post Growth Expert Melanie Rieback ( University of Amsterdam ) and Generous Minds . ğŸ™Œ 

Infinite growth is not possible on a planet with limited resources. We are all aware of the problems our traditional economic system leads to. Post Growth is not anti-growth. It is about rethinking what kind of growth we need for a thriving future. For example, we need more growth of renewable energy, but we need less excessive growth in waste or luxury goods. ğŸ“Š Generous Minds organizes this event because not many people are yet aware of the opportunities and challenges Post Growth brings for companies, financiers, and expertsğŸ’¡

Weâ€™re looking forward to seeing you there! #impactmeasurement #impactstrategy #postgrowth #businessopportunities 32 4 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in Melissa Pole Founder & CEO @ Pyralume | Tech Architect | SSHRC Researcher, PhD 4mo Report this post SAAS NORTH Conference is one of my favorite events of the year. The hospitality is always exceptional, and I love connecting with other founders, investors, and VCs within the local ecosystem.

One of the standout moments for me was during the keynote talks, where Martin Basiri shared profound insights on leadership. He spoke with such vulnerability about how being a founder means leading with your heart. His words resonated deeply when he said, â€œIf Iâ€™m not fixing a problem, Iâ€™m not satisfied" after joyfully poking fun "I wouldnâ€™t be happy sitting on a beach.â€ It was funny, relatable, and a perfect reflection of the passion that drives founders and their crazy dreams.

This year was particularly special, as I had the chance to connect with incredible people like Forbes journalist Monique Danao, share moments with The Firehood who I pitched to last year when my company was only a few weeks old, and they honoured how far Pyralume has come. It was my first time pitching it last year when I approached Simon Constantineau at Inovia Capital who said his minimum cheque is 1 million. Maybe I was just a little early. ğŸ˜‰

 Always a great time with Suzanne Grant, CD and seeing Jennifer Batley ğŸ’• I love exploring new opportunities & partnerships with other founders & industry professionals. I even met inspiring women from my hometown in Muskoka, like Lauren Valliere , whoâ€™s making waves in Fintech that I'm meeting with later today ğŸ

These gatherings are so much more than conferences to meâ€”they're opportunities to share stories, learn from each other, and strengthen both new and old relationships. Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Dirk Lock, BAâ€™s Post Dirk Lock, BA | Design Anthropologist | Multilevel Design and Futures Researcher | 9mo Report this post Reconciliation and recognition of Indigenous histories and cultures means in National Indigenous Month, and National Indigenous Peoples Day tomorrow. Facilitation of community engagement on systems changes and service management is an encouragement to discuss equity economic growth, social and health services, and rights to education.

A human centered collective that values and acknowledges knowledge pathways and awareness of policies that support Indigenous authorities on language, stewardship, and historic knowledge. Community health and wellbeing is a shared experience, sustainability along a path of decoloniality. Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Advancing #IndigenousEconomy & IndigenomicsAI #indigenousAI 9mo Edited What does #Indigenonics mean to you?
At the Indigenomics Design conference, we asked a few people what it means to them. Yamila Franco Ashley Richard Ifeoma Ngwudike, CPA, CMA #saskatoon #indigenous #wealth Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter To view or add a comment, sign in More Relevant Posts Samantha Panter Two Spirited Cultural Ambassador, DEI Strategist, Indigenous Advisor at K'waahlgahlda 9mo Report this post To me Indigenonics means, looking at the systems, the communities, and individuals then the journey to financial prosperity. 

What does the â€œcustomer journeyâ€ look like in accessing resources?

I have faced this time and time again. People in a financial authority saying that becauwe Iâ€™m Indigenous I have access to so many resources and benefits, yet the journey to access those is so beyond â€œbrokenâ€. Itâ€™s discouraging and disappointing. 

My work is centred around the journey of accessing whatever it is that the person or business is striving towards. 

A plan, goal, or vision is wonderful but the steps in that journey need to be clear and simple. Otherwise we are walking in place; no change. Carol Anne Hilton, MBA, ICD.D Founder of #Indigenomics movement- Indigenomics Institute, Global Centre Indigenomics & Indigenous Technology House. Entrepreneur, Author x 2, Speaker, Advisor. Title: Paul Lacerte (Gilam Giloh), OBC's Post - LinkedIn
Description: Jan 31, 2023  Â·  TELUS Pollinator Fund for Good#reconciliation #Indigenomics #investments #indigenousbusiness Â· View organization page for Raven IndigenousÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
#indigenomics #investments #indigenousbusiness | Paul Lacerte (Gilam Giloh), OBC Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Paul Lacerte (Gilam Giloh), OBCâ€™s Post Paul Lacerte (Gilam Giloh), OBC Co-Founder and Chief Purpose Officer, Raven Indigenous Capital Partners 2y Edited Report this post Teh Beh Mussi Cho (Thank you from the bottom of my heart) for the good medicine that is being shared with our People through this Fund and the investments it will enable.  This milestone represents our shared effort to shift the economic paradigm towards reconciliation, love and healing and I am deeply honoured to be on that journey with our team at Raven Capital, with each of our investors, and with all the incredible Indigenous Founders that we invest in.  By working together, we are implementing Article 3 of the UN DRIP and we are implementing the spirit and intent of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission (TRC) Calls to Action.  Deepest gratitude. Stephen Nairne Jeffrey Cyr Jeff Ward Lawrence Lewis Bobbie Racette Jenn Harper Keith McIntosh Aaron Aaron Lambie Aaron Joe Amber Buker, J.D. Ginew Navajo Power Home Jace Meyer Carol Anne Hilton, MBA Clint Davis Denise Williams Jay Calhoun Kate Finn Garry McBerryhill Devon Krainer Mitch Langan Alisa Denduyf Joshua A. Jonas Hunter Sage Lacerte Valerie Red-Horse Mohl Rally Assets Canadian Council for Aboriginal Business National Aboriginal Capital Corporations Association (NACCA) Common Approach to Impact Measurement Kate Ruff BDC Export Development Canada | Exportation et dÃ©veloppement Canada FCC / FAC InBC Investment Corp. TELUS Pollinator Fund for Good #reconciliation #Indigenomics #investments #indigenousbusiness Raven Indigenous Capital Partners 10,107 followers 2y Edited Raven Indigenous Capital Partners is excited to announce the final closing of a historic $100M (CAD) Indigenous venture capital fund to support Indigenous and Native American entrepreneurs. This fund addresses critical gaps in the Indigenous finance ecosystem and provides a culturally grounded approach to investing. 

The closing of this fund is a critical inflection point for both Indigenous Peoples and impact investing that highlights the positive state and growth of the Indigenous economy. Indigenous and Native American entrepreneurs are rightfully taking their place at the forefront of the economy. 

Backed by some of North America's most prominent foundations and financial institutions, Fund II will build on the success of Fund I to invest exclusively in Indigenous and Native American enterprises that demonstrate commercial viability, potential for scale, and measurable community benefit streams. â€œOur hands are raised in gratitude to all our Fund II investors. This is economic reconciliation in action and an implementation of Article 3 of the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples,â€ said Paul Lacerte, Managing Partner and Chief Impact Officer, Raven Indigenous Capital Partners. 

â€œBy providing the capital and the support that Indigenous entrepreneurs require to succeed, we will continue to build innovative and resilient Indigenous economies that are good for our People and good for the planet.â€ Jeff Cyr, Managing Partner for Raven Capital and CEO of the Raven Indigenous Impact Foundation. #Indigenousbusiness #Nativeamerican #Nativeamericanbusiness #impactinvesting 56 6 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Seth Asimakos Social Entrepreneur 2y Report this comment Awesome to hear. Congratulations to the whole team! I love your work and fund and plan to tell a lot of folks about you!!! Extracted_Text:
#indigenousprosperity #indigenomics #gerryrocks | Shannin Metatawabin ICD.D | 24 comments Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Shannin Metatawabin ICD.Dâ€™s Post Shannin Metatawabin ICD.D CEO at National Aboriginal Capital Corporation Association (NACCA) 3y Edited Report this post It is so important to highlight people in our lives who demonstrate allyship.Â  These souls care about and understand the barriers, inequities and injustice perpetuated on Indigenous peoples.Â  I would like to recognize NACCA CSO Gerry Huebner for his unrelenting passion and contribution to the AFI network. 
We worked together 20 years ago with Aboriginal Business Canada and now we work together administering and growing this program and network. Over the last number of years we introduced a market ready Indigenous Growth Fund, a Women's program, renewed AEP support, rolled out Covid business supports, solidified the Indigenous Prosperity ForumÂ  (one of the most impactful events in Canada), added 500M in programming - which will lead to positive socioeconomic impacts for our communities. One dollar added, in turn multiplies back into the whole economy.Â  Thank you Gerry, Thank you to your powerhouse of a fiancÃ© Kim, and the entire NACCA team, network and board for your contribution to bettering society as a whole and making Indigenous Prosperity a reality. My heart is full from all of your efforts. #indigenousprosperity #indigenomics #gerryrocks 108 24 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Radek Bandzierz Director General at Canadian Government (Ret) 3y Report this comment Good one Gerry Like Reply 1Â Reaction Gordon Miles Retired 3y Report this comment Well deserved! Title: #tahltanstrong #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness | Mindy Henyu
Description: Jul 4, 2022  Â·  Great way to start the week! Attending my Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC) Annual General Meeting in Dease Lake today.
Extracted_Text:
#tahltanstrong #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness | Mindy Henyu Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Mindy Henyuâ€™s Post Mindy Henyu Indigenous Relations Leader | Purpose Driven Tahltan/Nehiyaw Woman | Creates Prosperity Through Collaboration 2y Report this post Great way to start the week!

Attending my Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC) Annual General Meeting in Dease Lake today.

Did you know TNDC is the largest Indigenous-owned business in British Columbia with over 500 employees and over $70M in revenue last year? #TahltanStrong #indigenomics #indigenousbusiness 104 1 Comment Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Audrey Hlembizky CEO| Mining | Agriculture | ESG | Building Inclusive & Psychologically Safe Cultures | Organizational Development | Leadership & Workforce Training & Coaching 2y Report this comment Yes! During my work and site visits to Red Chris and had the opportunity to meet and work with so many great leaders from this organzization and the people within the community. The Tahltan Nation Development Corporation (TNDC) should really create a blue print to lead, empower and train other Indigenous owned and led organizations in North America towards successful economic development! Keep leading the way! Fyi. Working to advance #Indigenomics Have a blessed day and safe travels to all. Indigeno Travel 638 followers 2y We're thrilled to announce that Dennis Meeches, former longtime Chief of Long Plain First Nation, and more recently the chief spokesperson for the seven First Nations of Treaty One, has accepted the position of Chair of the Board of Directors of Indigeno Travel.

Dennis was instrumental in the economic growth of Long Plain's Arrowhead Development Corporation, made major contributions towards securing Naawi-Oodena (formerly known as Kapyong Barracks), and currently sits as President of Tribal Councils Investment Group.

Under Dennis' leadership, hundreds of jobs have been created. He is an excellent fit for leading Indigeno Travel with our goal to hire, train and employ Indigenous people in the travel industry. 63 7 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Alan Lagimodiere 2y Report this comment Congratulations Like Reply 1Â Reaction Michael Meeches Personal Assistant 2y Report this comment Congratulations Dennis!!! Title: Jani Djokic (she/her), MES' Post - LinkedIn
Description: Aug 2, 2022  Â·  " - Steve Rennalls, Operations Manager, Snowline #greeneconomy #indigenomics. One of the three main components to the system, the solarÂ ...
Extracted_Text:
#greeneconomy #indigenomics #mineralexploration | Jani Djokic (she/her), MES Agree & Join LinkedIn By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedInâ€™s User Agreement , Privacy Policy , and Cookie Policy . Skip to main content LinkedIn Articles People Learning Jobs Games Join now Sign in Jani Djokic (she/her), MESâ€™ Post Jani Djokic (she/her), MES Chief Executive Officer at Na-Cho Nyak Dun Development Corporation

Shaking things up. Investing in circular economies. 2y Edited Report this post Thank you to all the folks at Snowline Gold Corp. (CSE:SGD)(OTC:SNWGF) and Solvest Inc who helped make this happen with us. Special thanks to Ben Power , Scott Berdahl , Steve Rennalls , and Kara Kolkman for bringing all your creativity to the table on this file and making space for greener solutions at remote exploration sites via investments and innovation from Indigenous businesses.

This project was supported with funding from Yukon Development Corporation and Northern REACHE, under the Office of the Minister of Crown-Indigenous Relations #greeneconomy #indigenomics #mineralexploration Na-Cho NyÃ¤k Dun Development Corporation 890 followers 2y NACHO NYAK DUN DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION ANNOUNCES AN AGREEMENT WITH SNOWLINE GOLD TO POWER MAIN CAMP WITH A LARGE-SCALE SOLAR GENERATOR

TUESDAY, AUGUST 2, 2022 â€“ MAYO, YUKON: The Nacho Nyak Dun Development Corporation (NNDDC) has entered into a 5-year agreement with Snowline Gold Corp. (CSE:SGD)(OTC:SNWGF) (Snowline) to lease a 27-kilowatt portable solar generator system for Snowlineâ€™s exploration project in the Selwyn Basin. This project is located within the Traditional Territory of the First Nation of Na-Cho Nyak Dun (FNNND). This investment will help reduce carbon emissions and provide economic benefits within the green economy.
This solar generator, which was designed and built by Solvest Inc and is one of the first of its kind in the Yukon, will be used to power Snowlineâ€™s off-grid 45-person "Forksâ€ camp on its Rogue Project in the Eastern Yukon. Estimates provided by Solvest, based on data collected from Snowlineâ€™s 2021 field program, predict the new solar generator will have estimated total fuel savings per season of 12,572L of diesel and reduce the campâ€™s direct diesel consumption by up to 90% for the season. Not only does this project help to reduce direct consumption, but also reduces the indirect fuel consumption required to transport fuel to the site, which includes trucking fuel to Mayo and then to the site via airplane. This will have a net positive impact on the project from an environmental and financial perspective.

â€œInvestments such as this are examples of how Indigenous businesses are leading the way in accelerating the green economy, and innovations such as this provide opportunities for such entities to become increasingly engaged in the mineral resource sector. We see this investment as just the first of many of its kind and we are working towards building a fleet that can be deployed throughout the Traditional Territory.â€ - Jani Djokic (she/her) , CEO, NNDDC

The system consists of 3 main components: the power module, the battery module and the solar panel module. The size of the system was based on data collected during the 2021 exploration season. The system reduces the generator operating time and fuel consumption. Reduced operating time for the generator allows camp noise to be reduced, creating a better quality of life for employees due to the reduction of noise pollution. The reduction in sound is also expected to have a positive impact on the wildlife in the surrounding areas. Installation of the solar generator is complete, and the system is now fully operational, providing a majority of the campâ€™s power.

"This project is a tangible representation of how Snowline is realizing our Corporate Vision. It increases efficiency while creating financial and environmental value. It improves our employees' work environment, it is yet another partnership with the NNDDC, and it is being provided by Solvest, one of Yukon's most innovative companies." - Steve Rennalls , Operations Manager, Snowline #greeneconomy #indigenomics 41 4 Comments Like Comment Share Copy LinkedIn Facebook Twitter Vidya Vankayala 2y Report this comment Very inspiring outcome, glad to see large scale solar project like this happen Like Reply 1Â Reaction Michael Bakaic ğŸ§² Cyber Lead Magnets for MSPs | Founder @ Iceberg Cyber ğŸ§Š 2y Report this comment ğŸ‘ Like Reply 1Â Reaction Matthew Simard Pre-Construction | Sustainability | VDC 2y Report this comment Awesome work! Exciting project and a great team! Like Reply 1Â Reaction Sonny Banjac, AScT, B.Tech. Experienced technical sales specialist with leadership experience spread across civil construction, renewable energy and manufacturing industries. 2y Report this comment Glad to see that NNDDC has continued to advance it's renewable energy aspirations. Keep up the good work Jani. All the best.
